row.cell: Item sold sent Nycholas cote & woode greately eatyn wyth mothes
Item sold & toke of the sylver & stonys & sold them by the selffe
Item sold the bare myter vnto a paynter of sudbury hall

div.p: This garment and mitre had once been used by the boy bishop in Long Melford, in ceremonies abolished under the brief reign of Edward VI. This account was made by churchwardens William Dyke and William Marchall.

row.cell: Item of the profitt of a game kepptt at witsontyde
Item to Mr Rycherd Clopton for a seme of malt Ageynst þe gamyng
Item to Hammont for proclaymyng the games at BrantreBrantre: Braintree, Essex, & to peter for proclaymyng them at ypwyche
Item for borowyng of pottes at ye gamyng
Item to Bettes for settyng of xiij settes in ye Churche yerd
Item layd owt for that was owyng for ye games & for frynge

div.p: This folio of the account includes receipts of 41s 1d from a church ale, plus 22s 1d from a gathering made at the same ale by the the 'bachelors' (so identified in the subsequent entry), and a further 35s by the same bachelors. The bachelors routinely conducted gatherings on Plough Monday but the entry does not identify the ale in these entries as having occurred on Plough Monday, nor do the entries refer to mimetic activities (as would have occurred, for example, at a Whitsun Ale).
Folio 36v is headed 'Anno domini 1555' but no day/month range is specified. The sum at the foot of the previous folio is for 'one hole yere endyed at Ianuarye Anno Domini 1554.'
Folio 39 is headed 'Anno domini 1556,' and f 40v 'Anno domini 1557, both with no day/month range specified.

'[M]alet' (f 39) in this instance may mean 'malt' because on f 46, the miller of Hall Mill was paid for the grinding of two seams (sixteen bushels) of malt for the church ale. A seam equals two coombes. A coombe of grain equals four bushels. Therefore the parish bought two bushels. The purchase of malt against the gaming seemingly indicates that the play or game was mounted in conjunction with, or as part of, a church ale.
It was apparently the practice in Long Melford to send a single person to proclaim its game (and a different person for each place), rather than sending a troupe to cry the bans.

row.cell: Item paid to ffyrmin the glasier for mendinge the windowes that were broke at the scoole masters playe

div.p: The account is chronologically arranged, and the entry for the schoolmaster's play comes between midsummer and 2 October. An elementary school was present in Long Melford before 1484, and in 1548 a deed refers to Sir Edward Tyrell, a stipendiary priest of Long Melford as aiding the curate and teaching a grammar school at Long Melford (VCH: Suffolk, vol 2, p 340). The records do not indicate the venue at which the schoolmaster's play was performed.

The Long Melford churchwardens' accounts between 1573 and 1641 (FL 509/5/1) contain many payments to a widow known as 'waytes wyfe' or 'wedow wayte' (ff [1, 3v, 4, and ff]) and to another woman for keeping the deceased man's children (f [1v]). Whether he had been a musician is unclear from the records, but his family required poor relief from the parish. Typical is the entry 'payd to waites wyfe vj d.' (f [3v]).

div.head: single membrane
div.ab: The Scite of the Rectory with a hall and parlor at the west end thereof, and twoo butt ryes on the Est, being vnder one roofe, tyled throughout, with one stable & malting howse therevnto adioyning, and a barne with three bay=steds, all of them thacht togither with a yard , orchard=plot, & to est as they ly betwixt the Church=yard there in part, & the lands of Edmund Wittipot knight in part on the Est, and the lands of Akenham=hall in the tenure of Iohn Rose on. the west abutting vpon Maypole pyghtell south, and vpon the glebe-land of the said parsonage north, Containing togither by estimacion terce acres (more or les).

div.p: According to Birch, 'Rise Hall, near the church, is a late Georgian building on the site of an ancient manor house, formerly the residence of the Le Ruse or Rous family in the C13,' an apparent reference to Akenham Hall (Ancient Sites, p 16).

row.cell: Item paid to ye bearwarde of my Lordes beares

div.p: The closest dated entry before this payment occurred on 1 July 1567; the closest entry to follow is 24 September 1567. Thus this payment to the bearward occurred between those two dates.

Thomas Howard (p 34; 1537/8–72) was ninth duke of Norfolk and fifteenth earl of Surrey from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex, Kenninghall, Norfolk, and Duke's Palace, Norwich; he was executed for treason. See P&P.

row.cell: Item paid to Iohn browne ye mynstrell in parte of payment for ye clock
Item paid to ye Dukes bearwarde at ye balliffs comandement
Item paid for cartynge of Iohn Arnolde and alis smarte abowte þe towne & for þe pyper
Item paid to Iohn browne ye mynstrell more for ye dyall

div.p: The penultimate entry on f 12 (occuring two entries after the payment to the piper) refers to a meeting that was planned to occur on 15 August, indicating, as do several references to the payment of quarterly wages, that the payments on this folio were all made in August.
Browne the minstrel is one of several persons, including the priest, who were paid for contributing to the refurbishing of the clock.

A partial picture of John Browne can be pieced together from the several entries that mention him. In 1567–8 he is identified as a minstrel and in 1573–4 as a wait. He is paid in 1573–4 and 1574–5 for having a blind boy in his care, probably a poor boy taken as as an apprentice musician, since later records (see below) show that to have been the practice in Aldeburgh. These payments for wood at the church and for whiting the church, show him to have been employed, at least intermittently, by the parish. It is impossible to know whether the reference to stages indicates carpenter's scaffolding or stages for playing, but the Queen's Men did play in Aldeburgh that year. Someone named Brown, presumably this person, was dead in 1573–4 (f 78v) and a different person (John Batche) then took responsibility for the clock.
Thomas Howard (1537/8–1572) was duke of Norfolk from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex and Kenninghall, Norfolk; he was executed for treason.

row.cell: Item for wood for Iohn browne at ye Churche
Item to Iohn browne for whiting ye Church
Item to Iohn browne for ij bushelles of glovers shredes
Item for nayles to mak the stagis

div.p: The church referred to on f 49v is the Aldeburgh parish church of Saints Peter and Paul. It is built near the site of a Saxon church.
This payment to the Queen's players on f 52v occurs between entries dated 1 November and 1 December.
Elizabeth Tudor (f 52v; 1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

row.cell: To ye Blind boy being sent to mr brovnes
To Mr Bayly periman for Riding to ye Sessions with the blind boye
To thomas Smithes wiff for a ffourthnightes bourde of ye Blind boy

div.p: Mr Periman, who carried the blind boy to the sessions on f 67v, was one of the town's two bailiffs, the other being Mr Bence, in 1572-3. In 1574 Mr Periman reimbursed the town 6d for his seal of office (f 77). In that same year, his fellow bailiff, Mr Bence, received 24s for 2 cades (half-barrels) of full herrings, and 3 shillings for 2 cades of spratt (smelt) (f 80). Fishing was the town's principal commercial activity. In the same year the town paid Mr Periman for his dinner while travelling about the town's business (f 80). Of particular relevance to this collection, in 1584-5 Mr Periman paid unnamed players 10s. By 1595 Periman had disappeared from the records, replaced by a new bailiff, one Mr Nelson. Mr Bence continued.

row.cell: To Robert Hind for a Iyrken a paire of briches for making linyng & buttons for the same for ye blind Boye
To parsonne for a paire of shoes for ye blind boye
To thomas Smithes wiff for vj weekes keping of þe blinde boye at ij s. vj d. ye weke
To thomas smithes wiff for ye blind boyes bourd iij weekes & iij dayes at ij s. vj d. ye week
ffor a Shirt for ye blind boye
To ye earle of Lecesters menne when thei plaied in ye ChurchChurch: ie, of Saints Peter and Paul ye xxti of Ivne
To Robert LettesRobert Lettes: the town crier for his quater wages at mydsomer
more to him for writing of ye mvster book
more to him for going to mennes hovss to Bydd them to come to ffremans to ye play
More to him for him: John Foxe, one of the town's two bailiffs Mr caves man for ye blind boy
To thomas browne ye wait when he Receyved the Blind Boye

div.p: The Freman (or ffreman, who hosted the play on f 80v, was an innkeeper (Winn, Records, p 11).

The earl of Leicester whose men played in the church on f 80v was Robert Dudley (1532–3–88), fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: To thomas Browne for ye blynde boy
for carieng of staging & Ropes for ye church
Item paid to peter Hont mvsicion for taking blind Harry to prentis
To thomas Lovenes his wiff for ye said harries bedd
To Brovne þe wait for blind harrie
To my Lord of Bathes players

div.p: The entries on ff 103v and 106, as well as the one for 1573–4, seem to indicate that Blind Harry lived in the care of the wait, Thomas Brown, but was apprenticed to another musician, Peter Hunt, or that for some other reason he was shuttled back and forth between the two musicians during these years.
In the general receipts section on f 121, the words 'Blind Harrie' are written large in the left margin, but the reason why is unclear.
The lord of Bath, whose players received a reward on f 114, was William Bourchier (1557–1623), fourth earl of Bath, with residence at Tawstock, Devon. See P&P.

Because of a payment six entries later that was made on Coronation Day (17 November), the payment to Bathes' players was likely made sometime in the first half of November, perhaps even on Coronation Day.
The patron lord Sheafildes mentioned on f 114v was Edmund Sheffield (1565–1646), third Baron Sheffield (of Butterwick) from 1568, with residence at Hammersmith, Middlesex. See P&P.

row.cell: Deliuered at þe commaundment of Mr bailiffes to ye Earle of Leicesters menne

div.p: On f 123v, a payment of wages made six items after this one occurred at Michaelmas 1578, thus the payment to Leicester's Men likely occurred sometime in that same September.

The earl of Leicester whose men were paid on f 123v was Robert Dudley (1532 or 1533–88), fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: paid to my Lord Robertes menne & my Lord howardes menne when they played heere
paid to blynd harry at mr beuershins commandement
paid to Roberte hind for cloth for blinde harry
paid for a Coat for blind harry
more for a paire of bryches & ye making
more for a shirt & a paire of hose for him

div.p: There are no dated entries on f 136v, but the first entry on f 137 is a reckoning dated 3 September 1579, suggesting that the payment to Robert's men and Howard's men occurred in the later part of high summer.

The Lord Robert whose men were paid on 136v, was either Robert Dudley (1532 or 1533–88), fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex, or Robert Rich (c 1537–1580/1), second Lord Rich from 12 June 1567, with seats at Leighs Priory and Rochford Hall, Essex (though he was known as Lord Rich, not Lord Robert). See P&P pages for Robert Dudley and Robert Rich.
The Lord Howard on f 136v was Charles Howard (1536–1624), Lord Howard from 1573 and lord chamberlain 1574–7, tenth earl of Nottingham, with a residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P
An order for payment six entries later on f 138v identifies Mr Beuershin as one of the two bailiffs of the town.

row.cell: for a shalme for blind harry
more for a vyall for him
more for a Case for his vyall
more for a Case for his Shalme
To the mynstrelles at ye Lordes Court
To Iohn Bettes to bye blynd harry a Coat

div.p: The lord who held court on f 147 was Thomas Howard, duke of Norfolk, described as the lord of Aldeborough in letters patent granted on 21 October 1568 (see Great Britain, Historical Manuscripts Commission, Report on Manuscripts in Various Collections, W.D. Macray (ed), vol 4 (Dublin, 1907), 280).
Thomas Howard (1537/8– 1572) was duke of Norfolk from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex and Kenninghall, Norfolk; he was executed for treason. See P&P.
Based on nearby entries in the account, the transaction on f 148 occurred in the Christmas season 1580.

row.cell: paid for the waites vittelles & gatests at christmes Court
paid to the Players ye iijd day of Avgust at mr bayliffes commandement
paid to Lionell manclarke for making of the devilles Coat
paid for paynting of ye devilles coat

div.p: Concerning the payments made to the Queen's players on f 180, payments made three entries before and six entries after it, the payment to the Queen's players occurred between 1 June and Midsummer.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

Entries for the devil's coat on f 182 occur between entries dated (respectively) 6 October and 20 October. Winn, Records, p 11, dates the entries related to the devil's coat as occurring in 1581, but they occurred in 1582-3. The bailiff's payment to 'the Players' on 3 August, and payments for gear related to the devil, suggest that these were local players likely performing a morality play.
The payment on f 183 is preceded, two entries earlier, by a payment made on the Sunday before Christmas 1583, thus this payment was likely made for a play on or near Christmas.

row.cell: paid for a coat for blynd harry
Item gyven to the Earle of Arundels players
paid to gryffyn for ye iiijor waites dynners

div.p: On f 194, based on a dated entry several entries earlier and one immediately after, this purchase for Harry was made between 13 and 26 April.

On f 195v, the entry immediately preceding this one, to the earl of Arundel's players, is dated 8 July 1584. The next dated entry, on the following leaf, is 15 August. Arundel's players likely visited c 7 July.
Philip Howard (1557–1595) was twenty-fifth earl of Arundel from 1579/80 to 14 January 1589, when he was attainted. He had residences at Arundel Castle, Sussex, and West Horsley, Surrey. See P&P.

row.cell: paid the xvijth of Ianuary for the waites
paid to mr periman for the players

div.p: The page containing this payment to the players has no dated entries. The nearest dated entry on the previous page is dated 20 September. Mr Periman was one of the town's two bailiffs at this time; the other was Mr Bence). In 1574 Mr Periman, for example, reimbursed the town 6d for his seal of office (f 77). In that same year, his fellow bailiff, Mr Bence, received 24s for 2 cades (half- barrels) of full herrings, and 3 shillings for 2 cades of spratt (smelt) (f 80). Fishing was the town's principal commercial activity. In the same year, the town paid Mr Periman for his dinner while traveling about the town's business(f 80). In 1581-2, Leicester's men received 20s at the command of the bailiffs (f 123v). By 1595, Periman had disappeared from the records, replaced by a new bailiff, one Mr Nelson. Mr Bence continued.

row.cell: paide to Blinde Harrie þe xxjth of maye 86
paid ye xxixth of September to Anthonie benedick for playeng of the drvmme

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I of England 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

row.cell: paid to blind harrie with þe consent of master baylie ye iijde daye of Aprill 87 to bye him an instrument
paid to Roberte Bredlie for iij hornes
Gyven to my Lord admiralles players ye 28 of maye 87.
paid to Blinde Harrie ye .8. daye of Ivne 87. to bye him an Instrument
Gyuen to the Qvenes players þe 19. of Iulie
paid to Anthonie Benedick for his wagis in keping ye Drvmme for ye watch

div.p: The lord admiral referenced on f 237v was Charles Howard c 1536–1624,) lord high admiral from 1585, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Patron of the players paid on f 238v was Elizabeth Tudor 1533–1602/3), crowned 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

row.cell: paid to my lord of lesters men by Comaundment of Mr Baillies
paid to Bennedycke for one yere wages for playenge one the Drume and iiij d gevene to his boye
paid to the Quenes Players the xvjth daye

div.p: Concerning the payment to Leicester's Men on f 257, the two entries immediately preceding iton f 257 are dated 13 September, so the payment to Leicester's Men likely occurred on or near that date.
Robert Dudley (1532 or 1533–88) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.
Payment to the Queen's players on f 259v occurred during the month of December.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I of England on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

row.cell: paid to the Quenes players the 30th of Maye
paid the 21 daye to the Earle of Essex Players
paid to the Earle of Sussex Players

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (f 274; 1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I of England 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.
On f 277v, the second entry is dated 2 October and succeeding entries, including this one, proceed through the month.
The earl of Essex referenced on f 277v was Robert Devereux (1565–1600/1), nineteenth earl of Essex from 1576, with seat at Cassiobury House, near Watford, Hertfordshire. See P&P.

The first entry on f 280 was made on the last day of January. The next dated payment, occurring four items after the payment to the players, was made on 14 March 1588/9. Thus the players were likely paid between early and mid-March.
The patron of the players paid on f 180 was Henry Radcliffe (1533–93), ninth earl of Sussex from 9 October 1583, with residence at New Hall, Essex. See P&P.
The payment to the players occurs amidst a cluster of payments for wages made for Michaelmas quarter; thus the players were likely paid shortly before or at Michaelmas.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I of England 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

row.cell: To her Maiesties plaiers the xjth of October 1592
To my Lorde Morlies men the same tyme
To my Lorde Ambrose ‸ Admyralls Plaiers

div.p: The entries on ff 328–8v and 329–9v are all in an account that runs from Michaelmas 1591 through Michaelmas 1592. Either the scribe got the year wrong or he made the account sometime at least a week after the accounting year had ended at Michaelmas 1592.
The payment to the queen's players on f 328v is the only dated payment on ff 328v-9, so it is impossible to know the date of this second visit by those players.
The queen referenced on f 328v and 329 was Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3), crowned Elizabeth I of England 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

On f 328v, the patron Lord Morley was Edward Parker (1551–1618), twelfth Baron Morley from 22 May 1577 and twelfth Lord Morley from 22 October 1577, with residences at Hallingbury Place, Essex and Hornby Castle, Lancashire. See P&P.

The only dated entry, on f 329v, was made on Coronation Day (17 November). It occurs five payments after the payment to Blind Henry and four entries before the payment to the Admiral's Men, so both were made circa November.
Charles Howard (c 1536–1624) was lord high admiral from 1585, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.

div.head: f 118 (7 June)
div.ab: Humphrie Swaine a Youthe, and seruante to one of her Maiesties players was buried the same daie 1591.

div.p: The previous entry says 7 June. Winn, Records, p 12, transcribes this burial as occurring in 1571, but that seems a typographical error since the burial clearly occurred in 1591.
Adjacent dated entries in the account indicate that this payment occurred between 3 February and 3 March.
Charles Stuart (1600–48/9) was prince of Wales from 4 November 1616 until his accession to the Crown on 27 March 1625. See P&P.

row.cell: To William Younges for a head for the Towne Drum
To Thomas ffiske for a hoope for the drum
To Charles Waren for mendinge the Towne drum
Paid for a newe head for the Towne drum and for putting it on
To ffrancis Chapman for his sonnes beating the drum for the watche till Saint Michaell
To Zacharie Chaundler for beatinge the drum
To Iohn Cowebridge for tryminge the Towne drum
Paid mr Iohn Blowers for his sonnes beatinge the drum to set the wache
Paid Sir Thomas Glemhames drummer for tryminge the Towne drum for heades cord hoopes and braces and his worke and for bringinge it home
To Iohn Crisp for carryinge the Drum to the tryminge

div.p: Sir Thomas Glemham (c 1594–1649) of Glemham Hall, Little Glemham, Suffolk was knighted in 1617, and served as MP for Aldeburgh in 1625 and 1626. He was a politician and a soldier of considerable reputation as a battlefield commander, described by Gordon Blackwood as 'the most famous of all the Suffolk royalists and very like the Cavalier of fiction' (Tudor and Stuart Suffolk (Lanacaster, 2001), 148).

row.cell: Geuen by the apointment of Mr Bayliffes to the Kinges players

div.p: The payment immediately preceding the payment to the players is dated 7 August.
Charles Stuart (1600–48/9) was crowned Charles I of England on 27 March 1625. See P&P.

row.cell: Geven to the Players that they might not play
To George Nun for baies lace and silke for a coller for the Towne drum

div.p: The only dated entry on the page (f 138v) is one made on 7 May, but references to perambulation day occur repeatedly throughout the entries on the page; thus the players very likely performed before midsummer.
Charles Stuart (1600–48/9) was crowned Charles I of England on 27 March 1625. See P&P.
The payment on f 139v occurs amidst a cluster of payments of wages that were due at Michaelmas, thus these players were likely paid near 29 September.

row.cell: More to himhim: Richard Chapman, drummer for the town of old debt for beating the drum to set the watche
More to himhim: Richard Boone for headinge the Towne drum six seuerall tymes and for a head as per bill appeereth
to Richard Chapman for beating the drum
paid Thomas ffaken for looking to childen playing in the Church for a quarter of a yeere due at Saint Michaell
to Thomas ffaken for looking to children playinge in the Church for a quarter of a yeere due at Chrismas

div.head: single sheet (20 March)
div.ab: Item I give vnto Iohanna Cunisby my Yongest daughter the payre of virginalls that were her ffathers

div.ab: one Vyoll one Lute

one paire of old virginales

body.head: Suffolk, Bacon of Redgrave Hall 1628 SUBC04

div.head: single sheet (18 July)
div.ab: Acording to your worshipfull deriction: I have bought a drume: and have sent it by the berry Carriear: this weecke: it is in a barrill Case: and locked: with a pad locke: I boought it of one of the drumers of our Artilery gardon: it hath ben all oon his drume this nine years to my knowleg: and is estemed to be so good a drume as any is in all England: ther is a small Cracke in the rime: next to the nales: but hee dothe warrantt: that it shall never goe any further: for it hath bine so: ever since it was made: I Cased him to tacke out one of the heads: that I might locke in to the rime: and I found: it to be very sound: if I had not had: some great in trust in him: I could not have bought it of him for any mony: I have sent the key of the locke hear inclosed: if your worshipfull have any: other service: to comand me att any other time: or nowe: I shall be ready att your worshipfull Comand: Soe with my Sirvice to your worshipfull remembrance: I ‸leave you: to the protiticion:protiticiion: for protection? of the most heigh: and Rest

row.cell:
Your worshipfull to Comand to
His Power: Abraham Viell

div.ab: pt:pt: characters lost due to tear at left edge of sheet; possibly for postscript it is sertinly thought: (and also reported) that we shall have pece with Spaine: wich I thinke will be good for us in thes times:

div.head: p 4 (2 November–2 November)(List of Brothers and Sisters of the Guild of St Peter)
div.ab: owre menstrell to
toto to: dittography owre gelde he
to haue ffor hys
mede xij d. &
hys checeWylliam … chece: These six lines are bracketed together on the left.

div.head: p 6
div.ab: Nicholaus plowman mynstrall of the Gyld of Senyt petre he havyng to hys wages xvj d.
Crystofur ‸frater Cagge mynstrall
he to haue hys wages xvj d.

div.p: In 1521 Blomefeld (p 4) provided a cow as surety for another man (presumably the fee involved for admission to the guild?). The entry suggests that athough Blomefeld was a minstrel he was also a farmer. That double identity appears in the wills of a number of local musicians in Suffolk. Bardwell's guild of St Peter 'had a membership which comprised most of the adult population of the village' (Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 66.
The Nicholas entry spans the first line of p 6. Below it, names are listed in two columns with the Crystofur entry written in the middle of the page to the right of the right-hand column.

div.head: single sheet (5 November)
div.ab: Item in the wevynge shoppe

row.cell: & sarten parell for morres dancers & other empellmentes with the belles bels

div.p: The morris dancing gear is the eighteenth of twenty-four listings of items (some of these are groups of items) found in Mauldon's weaving shop. The inventory also lists numerous items in the hall, chamber, buttery, and shop (perhaps a different shop) of his home.

div.head: f 79 (22 February)
div.ab: Item lego pro ffesto sancti nicholai vnam mitram cum cambuca decenti & conuenienti predicte ecclesie de Boxford &c

div.head: f 79 (22 February)
div.ab: Likewise I leave for the feast of St Nicholas one mitre with an appropriate and suitable crook to the aforesaid church of Boxford, etc

div.p: The only other reference to the boy bishop in these accounts occurs in 1541–2 (p 66 of the accounts). See .

row.cell: Item payd ffor bred & alle ffor stoke play

div.p: This account was declared on 10 January 1529/30.

The hokepott (hock pot or hoc pot) appears annually through 1546–7 among amounts received. It is usually positioned near the Plough Monday receipts, but is always distinct from them, and the hocpot amounts always far exceed those from ales or Plough Monday gatherings. It seems likely that the hocpot refers to the kind of gathering activity traditionally held at Hocktide (on the Monday and/or Tuesday after Easter, thus between 31 March and 4 May). It might be a one or a two-day event. If the latter, men imprisoned (or bound) women on Monday (or confiscated their shoes) until the women paid release money. Women similarly captured the men on Tuesdays. The money raised by the women always far exceeded that raised by the men.

In Boxford the event involved the contribution of a considerable amount of grain used for brewing. Traditionally the event was inherently mimetic in that its premises and actions involved comic combat or ambush (the capturing and ransoming) as in Robin Hood games. At Kenilworth Castle in 1575, for Elizabeth's entertainment, 'Coventre men acted the ancient play, long since used in the city, called Hocks Tuesday,' a combat and victory play (W. Carew Hazlitt, Faiths and Folklore of the British Isles, 2 vols (London, 1813), 318). But what Hocktide precisely may have involved in Boxford the records do not say (on Hocktide, see Hazlitt, Faiths and Folklore; Steve Roud, The English Year (London, 2006), 316–18; and J. Charles Cox, The Sports and Pastimes of the Peoples of England By Joseph Strutt (Detroit, 1968), pp 274–50.)

The payment on p 6 to Stoke play appears to be made to banns cryers for a play that would be staged in Stoke-by-Nayland (see also the entries from pp 8, 21, and 30). In 1466 Sir John Howard had paid the players of Stoke 6s 8d for a performance on the Sunday next after Twelfth Day of that year (12 January), indicating that the local playing tradition in Stoke was current over at least a sixty-year period.

div.ab: And it is to be remembryd that all the persons ‸of the towne beforeseid (which brought in money at to the profight of the pley) dyd ffynde all the townshippes mete & drynk of ther proper Cost & charge withowt any maner of alowans to them made for any maner of Charge / by which meanys the tow there is no maner of alowanns owt of this pley but onely xxx s to the propyrte pleyer & xv s to dyuerse pleyers which cam owt of strange placys So that ther was made of the same pley clerely to the profyght of the Chirche xviij li. xix s. v d. ob.

Memorandum all the Whoole accompt of wylliam Coo & Iohn Skott Chirche wardeyns of Boxford made the Sunday after the xijth day in the xxvij yere of kyng henry the viijth of all suche Summes of money as they haue receyvid & payd this yere past / than it is fownd that they haue receyvid of the gatheryng vpon plough munday / the hockpot / the proffyght of iij alys/ & of the Chirche land as apperyth in the receyte v li. xviij s. v d. ob./ And of the profettes of the pley xvij li. xij s. ix d. ob. beside & xxvj s. viij d. in Petyr ffennys handes ‸ which he hath paid at the rekynyng anno 15 dyuerse rekening So that the whoole receyt is xxiij li. xj s. iij d. wherof the paymentes do extende to xiiij li. iij s. xj d ob
So that ther remayneth clerely in money in the Chirche Box at this present rekenyng ix li. vij s. iij d. ob.

div.p: 'My Lady of Oxenford' was most likely Elizabeth de Vere (c 1468–1537), countess of Oxford, with residence at Hedingham Castle, Essex.

For a discussion of property players in East Anglia and Kent (including the one mentioned in the Boxford accounts) as early professional directors-for-hire often used to oversee local amateur productions, see Coldewey, 'Enterprising,' pp 5-12.

Resseyuyd of rychard clark for a mothetermotheter: for motheten cot of red of saynt necolasnecolas: co written over other letters
xiij d. vix s. j d.

div.p: In the introduction to his edition of the Boxford accounts, Northeast says that the reference in this account to the selling of a 'motheter cot of red of saynt necolas marked the end of the "boy bishop" in Boxford. He argues that Boxford had long had a boy bishop ceremony because of the bequest by one John Cowper, in 1446, of '"a decent and convenient crozier" for the feast of St Nicholas' Boxford Churchwarden's Accounts, p xiv; see .

Item receyved of the proffyght of the hockpot Clyrly

div.p: The account for the following year (1547–8) pays 6d to 'the Wryghter of the chirche to make hys stagynge,' (p 93) but it is unclear whether this staging has to do with a play, or is simply scaffolding for a workman, a 'wrighter.' Likely it is the latter.

div.head: Item 1, ff 1–2 (3 January) (Examination of Thomas Leese, cobbler and trumpeter, of Colchester, Essex)
div.ab: To the 1. Interrogatory this defendant saieth that he doth knowe william ffyner ‸ shoemaker late dwelling in Colchester & one George wyniffe a gentleman of the towne of Ipswiche being an Atturnie at the Common Lawe, But doth not knowe Henry Dey the now Complainant nor doth know Iohn Lilley nor william Bloise nor ffrauncis Colborne mencioned in this Interrogatory And saieth that he came acquainted with ‸ the said william ffyner by reason that he dwelle in Colchester where this defendant doth & came acquainted with George Wyniffe by meanes of his brother who dwelleth also in Colchester

To the 2. Interrogatory he saieth that the aforesaid Iohn william ffyner & not anie other of the now defendantes, did ‸ about ffowre yeres now past cause or procure this defendant to travell ‸ & goe with him from Colchester in the Countie of Essex vnto Bramford in the Countie of Suffolk ‸ being about xv. miles distant to helpe worke there for the said ffyner in Harvest worke & to pitche Corne to the Carte which Corne the said ffyner then told this defendant was his corne, & his Grounde wherein it grew, for which purpose the said ffyner hired this defendant & promised to give this defendant xij d & meate & drinke for his first daies travell ‸ to that place & afterwardes ‸ to give this defendant vj d a day & meate & drinke so long as this defendant should worke with him
in the saied harvest ‸ about the said corne. And so vpon that the said ffyners promise he this defendant went in the companie of the said ffyner & of Ezechiell Cooke Alexander Harvie ‸ & one (blank) Atkinson of Colchester aforesaid & of some other persons beinge straungers to this defendant whose names he doth not know ‸ & that they then went from Colchester vnto Bramford aforesaid for the purpose afore saied But how much monie this defendant had of the said ffyner for his Iornie & traveles in the businesse aforesaid this defendant doth not now remember, but for that which this defendant so receiued, he was driven to threaten the said ffyner that this defendant would arrest him for it, before the said ffyner would make this defendant payment thereof And further saieth that he had not anie monie in hand before his going thither from Colchester to Bramford, nor did see anie monie paied to anie other of the defendantes ‸ before their then going nor after And more then is aforesaid he cannot say to this Interrogatory

To the 3 Interrogatory this defendant saieth that at his said going ‸ from Colchester to Bramford he carried his Trumpett at his backe & also then carried along with him a picheforke to worke withall when he came to Bramford wherewith he this defendant after his comminge thither did pitch Corne to the Carte, but this defendant had not anie armor nor anie other wepon deliuered him by anie person at his being at Bramford aforesaid And further saieth that some of the other said persons did at their said going from ColchesterColchester: C written over B to Bramford carrie with them pike staves & some of them brushe bills, & that in the morning about the breake of day after the comming of this defendant & the said other persons, into the ffeilde
at Bramford where the said Corne was, he this defendant did there by the appointment of the said ffyner sownd his Trumpett & that the said ffyner did provide for them this ‸ defendant meate & drinke duringe their ‸his abode & stay att Bramford about the cutting & takinge of the said Corne which was but the space of one Day, & that at their then first comming thther being in the night season (the same being a place where this defendant had never ben before) the said ffyner brought this defendant & the rest of the said companie into a howse ‸in that Towne where they staied a while that nightebut whose that house was this defendant doth not knowe nor doth certenly know who did beare the charges or provide for the rest of the saied persons during their said being at Bramforde And further this defendant saieth that he doth not know nor hath credibly heard that ffrances Colborne, william Bloise George wyniffe or anie other by their meanes or procurement did lend or furnishe the said Iohn Lilley or william ffyner or either of them or anie other of the defendantes in the tyme of their ‸then abiding at Bramford with anie monie Carte or horses or other furniture for Carting or with servauntes laborers or workemen for or to the intent to sheare cutt downe take or carrie away the wheat or other Corne of the Complainantes then growing at Bramford/ Neither can this defendant say vpon his othe whether they or anie of them were promised anie howse or howserome in Bramfford for the layeng or bestowinge of such Corne as they should reape sheare cutt downe or carry away owt of the groundes at Bramfored aforesaid And more he cannot say to this Interrogatory

div.head: Item 5, single sheet (1 February) (Answer by Thomas Leese, Cobbler, of Colchester, Essex)
div.ab: The said defendant saving to himselfe all advantages of excepcions to the incertenty and insufficiency of the said Bill of Complaint ffor Aunswere vnto such matters of supposed misdemeanors therein alleaged and wherewith this defendant ys charged by the said Bill of Complaint and for plaine declaration of the trewthe he sayeth That trew yt is that this defendant being a man that lyveth by his laboure about the tyme in the Bill mencioned was hyred by the said William ffyner in the Bill mencioned to worke with the said ffyner in Harvest work (as he affirmed) And the said ffyner agreed to geve this defendant wages for his said labor wherevpon this defendant, not intending or any way privie that any Ryott or vnlawfull Acte should be committed at or about the tyme in the Bill mencioned and in the Company of some other of the defendantes was present at the place in the Bill mencioned at the reapinge of certen corne then and there growing which Corne and the land wherevpon yt grew the said ffyner affirmed was his) and this defendant did bynd after the then reapers of the said Corne and had and brought with him to the said place a pytcheforke to pytche the said Corne to the Carte But this defendant had no other weapons at all nor had any intent to Committ any Ryott thth: word faded by damp; likelythen or ther or other misdemeanors at that tyme and place And it is trew that this defendant being a Trumpeter and having served the late Queenes Maiestis in her shippes at sea did carry his Trumpett with him at that tyme as ys vsuall in harvest tyme in many places in that Cuntrey and elsewhere to blowe and incourage harvest men in there lawfull worke and labor and this defendant sayeth that yt is trew that certen gentlemen being (as then was sayd Iustices of the Peace came at that tyme to the place where this defendant and other were laboring in reaping and bynding of the sayd Corne and at there comaundement this defendant did deliuer vnto them his pitcheforke without anie resistance. ffor the said gentlemen and there company and of a suddayne come vpon this defendant and thother isis: rust coloured mark obscures 30mm of text company and compelled this defendant and thother in his company to goe backe to a hedge syde as farr as they could goe and one that came in the company of the said Iustices drew his sworde and stroake at one in this defendantes company But thethe: rust coloured mark obscures 2 letters, probably re was no such violent resistance then and there made against the said Iustices as in the said Bill ys surmised Which is the very trewthe of the behavior and dealinges of this defendant at the tyme of the supposed Ryott and misdemeanors in the bill alleaged And touching the Complaynantes said tytle to the said corne this defendant for his part ys ignorant whether the said ffyner or the said Complainant had best tytle to yt But this defendant and diuerse other the defendantes in the Bill named were only reteyned to labor and worke for there wages in reaping and bynding and carying of the said corne And this defendant for his part neyther was priuie nor knowinge that the said ffyner or any the ‸other defendantes intended to committ any vnlawfull acte And therefore doth most humbly submitt himselfe to the Censure of this most Honorable Courte concerning his said dealinges and demeanor at the tyme and place aforesaid And humbly prayeth this most Honorable Courte (yf the same his dealinges shall be adiudged vnlawfull) that notwithstanding yt will please the same most Honorable Courte to conceave that this defendant hath offended of meere ignorance and not of willfull or sett purpose And therefore as before most humbly submitteth himselfe to such course as this most Honorable Courte shall think fitt concerning the premisses.

div.p: Given that the case was heard at the beginning of 1606, and that the defendant says the raid had taken place about four years earlier, the incident likely occurred during harvest time in 1601.

These examination answers given by Leese are responding to questions or interrogatories put to the defendant Leese by the court on behalf of the accusers or plaintiffs in the case. Responses by his fellow defendant, Ezekiel Cooke, to the same questions, if he, in fact, was required to give them, do not survive. In essence, Interrogatory 1 asks whether Leese and Cooke knew the other defendants. Interrogatory 2 asks whether other of the defendants had asked Leese and Cooke to journey with them from Colchester into Bramford, and had paid them to do so. Interrogatory 3 asks whether Leese and Cooke had carried weapons, whether they had been provided with food or lodgings by other of the defendants, and whether they were aware of defendants other than themselves being similarly paid by certain of the defendants. Interrogatories 4-6 (not represented by answers here) ask whether Leese, Cooke, and others were fed, paid, lodged, and supplied by Francis Colborne, gentleman, and others. The several questions in this interrogatory reflect the charges that the defendants went at night to sheare and cut down wheat or corn, put it into a cart, and carry it away, all from a close claimed by the plaintiff, Henry Dey of Bramford, and that they had violently resisted a justice of the peace when he came to stop them.

div.head: single sheet ( Bill of complaint)
div.ab:
To the reuerend ffather in god my lord Cardinall legate A latere
Archebisshop of york Primate of Englond And Chauncler of the same

In most humble wyse shewyth & compleynyth vnto your grace your trew & faythfull Subiettes & dayly Oratours Iohn Richers of Bungey in the Countie of Suffolk Thomas ffuller Iohn Crakyngthorpp Austyn ffichar & william Sowsyng the inhabitauntes of the sayde Town of Bungey Soo it is that where the same your seyd Oratours haue ben grevously wrongyd & Oppressyd by the extort power malicious supportacion and vntrew meyntenances of Richard Warton Bayly of the seyd town of Bungey Soo it was gracious lord that the seyd Richard warton Thomas wodcok & Iohn wodcok and dyuers other euyl aduisyd persons arreyed as Riottours and in Riottous manner at Bungey aforeydaforeyd: for aforseyd at xj of the clok on the frydaye at nyght nex after Corpus christi day in the sixthe yere of the most noble reygn of Kyng Henry tha now is and at that tyme the seyd Richard warton Thomas & Iohn brake & threw down ffyve pagentes of your seyd inhabitauntes that is to sey hevyn pagent the pagent of all the world Paradys pagent Bethelem pagent & helle pagent the whyche were euer wont tofore to be Caryed abowt the seyd Town vpon the seyd daye in the honour of the blissyd Sacrement And syth that tyme the seyd Richard wold haue compelled your seyd Oratours to haue made them agayn at ther costes & charges Besecheth your grace that the seyd Richard may make answere to the premissys And soo to be ordered as your grace shall thynk best in this behalf And your seyd Oratours shall praye to god for the examinacion of your noble estate long to endure//

div.head: single membrane (Answer by Richard Wharton, bailiff of Bungay)
div.ab: The seid wharton seyth that the seid byll of Compleynt ys on trewe & only feyned & ymagyned to put the seid wharton to vexacione and trobules & for noon other cawse as here to fore dyvers & many tymys they haue doon neuerthelesse for a further declaryng of the trewth the seid wharton seyth/ That syns the breche & throwyng down of the forseid fyve pagentes esspecyfied in the seid byll of Compleyntes the seid wharton at Bungey aforseid comunyd with the forseid Ryches & others the Inhabitantes of the seid Town wheche were owners of the same pagentes to that entent to make to them recompens & amendes for the seid offence vpon the hchehche: for wheche comunycacion yt was then confdconfd: for conferyd amonges them that the seid fyve pagentes were very old & auncytauncyt: for auncyent and that the yeerly reparacion & renewyng of them wewe: for were to the grett charge of the seid Ryches & others the seid InhabitesInhabites: for Inhabitantes beyg owners of the same whervpon the seid Ryches & others to whome the seid pagentes dyd belong ryght well appercyvyng the seid offence to be small & of no valour/ and that the recompens therof were sone made/ yt was than fully accordyd & agreyd betwen the seid wharton & the seid Ryches wyth others the seid Inhabitantes beyng owners of the same That the seid wharton shuld bere his good wyll & favour to the seid Ryches & others the seid persons beyng owners of the same and that they & euery of them in lyke case shuld bere ther good wylles vn to the seid wharton/ and that the seid trespas and offence to be clerly remytted & forgevyn whervpon the same wharton gave vn to the seid Ryches & others the seid persons a pottell of ale or therabowtes in full agrement of the seid trespas/ and so were fully agreyd for the seid offence afoyr the wheche agrement as is aforeseid the seid Ryches & others the seid persons to whome the same pagentes ded belong ded desyre the seid wharton That at suche tyme as the seid Ryches & others the seid persons ded hereafter make newe pagentes that the same wharton shuld be good to the aydyng helpyng & newe makyng of the seid newe pagentes. and that also he wolde procure store & provoke others of the acqueyntans of the seid wharton to gyve to the aydyng of the newe makyng of the seid pagentes to the wheche forseid request & desyre the seid wharton ded them condyscend to accomplyshe and as yet entendyth the same when so euer the seid Ryches & others the seid persons entend to make the seid newe pagentes wyth out that the seid wharton Thomas wodcok & Iohn wodcok after a ryotous & rowtus maner threw down the seid v. pagentes as in the seid byll ys surmytted/ and with out that the seid pagentes ded belong to the seid Ryches & others accordyng as ys specyfyed in the seid byll of Compleynt/ but that the same pagentes ded belong to the seid Ryches & other Inhabitantes in the seid Town of Bungey other then ben be for me'c'me'c': likely for mencionyd; water damage and a fold have obscured the end of this word in the seid byll of Compleynt/ att wheche matters etc

row.cell: Item payde for the Copying owȝt of þe game booke

div.p: In this account, the wardens paid 4d for sewing of the banner cloth (for use in processions). It is not possible to connect the game to fund-raising with certainty in that it is not ever mentioned among the receipts.

In The Medieval Stage, p 343, E.K. Chambers says that a Norwich priest, one Stephen Prewett, was paid for his labour 'in the matter,' meaning the matter of copying the game book, but the payment to the priest occurs much later on the page and it says not 'in the matter' but '& costes.' The nature of the priest's labours is unclear. Also, the original account identifies him not as 'Stephen Prewett' but as 'Ser prewett.'

div.head: ff [1-2] (16 May)
div.ab:
My lorde in my right hartie wyse I Commende me vnto you And Theise shalbe to aduertise you Apon Sonday lastSonday last: 13 May 1537 Mr wharton my lord of Norffolkes lord of Norffolkes: Thomas Howard, eighth duke of Norfolk (1473–1554)Comptrvllor Cam vnto me to hoxston And shewide vnto me. That oon Robart seyman shewid hym That oon Richarde Bisshope of Bungay shuld speke vnto hym certeyn wordes agaynst the kynges highnes the whiche he wolde not kepe and so declaride the said wordes vnto hym Wherevpon he sent for the said Richarde and examynyd hym and he vtterlie denyede theym/ Wherevpon he Brought theym bothe with hym to me./ And Apon that I and he did examyne the said seyman/ who said surely the said Richard bisshoppe dyd saye the sam wordes/ And Apon That I laid it vnto the said bisshopes Charge who denyed yt a gret whyell/ But at the last he conffessyde all that Robert said Savynge he wold not conffesse in noo wyse That he spake that if three hundrethe good fellowes werre to gyther that they shuld haue company Inoughe to Subdue the gentillmen but I thynke surely he spake them My lorde here with ye shalle Receyve the Examynacions and sayenges of bothe partyes I ensure you thys Richard is a wrechid person and A nowghtie wreche for nother by fayremeanes nor be fowlle I can make hym Conffesse that ever he hard any such wordes of any body or that he spake any suche like wordes to any other person whiche I thynke is not trewe Seynge that he never knewe the man Afore that he spake theise wordes vnto/ nor the man hym/ It is likely he wold haue suche wordes rather to suche as he knewe well and trusted well rather to hym yet neuer knewe wherefore I thynk it warr not Amysse And he warr sent vpe to se and if anymore and begotton of hym or ells I praye you I may knowe the kinges pleasure what shalbe don with hym Also ye
shalle Receyve herewithen the copyes of the prophysye And I haue sent for the Origynall of the same/ And hym that hath yt And to knowe who hath hade Copyes out of thesaid boke./ And further to knowe in what Companyes thesaid copyes hath ben Rede as nere as I can. And ffurther I haue Sent for them that was At the Redyng of thesaid Copies with this Richarde bysshope and to see what can be gotten of them Also thesaid Mr wharton shewid vnto me that it was shewid hym that Apon Mayday last there was a maij game was played A play/ whiche playe was of a kinge how he shuld Rulle his Realm And Amonges other thynges there cam in oon & playd hussbandry which said many thynges Agaynst gentillmen/ mych more then was in the boke of the play as it was said which he sent to haue hym but as yet he cannot befounde but I trust he shalbe hadd shortlye My lord I haue sent vnto all the Iustices of the peas in these shere That euery man in his quarter shalle haue Regard to the lyght persons and specyally at games and playes where any nomber of Idell persons shall mete And Also kepe wache in good Townes And in such other places as they shall thynk most convenyent for a tyme/ Not withstandynge if it myght stande withe the kinges pleasure that his highnes letters myght be sent vnto all the Iustices of the peas of thysschyre Comaundinge euery man to haue good Respect & spyalle Amonges the light persons it shuld be well don And Also I thynk yf it myght stand with the kynges pleasure that
there shuld nother games nor playes be vsid in theise partyes this somer whereby the Idell people shuld haue Accassyon to assemble/ I haue Staide som tylle I maye knowe the kinges Pleasure And Also ye shall Receyve herewithe howe Mr wharton cam by the said Copyes of the prophysye And the knowleg where the boke ys My lord I ensure you That the said wharton doth the kynge good service in his quarters & wordy thinkes as knoweth god who send you as well to doo as I wold my self ffrom hoxston. the xvjth day of May

div.head: ff [1–2v] (16 May) (Confession of Richard Bysshope)
div.ab:
Memorandum that the said Richard byshop saith that he mette with on Robert Seymon At tyndale wood the xjthday of maij abowte ix of the Clokke in the xxixth yere of the Reigne of our Sufferayn lorde kyng henre the viijth And aftre such salutacion as they hadde then/ the said Richard bushop said to the said Robert/ What tythynges here you/ haue you any mustres abowt you And the said Robert said noe And askyd of the said Robert Richard if he herde of any mustres At bungay And he said noe then the said Richard said/ this is an hard world for pore men. And the said Robert ‸saidtruly it is so/ then the said Richard said ye seme to be an honest man and such on as A man myght open hys mynde vnto/ And the same Robert said I am A playn man ye ‸may say to me what ye wolle And then the said Richard said wee ar so vsid nowe A days at Bungay as wos neuer sene affore this for if ij or iij gud felwys p be walkyng to gedr the constables come to theyme and wolle knowe what comynycacion they haue or ellys they shalbe stokkyd And as I haue herde nowe lately at walsyngham the people hadde rysyn if on person hadde not byn And as I here
sume of theyme nowe be in and other be sende to london And further the said Richard said if ij men were to gether on myght say to A nother what he what ‸wold as long as ye iijde man wos not ther And if iij men were to gether if ij of theyme were absent the iijdemyght say what he wold ‸in surety enoghe/ And he said he knewe where wos a certan prophecye wich if the said Robert wold come to Bungay he shuld here hyt redde And that on man hadde taken payn to wache in the nyght to write the copye of the same/ And if so be as the prophecye saith ther shalbe A rysyng of the people this yere or neuer/ And that ye prophecye saith that the kynges good was Signified by A mowle And that ye mowle shule be subduyt and put down/ And that the said Richard dyd here that therle of derbytherle of derby: Edward Stanley (1509–72), twelfth earl of Derby from 1521 was vp with mony And that he shule be proclaymyt traytor in those parties where he dwellyth And also he herde (as he saith) that a greate company was fledde owt of the lande/ And the duc of Norffolks duc of Norffolkes: Thomas Howard (1473-1554), eighth duke of Norfolk grace was in the Northe parties And was so be sette abowte as he herde say that he myght not come away
when he wold/ ‸I pray god it be not so Also he said that the prophecprophec: for prophecye last two letters faded at edge of leaf saith that thre kynges shall mete At moshold heethe And the prowdast prince in Crystendome shuld be ther subduyt And that the whyte lyon shuld stey all that besynes at length And shuld obtayne And said fare welle my frynd and knowe me A nother day if ye can. And god sende ‸vs A quiete world

div.p: Robert Seyman, in his own confession (see ) said that he lived at Wutton, which is very likely the village of Woodton, Norfolk, situated about four miles from Bungay, Suffolk where the play was staged. Seyman said that Turner, the person he had whooped ('whoppid') to, was his neighbour, thus Tyndall Wood is most probably Tyndall Wood, Ditchingham. The village of Ditchingham is located on the Norfolk side of The River Waveney, two miles north of Bungay.

div.head: ff [1–1v] (16 May) (Confession of Robert Seyman)
div.ab:
Memorandum that the xjth day of may Anno Regis henrici viij xxixo thesaid Robart seyman of wutton went to A wood callid Tyndall wood and About ix of the clok whoppid for a neyghborgh of his and there cam vnto hym by chaunce a man namyd Richard bisshope And said to hym gude morow/ And the said Robart said in lyke wyse to hym/ And then he asked thesaide Robart yf he se not of oon Turner/ And Robart said no/ And Richard said this ys an hote day And I Robart said it is so And then thesaid Richard said what muster they with you And I thesaid Robart said nay/ And then he Requyred what was my name And I shewid hym/ And then I asked hym do they muster About you And thesaid Richard said nay/ And said we ar s vsed vnder suche fassyon now adais as it hathe not ben sen for if iij or iiijor of vs be commyngye to githers the cunstables woll examyn what communycacion & stokke as yf we woll not tell theym/ gudd fellowes wold not be so vsed longe if on wold be trew to another And then he said my thynketh ye seame to be an honest man such a on as a man may trust to Open his mynd vnto And if that ij men haue Communycacion to gither A man may go back At his word as longe as no thyrd man ys ther/ iij may kepe counsell if ij be Away/ And further thesaid Richard said that if ij or iijC wold Rysse And on to be assuryd of Another shuld haue compacompa: for company; last two letters lost at edge of leaf Inoughe to subdue the gentillmen/ but ther
ys no Companye gatheryd but there ys on fals knave Amonges them/ for they warr apoynted/ to haue Rysyne at walsingham but there was on falsse knave that discoveryd them/ And Richard said if ye wille mete with me at Bungay/ ye shuld se a prophysey And here yt Redd And than I thesaid Robart asked of thesaid Richard if he war boke lernyd/ And he sayd naye/ but he wold bryng me where I shuld here yt Redde in thesaid prophyssye/ he said our kynge ys Singnyfyed to be a mowle and the mowle shuld be Subduyde & put downe/ And that there shuld lan at walborne hope/ the prowdest prynce in all Cristendome/ And so shall com to moshold heethe And there shuld mete with other ij kinges And shall fyght And shalbe put down/ And the whyte lyon shuld Optayne/ And he saithe that a lord ys/ as he harde say out of the land with an nombr of men And they war be where they be/ Also that he hard that the Erle of Darby the Erle of Derby: Edward Stanley (1509–72), twelfth earl of Derby from 1521is vpe with a great nombre of men/ And ys proclaymed traytor in the parties where he dwellithe And more over he saith that my lord of norffolk grace ys in the north and ys so sett abowt that he cannot com Awaye whan he wold as he hard And Also Mr Bayly of bungay & Mr whyt is left at home for now other cause but to kepe down pore people for Rysinge And than I said god spede you well for I wyll not medyll with you And the said Richard said fare well my frynde and knowe me another day yf ye can //

div.p: The Wutton where Seyman lived is very likely the village of Woodton, Norfolk, situated about four miles from Bungay, Suffolk where the play was staged. Seyman said that Turner, the person he had whooped ('whoppid') to, was his neighbour, thus Tyndall Wood is most probably Tyndall Wood, Ditchingham. The village of Ditchingham is located on the Norfolk side of The River Waveney, two miles north of Bungay.

div.head: ff [1–1v] (26 May)
div.ab: My very goode lorde in my moste harteyst wyse I comende me vnto yowr good lordeshyyp/ Sygnyfying yowe the same that I have receavid your lettres dated at hampton Court the xxvj daye of May/ And as concernyng Seyman and Busshope mencioned in your said lettures and suche other offenders as I cane cume to knowlege of, that are worthy punyshment I shall not fayle, god willing to accomplishe the kynges pleasure in that behalfe expressid in youre said lettures/ And as towchyng the boke of prophesi and hym that kepeth the said boke your lordeship shall vnderstande that wharton as yet hathe notte brought to me the said boke nor the mane/ Nor hym that played the parte of husbandry. But I shall do as muche for thapprehendyng of them as I cane And as for staying of the games & assembly of people I truste I with the lorde wentforthe & otheres the kynges cous iustices of his peace hes shall do to by all suche policy as we cane vse that your letters in that poynte shalbe fully executed And that no rumore shall ryse vpon the same

And my lorde wher in your said lettures ye advertised me þat the kinges highnes supposid that I had bene in lincolne by this tyme/ ye shall vnderstande that at my departynge thyr frome his hyghnes I ascked his grace vj weekes respyte aswell for the dispatchyng of my busynes in thes parties as also for the removyng of my hole howshold into lincolne Shyre aforesaid wiche I trust his grace hathe yett in his remembraunce And that not withstandyng I had bene in lincolne Shyre or this tyme. Savyng my sone fell sycke of the smalle pockes And is now well amended And my wyeffe also trobelid with the Ageu. But I intende god wylling to make as muche spede thitherward as I conveniently may Acertening youre lordeshypp that the moste parte of my provision ys alredy made in lincolne Shyre aforesaid And where your lordeshyp desyreth me to acertayne yow by my lettures whether my beinge her in Suffolk shold do more gode than my beyng in lincolne Shyre As towchyng that/ your lordeshyp shall vnderstande þat my opinion & full determinacion is & shalbe to be there where as the kynges hyghnes shall apoynte me/ And as for thees parties her in Suffolk I do not perceyve the contrary but that the most parte of people her be in good conformyte and quyetnes & appliable to be orderid by the worshypfull of the Shyre/ So . I cane not suspecte that any daunger is liekell to chaunce in these parties/ And wher yowre lordeshyp by youre
Seid letteres hathe aduertised me that the kynge & the Quenes graces be mery & yoyouse. I most hartely thank your lordshyp of that aduertisment for yt ys great comforthe to me to here therof And I pray gode longe to contynewe their graces in the same to his pleasure & to the Rewysyng of their noble hartes And I right hartely thanke your lordshyp for your aduertisement of the newes expressid in your seid lettures. And I am moche desyerous to here the Residewe of the same & of other newes as they shalbe occurrant in those parties yff ytt shall stend with your plesure to aduertise me therof. And thus I beseche our lorde gode to send vnto your lordshyp longe lyeffe., with thaccomplishment of all your honorable desires Wreten at hoxun in Suffolk the xxvjth day of Maye.
by yovrs assur Charlys Suffolk

div.p: In Lincolnshire, Charles Brandon lived with his wife, Katherine Brandon (1519–1580), duchess of Suffolk and twelfth Baroness Willoughby de Eresby, at Grimsthorpe Castle.

div.p: In 1558, in addition to the wives' gathering, the parish collected plough money and had a church ale on Trinity Sunday.

div.p: The ale and game on Trinity Sunday (p 27) confirm sometime connections between the games and the church ales, especially on Trinity Sunday.
In the margin of p 33 someone has drawn a pointing finger and reference to the building of the scaffold for the interlude in a modern hand.

Thomas Howard (p 34; 1537/8–72) was ninth duke of Norfolk and fifteenth earl of Surrey from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex, Kenninghall, Norfolk, and Duke's Palace, Norwich; he was executed for treason. See P&P.
In the margins of pp 33–5, someone has rendered sums, details, and parts of the original marginalia in a modern hand, repeating in abbreviated form the essence of what is on the page.

The play (p 35) was staged on Trinity Sunday, 9 June, 1566 and either Saturday, 8 June or Monday, 10 June, likely the former if the wish was to have the culminating episodes of the play occur on a Sunday.

div.p: Castle Yard (p 46) refers to a space within what remains of the c twelfth-century castle built by Baron Roger Bigod in the center of Bungay, looking down on the River Waveney at a large bend in the river. The Castle Yard, also known as the Outer Bailey, is 'set out along the southern side of the original castle, approximately two hundred feet away from the edges of the ditches' of the castle (Hugh Braun, Bungay Castle: Report on the Excavations 22, Part 2 (1935), 4). Ownership of the castle descended through the Uffords to the Howards, who gave it to the town of Bungay in 1987. It is now owned by the Bungay Castle Trust (Birch, Ancient Sites: Historic Places, p 61).

John Underwood was a churchwarden in 1566. Nine of the ten men named here can be identified as having served as churchwardens one or more times. The practice seems to have been that men and women shared joint responsibility for the safety and the presenting of money taken in from the game. This shared husband-wife responsibility by wardens and their wives indicates a major role for churchwardens in the production of fund-raising religious drama in Bungay.
In the margins, the game in the castle yard is noted in a later hand.

row.cell: Item paid for nayle for the stage

div.p: It is uncertain from the records whether these entries are references to a stage for plays, or to a strictly religious display of some kind, but payments in past years for the scaffold for the interlude, and a reference to nails for a scaffold that was clearly for entertainments in 1566–7, support the impression that these entries are for a play stage, as do other entries.

row.cell: Item paid to the colleccion for gillyngham churchegillyngham: Norfolk village 6 miles from Bungay, 1 mile from Beccles for the churchale ther
Item receyuyd of Iohn Edwardes thelderIohn Edwardes: a former churchwarden, who served in 1558 and 1566 for all the game players gownes & coates that were mad of certayn peces of olld copes

Item Receyuyd of the said Iohn Edwardes for all the residewe of peces of copes & others that remaynyd which the said Robert cooke & gregory Brownyng churchrevys sold hym by assent of the Inhabitants of ye parish

div.head: p 109
div.ab: Memorandum ther remayne in the churche chest all the Evydences for the ij shoppes at Harliston & Becklys and the ‸ thre Allmes houses in Bungay Agaynst our Lady churcheour Lady churche: Bungay St Mary Parish Church / for the twoo churche howses that Ryvet & graygose dwelle in / and for nettylham medowe / & a dede of estate Annexed to Mistres whartons will for the fyve Allmes howses. & also all the game players Apparell

div.p: Wasson, Plays and Players, p 146, includes a receipt from William Allyns 'for old coppes,' but the word is actually copper, so it is not an entry related to performance (see p 103).

The evidences concerning two shops (p 109) appears to refer to documents confirming that the feoffees of Bungay owned the two shops and, therefore, should receive rent or another kind of payment accruing from them.
In her will in 1577, Dame Christian Wharton designated five small tenements for the use, rent free, of five widows (Goult, East Suffolk, np.)
. In the left margin of p 103 the entries transcribed here have been summarized in a later hand.
In the lower left margin and at the bottom of the leaf, transcribed here have been summarized in a later hand.

row.cell: Item Receiued for the players Cootes

Players,Players: in display script; also written as catchword at the foot of recto bookes of surgerye and all other thinges belonginge as well to playes as to surgerye.

div.head: mb 5 (29 September–29 September) (Gifts)

div.head: mb 5 (29 September–29 September) (Gifts)
div.ab: And given to a certain minstrel occupying the office of 'the wait' in Bungay at one interlude performed before the lady (prioress) in the course of his tenure during (or before) Christmastide this year, 4d

div.head: mb 1 (25 December)
div.ab: Et omnibusAbbateAbbate: De before Abbate likely lost to wear at left side of membrane & Conuentu de Sancto Edmundo ad quos &c. salutem. Supplicarunt nobis dilecti nobis in Christo Abbas & Conuentus de sancto Edmundo quod cum ipsi dilecto ministrallo nostro Iohanni manpryne sustentacionem pro se vno garcione & vno equo ad totam vitam ipsius Iohannis in Abbatia predicta sub certa forma percipienda ad requisicionem nostram concessissent & velimus indempnitati eorundem Abbatis & Conuentus ne ipsi seu successores sui de huiusmodi sustentacione post mortem predicti Iohannis racione concessionis supradicte nobis vt premittitur iam facte imposterum onerentur seu eis ea occasione alias preiudicetur prospicere gratiose. Nos nolentes ea que ijdem Abbas & Conuentus ad instantem requisicionem nostram gratanter & ex mera voluntate eorundem in hac parte eidem Iohanni concesserunt eis seu successoribus suis vel Abbati predicto futuris temporibus cedere in preiudicium siue dampnum set volentes pocius eorum securitati prouidere vt tenemur volumus & concedimus pro nobis heredibus nostris quod concessio dictorum Abbatis & Conuentus de sustentacionem predictam ad requisicionem nostram ex mera voluntate eorundem modo ffacta dic Abbati & Conuentui seu successoribus suis non cedat in preiudicium seu trahatur in consequenciam in ffuturum nec quod ijdem Abbas & conuentus successores sui de aliqua liberacione seu sustentacione ad rogatus seu requisiciones nostros seu heredum nostrorum post mortem predicti Iohannis racione concessio predicte concedenda in aliquo onerentur set quod ipsi de huiusmodi liberacione & sustentacione post mortem predicti Iohannis sint exonerati penitus &
In cuius &c. Rescriptum apud Gildeford. xxv. die Decembris.

div.head: mb 1 (25 December)
div.ab: And to allRegarding the abbot and convent of St Edmund to whom, etc, greetings. Our beloved in Christ, the abbot and monastery of St Edmund have petitioned us that since they had granted sustenance for him, our beloved minstrel, John Manpryne, for himself, one attendant, and one horse, for the whole life of the same John in the aforesaid abbey, subject to a fixed procedure to be taken at our request, and (since) we wish to provide favourably for the indemnity of the same abbot and monastery lest they or their successors be burdened hereafter by (the provision of) sustenance of this kind after the death of the aforesaid John by reason of the aforesaid grant made to us, as is already mentioned, or it be otherwise prejudicial for them on that occasion, we, not wishing that those things which the same abbot and monastery have granted to the same John freely from the pure will of the same in this matter, at our earnest request, should fall to them or their successors or the aforesaid abbot in future times in prejudice or loss but wishing rather to provide as we are obliged for their security, wish and grant, for us and our heirs that the grant of the said abbot and monastery of the aforesaid sustenance now made at our request from the pure will of the same shall not fall to the same abbot and monastery or their successors in prejudice or be drawn in consequence into the future nor that the same abbot and monastery and their successors be burdened in any way regarding any provision or sustenance to be granted at our entreaties or requests or (those) of our heirs after the death of the aforesaid John, by reason of the aforesaid grant, but that they themselves from the provision and sustenance of this kind after the death of the aforesaid John be exonerated entirely and . In (witness) of which, etc. Rewritten at Guildford. 25 December.

div.head: single membrane (1 February)
div.ab:
Certificacio fundacionis regiminis & continuacionis fraternitatis de corpore christi in ecclesia sancti Edmundi de Bury in cancellaria domini Regis per Iohannem
Aldermannum fraternitatis predicte in vigilia Purificacionis beate marie anno regni Regis Ricardi secondi duodecimo iuxta formam proclamacionis per breue regium inde facte patet in forma subscripta

Est autem quedam Gilda in ecclesia sancti Edmundi de Bury que a tempore quo non extat memoria ex : as many as 15 characters illegible hominum ville predicte ad honorem Corporis Christi incepta extitit & fundata & adhuc continuatur sub haec forma videlicet quod fratres & sorores gilde predicte conuenient in die Corporis Christi & habebunt Missam de die & offeret quilibet eorum vnum quadrantem & inueniuntinueniunt: for inuenient certos cereos ad honorem Corporis Christi omnibus diebus festiuis per annum in ecclesia predicta ardentes ac quendam capellanum diuina pro fratribus & sororibus ‸predictis celebrantem & habebunt eodem die capicia de vna secta & quoddam interludium de Corpore Christi ad quod quidem interludium manutenendum & sustenendum dicti fratres ac sorores quando de nouo fiunt & creantur Astringentur vinculo iuramenti Et eodem die sumptibus suis propriis ad certum locum in villa predicta ad inuicem manducabunt Intererunt insuper dicti fratres & sorores exequiis & alijs solemnitatibus die obitus fratrum & sororum gilde predicte offerent ad missam vnum quadrantem & dabunt vnum denarium ad celebrandam missam eodem die pro anima sua Et in super eligent dicto die vnum aldermannum qui curam & superuisum gilde predicte habebit pro anno sequente et non sunt ibi plura bona vel catalla aut terre tenementa redditus vel possessiones mortificate vel non mortificate ad dictam Fraternitatem pertinencia aliter quam superius est expressum

div.head: single mb
div.ab: Certification of the founding, governance, and continuation of the brotherhood of Corpus Christi in the church of Bury St Edmund in the chancery of the lord king by John alderman of the aforesaid brotherhood on the vigil of the purification of St Mary in the twelfth year of reign of King Richard II according to the form of the proclamation made thereof by royal writ in the form written below.

There is, moreover, a certain guild in the church of Bury St Edmund which from time immemorial out of of the people of the aforesaid town was established and founded to the honour of Corpus Christi and is still continued under this rule, namely, that the brothers and sisters of the aforesaid guild will gather on Corpus Christi day and they will hold mass of the day and each of them will offer one farthing and they procure wax candles specific to the honour of Corpus Christi which burn on all the feast days throughout the year in the aforesaid church and a certain chaplain who celebrates divine service for the aforesaid brothers and sisters, and they will have on the same day matching hoods and a certain interlude of Corpus Christi. Indeed,the said brothers and sisters, when they are made and appointeded anew, are obliged by a sworn bond to maintain and sustain that interlude. And on the same day at their own cost they will eat together at a certain place in the aforesaid town. The said brothers and sisters, moreover, will be present for exequies and other solemnities on the day of the death of (one of the) brothers and sisters of the aforesaid guild, they will offer for the mass one farthing and they will give one penny for the celebration of the mass on the same day for his or her soul. And moreover, on the said day they will elect one alderman who will have the care and oversight of the aforesaid guild for the following year. And there are not there more goods or chatels or lands, tenements, rents, or possessions, amortized or not amortized, pertaining to the said fraternity other than as has been expressed above.

div.head: f 28v (18 March)
div.ab: Item willelmus Stevenyssone filius Thome StevenyssoStevenyso: letters lost in gutter de BraborneBraborne: possibly in error for Bamburgh Braburne in Comitate deNorthomerlond ponit se ipsum in apprenticiatum Thome lorymer de Bury Sancti Edmundi harparij a die dato presenti vsque ad terminum vij annorum & in vltimo anno 1 par sotularium 1 par calceorum sufficientium apparatus de nouo 1 harpe 1 lowde pype & a stylle pype & xx d. in fine termini predicti

div.head: f 28v
div.ab: Likewise William Stevenyssone, son of Thomas Stevenyssone of Braburne in the county of Northumberland places himself in the apprenticeship of Thomas Lorymer of Bury St Edmunds, harper, from the present day for a term of seven years and in the last year (he will receive) one pair of shoes, one pair of boots, adequate new apparel, one harp, one loud pipe, and a soft pipe, and 20d at the end of the aforesaid term.

div.head: f 96v (10 September)
div.ab: Item I yeve and be qwethe x. marke to the peyntyng rerdoos and table at seynt marie avter of the Story of Magnificat that in caas be þe awter be seet aftir my entent as is wretyn aftyr And in the enner part of þe lowkys with inne there be wreten the balladys I made therfore & the pardon wretyn there also

div.head: mb 1, 2–2d (8 June)
div.ab: alle the Ocupiers of the seyd Crafte with inne the seyd Toun of Bury by one assent prayin and in the waye of charyte hertely besechen the Secristen of the monastery of Bury aforesayd lord of the seyd Toun that certeyn provysyouns bylawes and ordenances may be maad to the plesiere of god increse and profyte of the seyd Crafte Toun & Cuntre be the sadde & discrete advyse of his Officers and Councell made inactyd and auctorysed in maner & forme as hiere after ffoleweeth

if ony persone dewly chosen to be wardeyn refuse & wyll not take his charge dewly & treuly to ocupye and excersyse the seyd Office in maner & forme afornrehersyd than that persone so refusyng xall lose & fforfete xiij s iiij d wherof the Secristen of Bury afornseyd for the tyme beyng xall haue the one half/ And the othere half to go to the sustentacion & mayntenance of the payent of the Assencion of our lord god and of the yiftys of the holy gost as yt hath be customed of olde tyme owte of mynde yeerly to be had to the wurshepe of god amongge other payenttes in the procession in the ffeste of Corpus christi And yf ony wardeyn of the seyd Crafte be after the charge as ys afornrehersyd be hym take neclygent remysse or in ony maner of wyse defectyff in executyng or in excersysyng of his seyd Office. that wardeyn so dwly ffounde defectyff xall loose & fforfete for euery poynt that he is ffounde ffauty or defectyff in. iij s iiij d wherof the seyd Secristen xall haue the one half & the other halfe to go to the Sustentacion & mayntenance of the seyd pagent

And yf ony persone occupying the seyd crafte of necligence wylfulnesse or frowardnesse or any other cause with oute licence of the wardeyns of suche cause as the seyd wardeyns xall thynkke resonable be absent & mete not with the wardeyns occupiers of the seyd Crafte at þe place & tyme afornlymytyd & assignyd that persone so dewly fownde defectyff in ony of these poyntes afornseyd xall forfete & loose for euery poynt that is so founde defectyff in xiij s iiij d wherof the Secristen afornseyd xall haue the one halfe And the seyd wardeyns the other halfe to the sustentacyon & maynntenance of the seyd payent & profyth of the seyd Crafte/

same and so be examynyd And admyttyd be the seyd wardeyns as able men to sette vp & occupie the seyd Crafte & that euery persone so wyth holde heryd or wagyd be the yeer or lesse tyme contynue in the seyd Toun occupyid in the seyd Crafte be the space of a yeere xall paye to the maynntenance & sustentacion of the seyd payent. iiij.d. And that no persone presume to do contrarye to ony poynt conteynyd in these articules & poyntes afornrehrersyd xall forfete & loose for euery poynt that is so founde defectyff in xiij s. iiij d. wherof the Secristen afornseyd xall haue the one halfe And the seyd wardeyns to the othere halfe to the Sustentacion & Mayntenance of the seyd payent & profyth of the seyd Crafte

AlsoAlso: display letter A yt ys in maner & forme and be the auctoryte afornrehersyd ordeynyd & prouydyd that euery fforeyn weuer that fettyth of the seyd Toun of Bury mennysyern for to webbe xall be contrbutorie vnto the Sustentacion of the seyd payent lyk as a deyzin weuer oweeth to be/ And that no persone presume to do contrarie to ony poynt conteynyd in these articules vpon peyne of fforfeture of xx s as oftyn tymys as ony persone of the seyd Crafte is founde defectyff in wherof the Secristen afornseyd xall haue the one halfe. and the seyd wardeyns the othere halfe to the Sustentacion & Maynntenance of the seyd payent & profyth of the seyd Crafte

AlsoAlso: display letter A yt ys in maner & forme and be the Auctoryte afornrehersyd ordeynyd inactyd & prouydyd that what persone of the seyd Crafte withholde a Iurnyman for a terme withinne wiche terme the Iurnyman be vacant for the defaute of werke the maister shalle satysfye vnto his Iurnyman for his losse be warde of the wardeyns and no persone p(re)sume to do contrarye to ony poynt conteynyd in these articules vpon peyne of fforfeture xiij s. iiij d. wherof the Secristen afornseyd xall haue the one halfe. and the seyd wardeyns the othere halfe to the Sustentacion & Maytenance of the seyd payent & profyth of the seyd Crafte
