half And the wardeynswardeyns: underlined other halfe to go to the sustentacion & maynntenance of the seyd payent & Crafte And that no persone presume to do contrarye to ony poynt conteynyd in this articule vpon peyne of fforfeture as oftyn tymys as ony persone is ffounde defectyff in xx s wherof the Secristen afornseyd xall haue the one halfe and the wardeyns to the Sustentacion vse & profyte of the seyd payent and crafte the other halfe

AlsoAlso: display letter A yt ys be the agrement and assent afornrehersyd ordeynyd provydyd agreed inactyd and auctorysed of alle the persones occupying the seyd Crafte ordeynyd that one day with inne lenton duryng the lete of the seyd Toun of Bury the wardeyns xij. or xiiij honeste & discrete persones of the seyd Crafte than & there to be Sworn and Streytely chargyd be the seyd Baliffez trewly & Indeferently to Inquere and to present alle the persones that in ony poynt mysbehave and if ony persone warnyd be the wardeyns and Subbaylleffez in maner & forme rehersyd to Apper beforn the seyd Baylleffez make defaute and appere not that persone so makyng defaute xalle forfete iij s iiij d wherof the Secristen afornseyd xall haue the one halfe. And the wardeyns to the Sustentacion vse & profyth of the seyd payent and Crafte/

AlsoAlso: display letter A yt ys assentyd agreed ordeynyd and prouydyd that alle the fforfetures ffynes peynes of amercymentes that xall growe be reason of the ordenances provysyonnys and Bylawes as weell to the seyd Secristen as to the seyd wardeyns xall be leuyed & gadered be the wardeyns & seruantes and Officers of the seyd Secristen wiche seyd wardeyns and Subbaylleffez xall yeerly make a trewe accomptaccompt: 4 minims for mto the seyd Secristen of suche duetes as to hym xall be longgyng in that be half and to the Sustentacion of the seyd payent & Crafte of that parte ther to xall be longgyng

div.head: sheet [2]
div.ab: A true Inuentary of all the Implementtes moveable apperteynyng to the seyd GuyGuy: likely for guyld other thane Certeyne pagenttes theare Remaynyng at the day aforeseyd whereo the keperys to yeld account at the departyng ffrom that offyce/

row.cell: Of xl s. geuen to the seyd Master of the Scoole by the consent of the gouernors in regard of his paynes taken with the Scolers about the comedy played at Mr. Goldinges

div.p: The master of the school from 1601 to 1603 was John Mosse, of whom little is revealed by the records.
Robert Golding, esquire (buried 1 March 1610/11 ), was a feoffee of the town 1582–8 and 1610–11. He was a governor of the Bury Grammar School from 21 January 1583.

div.head: f [4] (18 July)
div.ab: ItemItem: in display script to7 prevent the resorte of Idle persons to plaies and sightes of toyes It is ordered that noe Inholder Alehowskeeper victualler or other person inhabitinge within this Burghe shall permitt or suffer any stage plaie Comedie interlude or other plaie to be plaideNo playes to be Att eny Enndds with owt lysennce from the Alderman in their or any of ‸their howses or any horses, Babones, Apes, Beares, Puppittes, or other sightes or shewes to be made in their howse or howses vpon paine to forfeite for the first offence iij li. vj s. viij d., for the second offence vj li. xiij s. iiij d. and for the third offence x li. withowt the licence of the Alderman Recorder and tw of the Assistantes or one‸ three1three: cancelledone and three are in different inks ‸two of them therevnto first had and obteyned in writinge

div.head: f [15] (18 July)
div.ab:
To avoid swearing and vsinge vnsemelie
songes Balletts libells and Rymes././.

ItemItem: in display script yt81 is ordered that yf any person shalbe heard swearinge any greveous oath or othewise takeinge the name of god in vaine or shalbe heard singinge or sayinge of any vngodly vncyvile or dishonest songe Ballet Libell or ryme within this Burghe, the person so swearinge (yf he be able) shall paie to the vse of the poore of this Burghe for euery oath so by him vttered iiij d. & for sayinge or singinge any such songe Libell or Ryme xij d to be levyed by the Overseers of the Poore for the tyme beinge by distres and sale of the goodes distreyned rendringe to the partie the ouerplus But yf the partie soe offendinge be not able to paie such a penaltie or fine then he or she shalbe Comitted to the howse of Correction and there be set to worke vntill other order shalbe taken by the said Alderman Recorder & Iustices of peace or some of them./

row.cell: The saydeThe sayde: in display script Accomptant prayeth Allowance of
Item of ij s. for vj li. Candelles spent at the Commody
Item of x s. payd to Iohn Greene for his Musick at the Commodye
Item of xxiij s for the Banquett at the Commodie
Item of x s. iiij d. payd for wyne then spent
Item of xviij d. to Inglethorpe & ffoxgill for keeping the dore

Item of xj s. iiij d. payd to Lawrence ‸Boyden for Bracketes for the wall planke and bourd for the pumpe
Item and setting the pale
Item of xv s. viij d. payd to mr. Dickenson vpon his Bill of thinges for the Commody
Item of xxxij s. payd to Dyster for the tables
Item of xxxvj s. xj d. payd to Langham for workes splentes nayles straw splentwoodsplentwood: -wood written over another word, probably bord& other thinges as appereth by his Bill
Item of xv s. payd to mr ffayercliffe for fflockes to stopp the Cushions
Item of iiij s. vj d. payd to Ions for making the Cushions
Item of ix d for a pownde of hoppes to stopp the Cushions
Item of xix s. vj d for a Carpett
Item of ix d. for making thereof
Item of iij li. xix s. payd to Nicholas Bell for the Charges for the dynner

div.p: In addition to this entry, John Green, musician, was also paid 10s for performing at the civic feast on 16 January 1619/20 and 10s again for a similar performance on 2 January 1621/2. He appears to have been one of the town's waits, perhaps their master. He died in late December 1621 and was buried at St James Church (Stratham, Accounts, p 355). His contribution of music to the comedy confirms that Bury's waits sometimes contributed to local dramatic productions

John Dickinson (d. 1643) was high master of Bury Grammar School from 1605 through 1637. He had been recommended to that position by Sir Edward Coke, lord chief justice of England, whose student Dickinson had been at Cambridge. Dickinson received a lifetime appointment, and the school was said to have thrived under his leadership. When he resigned from the school for a time in 1618, due to ill health, the governors of the school awarded him £5 a year to help him in seeking treatment and a perpetual annuity of £20 (R.W. Elliott, The Story of King Edward VI School (Bury, 1963), 52-9).

One of Dickinson's scholars was paid for making an oration to the governors of the school in 1607 (item [6], mb [2]),and others of the 'Grammer Schollers' were twice paid by the governors for performing their verses in 1609 (item [4], mb [1]). The payments suggest that he was teaching them a range of performative skills.

row.cell: And of xl s. given to the kinges Maiesties Trumpeters

div.p: Charles Stuart (1600–48/9) was crowned Charles I of England on 27 March 1625. See P&P.
The town also made money by renting out the guildhall for marriage dinners.

row.cell: And of xx s. for wine and Musicke when Mr Alderman Davy did take his oath
And of xx s. given to the late Quenes players to send them owt of Towne when they came to playe at an vnfittinge tyme
And of xx s. payde to Iames ffayecliff & Richard Maltyward heynors of the ffeast when this Accomptant did take his oath of Alderman, towardes the charges of the wyne
And of x s. given to Iohn Grene the Musitian at that tyme

div.p: The payments in this account confirm that the annual elections dinner included music.

row.cell: And of xx s. paide for wine & Musick at the eleccion of Mr Alderman Barker
And of xiiij s. iij d. paide for wine & Musick when Mr Alderman Barker did take his place
And of x s. given to Greene for Musick then
Liveries for the waytes of the Towne

cell.note: : sum omitted

row.cell: And of iij li. vij s. paide to Mr Bright for 7 yardes of blew cloth at ix s. the yard for Liveries for the Towne waytes in the tyme when Mr Roberte Browne was Received
And of liiij s vj d paide to the Goldsmith for the silver cognizaunces for the waites of the Towne
And of xl s. paide to Thomas Cropley towardes the charges of the Dinner at the Guildhall at Mr Aldermans election
And of xv s. laide out for wyne and suger at the time of the Aldermans taking his oath
And of Ten shillinges given to the Towne waytes at both those dynners
To a Messenger for bringing a Breif touching the suppressing of vnlawefull Games

div.p: The guildhall, which dates from the thirteenth century (or earlier), is located on Guildhall Street, four blocks from the abbey grounds. The medieval hall has been divided into a north hall, ‘known as the Sessions or Court Room, from the Borough Sessions having formerly been held there,’ or Sessions Room, and a south hall or Banqueting Room. It is in the latter, according to Tymms, that weddings and bride-ales were held during Jacobean and Caroline times, which generated considerable revenue for the town. In earlier centuries (including our period), townsmen used the guildhall as a town hall. At least four of Bury's religious guilds (Assumption, Purification, Candlemas, and St Peter) held their guild meetings there (Samuel Tymms, A Handbook of Bury St. Edmunds in the County of Suffolk (Bury St Edmunds, 1854), 47–8; for a detailed study of the guildhall, see Statham, 'Guildhall,' pp 117–57). Although still a monastic borough in the fifteenth century, Bury was an important wool-producing town and its population grew considerably. During that century, local worthies rebuilt and improved parts of the guildhall, including the roof, porch, and kitchen (Statham, 'Guildhall, p 120). A minstrels' gallery rests above the entrance vestibule, looking down on the banqueting room (Statham, 'Guildhall,' p 130; figs 22, 23). For more on the guildhall, see Statham, Accounts , pp xiii, lii, lvi–lvii, and lix (on wedding parties).

div.head: p 99 (1 October)
div.ab: It is further agreed that Mr Stevens the highe Schoolemyster shalbe alowed out of the revenues of this house. Six poundes thirtene shillinges and eight fouer pence towardes his charges in the ‸late Acting of a Comedye by the Scholleres to be payd him by the present Controwler

It is agreed at a meeting by the Governours the day & yere aboveseid that Mr Stevens shalbe payd & allowed all the charges that shalbe layd out & disbursed for the makynge of a stage at the Abby for a Commodye for the entertayntment of the high sheriff of the County of Suffolk that now is:the high sheriff … that now is: Sir Symond D'Ewes of Stowlangtoft, Suffolk & the seid stage to be kept & the serues to the vse of the Schoole:
Robert Browne
Iasper Sharpe
Thomas ffletcher
Iohn Woodward henry Walker
Henry Chapman
Edward Lelamp
Richard Gipps
Anthony Smyth

div.p: Thomas Stephens was high master of Bury Grammar School, 1638–45, and again between 1647 and 1663. He was an ardent royalist, which might account for his absence from the school between 1645 and 1647. During his two-year hiatus, he taught his own school at a location which is unknown. While Stephens was gone, the governors felt that Bury Grammar School had fallen into decline and in 1647 they prevailed upon him to return to 'replenyshe' the school. He was held in such esteem that the governors had purchased a house for his use in 1639, and in 1654 they permitted him to purchase it (which he had no financial difficulty in doing). It is also obvious from the school accounts that he was skilled in the production of plays by his scholars (Elliott, Story, pp 59–61).

The nine men who signed the order on 1 October and again on 16 December 1639 were the governors of Bury Grammar School. Two of the governors who signed on 1 October (John Godbold and William Colman) had been replaced (by Jasper Sharpe and Henry Walker) in the order of 16 December. Four of the governors were also officers of the town. John Godbold was recorder; John Woodward was clerk to the feoffees of the town lands; Robert Browne was an alderman, feoffee, and receiver; and Anthoney Smyth was an alderman and feoffee (Statham, Accounts, pp xx-xxi (n 48), xxv-xxvii, liv, xliv, 194, 263, 247, 270, 274, 289 (n 12), 309, 314, 321, 359). Henry Chapman was a grocer (Tymm, Wills and Inventories , p 220). It has not been possible to identify with certainty the remaining governors, although men of the same names who died in the 1670s are identified in indexes of Bury and Sudbury wills as gentlemen.

Simonds D’Ewes (1602-1650), was knighted by Charles I on 6 December 1626, was high sheriff of Suffolk in 1639, and became MP for Sudbury in 1640. Although he was an influential antiquary and politician in London, he retired to Stowlangtoft Hall near Bury St Edmunds in 1632. In his youth, he had been a student at Bury grammar school, where he had distinguished himself in his facility with authoring great numbers of Greek and Latin verses (J.M. Blatchly, 'D'Ewes, Sir Simonds, First Baronet (1602-1650, Diarist and Antiquary,' ODNB, accessed 13 December 2024).

div.head: sheets [1-2] (18 March))
div.ab:
I Robert Hobart of Saint Edmondes Bury in the County of Suffolk musicion being in perfett healthe & memory (praysed be god therfore) & being now a trumpeter Chosen to serve in the warres & knoweing the ffrailtie of mans life & the suddennes of deathe therin & also how svdenly death otherwise by the hande of god falls vpon man I doe hereby make & declare this to be my last will & Testament
Item I giue & bequeath vnto my said sone Iohn Hobart all my instrumentes of musicke both of lowde & still musicke & all my bookes of musicke whatsoeuer And also all my workinge tooles whatsoeuer which belonge to heale makinge which I did vse about the same trade

Likewise on the same day to four other minstrels, 2s. Likewise on the feast of St Edmund given to two trumpeters of the Lord of Offord and two trumpeters of the lord of Verdun and six other minstrels 8s 4d and to six other minstrels, 8s 4d.
Likewise on the same day given to harpists of Lord John of Seagrave, 2s.
Likewise at Christmas to an entertainer of the earl of Northampton, that is to say, a tregetour, 3s 4d, and to Nulour.
Likewise given to a certain Nulour while he was staying with Lord Edmund of Pakenham, 12d.
Likewise to two runners of the wardrobe of the lord king, 6d at Christmas.
Likewise given just before the Newmarket tournament to John Chesam, herald of the lord king, 40s.
Likwise to Manprene, 40d. Likewise to a third minstrel 18d. Likewise on the feast of the Purification given to minstrels/a minstrel, 12d.
Likewise to a messenger of the king's chamber bearing a brief for the parliament to celebrated at York, 12d.

Likewise to two runners of the Exchequer, one of whom was called William Brown, 5s. Likewise given around Shrove Tuesday (or Septuagesima) to a taborer of the earl of Northampton called William of Wandur, 3s 4d.
Likewise given to minstrels/a minstrel on Easter day at Chevington, 16d.

Likewise given at Culford on the octave of Easter to Garber the trumpeter, 12d. Likewise actually on Easter given to two trumpeters of Lord John of Verdun, 12d. Likewise on the same day to two other minstrels, 6d.
Likwise around a certain time given to a minstrel called Monch and his fellow by command of R. the Good, 2s
Likewise given to Thomas Horn around the feast of St Mark the evangelist by the command of R. the Good, 12d.
Likewise given to three minstrels on the feast of the Ascension of the Lord, 15d.

div.p: Robert de Ufford (1298–1369) was first earl of Suffolk from 1337, with residence at Orford Castle.
Sir John de Verdon (1299–1376) was first Baron Verdon and lord of the Manor of Martlesham, with main residence at Martlesham Hall, Suffolk.
John de Segrave (1315–53) was fourth Baron Segrave from 1325, with residence at Seagrave, Leicestershire.
William de Bohun (1312–60) was first earl of Northampton from 1337, with residences in Berkshire, Oxfordshire, Buckinghamshire and numerous other counties.

Edmund de Pakenham (1278–1332), lord of the Lower Manor of Pakenham, with residence at Pakenham, Suffolk. 'When Edmund [de Pakenham] died in 1332 the lesser manor passed to his widow, Rohais, or Rosia (rose) de Pakenham, who held it from the Abbot (of Bury) for the annual rent of three shillings and ninepence (that is, the lordship continued with them after his death). After her death in 1352 it passed to her son, Edmund.' (W.R. Rayner, Pakenham History: The History of Nether Hall (Pakenham, nd), 4, Pakenham – Village of Two Mills https://pakenham- village.co.uk/History/historyOfNetherHallbk/historyOfNetherHall-p01.htm.

E vostre couernour
Pur ceo ieo voil ke moun barnage
Tretus ke sunt de grant parage

ye weten wel yat i am king

yerfore i wile yat min barnage

For al yat arn in burw or toun
I wile he witen mi resoun
And yat is richt and schil
Venet sa moun messager
vousTunc dicet nuncio dirray pur turney
I vous couent tout aler

div.head: single membrane verso
div.ab: Assist my beginning, holy Mary. Every animal condemns the raven of perfidy.!
Now listen, dear lords,
All barons and knights,
And all who are in the court
Know well that it is true
That I am the crowned king
And your governer.
Therefore I will that my baronage
All who are of noble lineage
That they come to me,
For I wish to speak to them
And show my reason
Without any delay.
Come here my messenger
YouThen let the messenger say shall say for the tourney
'Go you there in assembly'.

div.p: Elizabeth de Mowbray (n'ee Fitzalan) (nd-1425) was duchess of Norfolk from 1385.

Thomas de Mowbray (1366-99) was earl marshall from 1385 to 1398 and first duke of Norfolk from 1397; he was banished 29 April 1398 and died in Venice. See P&P. The ODNB notes that Mowbray's apparent birthdate of April 1566 seems too early, given that his brother was born in August 1365; see C. Given-Wilson, "Mowbray, Thomas, first duke of Norfolk (1366–1399), ODNB, accessed 4 November 2024.

body.head: Suffolk, Bury St Edmunds Abbey 1401–2 SUAB01

row.cell: Item datum menstrall' in aulam a Nativitatis
Also given to minstrels/a minstrel in the hall at Christmas

div.p: Since this is the abbot's account, the hall in which the performances occurred was likely the Great Hall in the Abbot's House. Entering the abbey precinct through the Great Gate brings one immediately into a large open space then called Great Court. According to Pevsner, 'the E side of Great Court was given over to the Abbot's House with (from N to S) its own Stables, Bakery and Brewery, Great Hall, Kitchen, and then a second hall called the Queen's Chamber' (Suffolk, p 137). Like most of the abbey buildings, the Great Hall no longer survives.

body.head: Suffolk, Bury St Edmunds Abbey 1417–18 SUAB02

row.cell: Datum Episcopo Sancti Nicholai hoc anno
Item datum ministrall' ad Natalis domini Natalis domini: written over erasure
Item solutum ad contribucionem factam pro ministrall' ad festum Sancti Edmundi
Given to the bishop of Saint Nicholas this year
Likewise given to minstrels/a minstrel at Christmas
Likewise paid as a contribution made for minstrels/a minstrel at the feast of Saint Edmund

div.p: This record is the earliest mention of the ceremony of the boy bishop in the records of the abbey. For a discussion of the institution of the boy bishop, and of uniquely surviving coins or tokens possibly used in the ceremony of the boy bishop at Bury St Edmunds see J.B. Caldecott, 'The Money of the Boy Bishop at Bury St. Edmunds,' Transactions of the International Numismatic Congress: Organized and Held in London by the Royal Numismatic Society, June 30–July 3, 1936, on the Occasion of its Centenary, J. Allen et al (eds) (London, 1938), 366–71. While acknowledging that the certain connection of the tokens to the boy bishop cannot be proved, Caldecott makes a compelling argument that the tokens were moulded at Bury, had a redeemable value, and were distributed as alms to the poor by the boy bishop during his Christmas season ministry (Caldecott, 'Money,' p 92). See also S. E. Rigold, ‘The St. Nicholas or ‘Boy Bishop’ Tokens,’ Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology and History, 34 (1977), 87-101. Though his study of the tokens is archaeological in focus, Rigold accepts that the English version has certain qualities that justify associating surviving tokens with the ceremony of the boy bishop (pp 90-1), although the precise relationshop of the tokens to the ceremony itself, in his view, ‘is not yet clear’ (p 91). Rigold also provides persuasive contextual evidence associating the tokens with the Abbey of Bury St Edmunds and the confraternity of St Nicholas in St Mary parish church in Bury (p 92). See also VCH: Suffolk, vol 2, p 312.

div.p: Henry Tudor (of Richmond) (1456–1509) was king of England from 22 August 1485.
Henry Tudor (1491–1546/7) was created prince of Wales in 1503.
John de Vere (1499–1526) was fourteenth earl of Oxford from 1512, with residence at Hedingham Castle, Essex. See P&P.
Thomas FitzAlan (1450-1524) was twenty-second earl of Arundel from 1488, with residence at Arundel Castle, Sussex and lands in Norfolk. See P&P.

div.head: single membrane (29 September–29 September) (Gifts)
div.ab: Given to minstrels on Saint Edmund's day in the absence of the lord abbot 3s Likewise given to the bishop of Saint Nicholas 12d Likewise given to minstrels of the lord king, the lady sovereign, Lord Curson and others playing in the hall of the convent by the order of the lord prior 2s 4d

div.p: Sir Robert Curson (1460-1534/5) was knighted in 1489, and named Baron of the Holy Roman Empire sometime after 1500, with residence in Ipswich. For useful biographical information on Curzon, see John Blatchly and Bill Haward, ‘Sir Robert, Lord Curson, Soldier, Courtier and Spy, and His Ipswich Mansion,’ Suffolk Institute of Archaeology and Natural History 41.3 (2007), 335-50.

Katherine of Aragon (1485-1536) was queen of England from 1509 to 1533. She served impressively as regent of the kingdom in 1513 while her husband was in France, which may explain the use of the term princeps (in this instance ‘the lady sovereign’). It appears that he was permitting that same title for Katherine in 1520 (given the honorific used by the scribe at Bury), a year filled with momentous international diplomatic events in which she played a central part (C.S.L. Davies and John Edwards, 'Katherine [Catalina, Catherine, Katherine of Aragon] (1485-1536),' ODNB, accessed 9 May 2011. For her troupe of minstrels, see P&P.

div.p: Henry Tudor (1491–1546/7) was Henry VIII of England from 22 April 1509.
Henry Courtenay (c 1498-1538) was first marquess of Exeter from 1525, with primary residence at West Horsley, Surrey. See P&P.
Edward Stanley (1509-72) was twelfth earl of Derby from 1521, with seats at Lathom and Knowsley, Lancashire. See P&P.
Thomas Howard (1473–1554) was duke of Norfolk from 1524 to 1546 and in 1553-4, with residence at Kenninghall, Norfolk. See P&P.
Henry Fitzroy (1519–36), first duke of Richmond, was fourth duke of Somerset from 1525, with primary residence at Sheriff Hutton, Yorkshire North Riding. See P&P.

To theIn reward xvij li. xiij s. iiij d. gyven by the Countese of Bathe and my Master to my lord of Norffolk his officers at kennyngall dellyvered by the Steward viz. by the countesse of Bathe vj li. xiij s. iiij d. & by my Master xj li. at the Marying of Mistris Elezabeth Cornwallays as apperethe Violernes & game players
Gyven to iij Muchesones that came and playd befor my Master on shrofte sonday
gyven to two Tvmbellers that played befor my Master and svndry strongers

div.p: The payments on f [10] occurred at Kenninghall, Norfolk.
Margaret Bourchier (Donington) (f [10]; c 1510–1561) was countess of Bath and wife of Sir Thomas Kitson (1485–1540), with a residence at Hengrave Hall, Suffolk.
Thomas Howard (1537/8–1572) was duke of Norfolk from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex and Kenninghall, Norfolk. He was executed for treason in 1571/2.
Elizabeth (Lady Kitson Cornwallis (1546/7–1628) was the wife of Sir Thomas Kitson (1540–1603), with a residence at Hengrave Hall, Suffolk.

Kenninghall Palace was the chief residence of the Howards, dukes of Norfolk. Built between 1505 and 1525 for Thomas Howard, eighth duke of Norfolk (1473–1554), the main house was demolished c 1650. A fragment of the service wing alone survives.

The performances recorded on ff 11v and 15 occurred at Brome, which is located two miles north of Eye, in Suffolk. The Cornwallis family lived at the Brome estate from the late fourteenth century until 1823, when it was sold to the Kerrison family. Brome Hall, the Cornwallis residence, was built c 1550 by Sir Thomas Cornwallis and seems likely to have been the venue at which these entertainers performed. A description written in 1809 says of the great hall or dining room that it 'exhibits a perfect specimen of old English grandeur. It is very lofty, wainscoted with oak, to the height of about 10 feet, without ceiling; the timbers of the roof being finished like those of churches.' It further says that over the entrance to the room, above the butler's pantry, was a gallery with a flight of stairs at each end' (A. Rosamund Bateman-Hanbury, 'Brome Hall,' Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology 14, pt 2 (1912), 233–4. One wonders if the so-called Brome Abraham and Isaac play may have been performed there. The house was still occupied by the Kerrisons and grandly outfitted, in 1911, but demolished c 1958.

Records indicate that the Cornwallis family (and notably Sir William Cornwallis) were major patrons to entertainers both at Brome Hall in Suffolk and (after 1588) at their palatial house and grounds in Highgate, a village five miles north of London on the Great North Road.

div.head: sig Biij–Biij verso
div.ab:
there were two hundred yong Gentlemen, cladde all in white veluet, and three hundred of the grauer sorte apparelled in blacke veluet coates, and faire chaynes, all ready at one instant and place, with fifteene hundred seruing men more on Horsebacke, well and brauely mounted in good order, ready to receyue the Queenes highnesse into Suffolke, which surely was a comely troupe, and a noble sight to beholde: and all these waited on the Sheriffe Sir William Spring, during the Queenes Maiesties abode in those parties, and to the very confynes of Suffolke. But before hir highnesse passed to Norffolke, there was
in Suffolke such sumptuous feasting and bankets, as seldome in any part of the world hath bin seene before. The maister of the Rolles, Sir William Cordall, was one of the firste that beganne this great feasting, and did lighte suche a Candle to the rest of the Sheere, that many were glad bountifully and franckly to follow the same example, with such charges and cost, as the whole trayne were in some sort pleased therewith. And neere Bury, Sir William Drury for his part at his house, made the Queenes highnesse a costly and delicat dinner, and Sir Robert Iermyne of Roeshbroke feasted the French Embassadoures two seuerall times, with whiche charges and courtesie they stood maruellously contented. The Sheriffe Sir William Spring, Sir Thomas Kidson, Sir Arthur Higham, & diuers others of worship, kept great houses, and sundry eyther at the Queenes comming, or returne, solemnely feasted hir Highnesse, yea and deffrayed the whole charges for a day or twayne, presented giftes, made suche triumphes and deuises, as in deede was most noble to beholde, and very thankefully accepted.

div.head: sig Giv verso
div.ab: the Queene passing from Norwich, came to Maister Woodhouses that night, where she was well receyued, and nobly entertayned. From thence to Wodde rising, the cheere and entertaymente there I sawe not, wherefore I giue it no greate commendation. From thence to Thetforde at Sir Edward Cleeres. The trayne haue tolde me (that was there) how they were worthily feasted. From thence to Sir Thomas Kidsons, where in very deede, the fare and banquets did so exceede a number of other places, that it is worthy the mention. A Shew representing the Phayries (as well as might be) was there seene, in the whiche Shew, a rich Iewell was presented to the Queenes Highnesse. From thence to Maister Reeuets where all things were well, and in very good order, and meate liberally spent.

div.p: Sir Roger Woodhouse (Wodehouse)(c 1541–88), of Kimberley, Norfolk, was MP for Aldeborough, Suffolk. He was the son of Thomas Wodehouse and Margaret Shelton and was married to Mary Corbet, daughter of John Corbet (1514-59) of Sprowston, Norfolk.

Kimberley is a small village located three and half miles north of Wymondham. In 1578 it had a moated hall with a tower, and Elizabeth I stayed in the hall during her progress through Suffolk and Norfolk. The old hall was demolished in 1659 and replaced by the present Kimberley Hall, in the parish of Wymondham.

Woodrising is a village five miles west of Kimberley and northwest of Wymondham. It was the home of Sir Robert Southwell (15631598), high sheriff of Norfolk, 1589–90. As an admiral and a ship commander, Southwell would take part in the battle with the Spanish Armada in 1588. He was married to Elizabeth Howard, a lady in waiting to Elizabeth I and daughter of Charles Howard, tenth earl of Nottingham, himself a cousin of the queen. The queen stayed at Woodrising Hall, home of Sir Robert, for four days, before moving on to Thetford. The moated hall where she stayed was taken down in the eighteenth century.

Sir Edward Clere (1536–1606), of Blickling, Norfolk, was married to Frances Fulmerston (1545?–c 1579), daughter and heiress to the fortune of Sir Richard Fulmerston, of Ipswich and Thetford. Clere himself was a second cousin of Elizabeth I in that his great-grandfather's second wife, Alice Boleyn, was the aunt of Anne Boleyn. Sir Edward Clere was also a second cousin of Thomas Howard (1538–72), ninth duke of Norfolk.

row.cell: Item payde to Syr vmfrye Ratlyfes sarvantes

div.p: The account was declared by the two churchwardens on 2 February 1556/7.

Sir Humphrey Radcliffe (1509–66), was knighted in 1536, with residence at Elstow, Bedfordshire. Radcliffe had no obvious connections to Cratfield and the amount given is typical of what a travelling company would have received, so it is likely that his servants were touring entertainers.

div.head: f 1v col 1 (Jesus and Corpus Christi Guild, list of original members)

div.p: The minstrels in the account are the only individuals identified by craft or trade. Another Thomas Baker, with a cross (+) before his name, is included on f 1, the first page of the membership list.

div.head: f 24 (28 May)
div.ab: Item payd to the menstrelles þat is to sey hert and the taborer xij d.

div.p: The fact that both Hart and the taborer are described as minstrels would seem indicate that they may sometimes have performed together.

div.head: f 29
div.ab: Item the bredryn are A greable that þe Minstrall xall haue outȝ of the stok yerly xij d helpyng the holder And he to bere odyr xij d and his Costes

div.p: That the assistance of the minstrel was needed by the holder (the person who kept the accounts and mounted the 'guild') would seem to indicate that the event involved something more than a simple procession.

div.head: f 31
div.ab: To the Mynstrall delyueryd ij s. George Haryngton ij s.

row.cell: Item payit on to the menstrall
Item payit on too the berere of the baner

div.p: The first two payments to the minstrel and banner bearer are clearly dated 1507–8. The third entry is for an undated part that, as Wasson says, 'must be for 1509, for as subsequent entries make clear, the account in the following year, listed as 1 Henry VIII, was rendered in "1510"' (Plays and Players, p 152). The entries offer no unequivocal indication that the minstrel and the banner bearer took part in the same event.

div.head: f 37v
div.ab: for ye menstrall xij d.

row.cell: for menrallmenrall: for menstrall; ink blot obscures middle of the word
viij d. & to brewers xij d.

div.p: The payment to the brewers has been added later in a different hand. Although there is adequate space to have added the brewers at the bottom of the page, the scribe has chosen to add it into this rather pinched space. One wonders if that choice indictes that the minstrel may have been playing at a church ale.

row.cell: ffor the beryng of ye banner
Item to the berynge off the banner

div.p: The accounts also contain a number of payments to the banner bearer in entries which have no payments to the minstrel. See ff 49v, 50v, 51, 51v, and f 52.

row.cell: Item to the berer of the baner
payd to ye berer of þe baner

div.p: The scribe has wrongly corrected the year, repeating 17 Henry VIII. He dates the following year 18 Henry VIII but the error is corrected in 1529.

row.cell: Item payd to ye berer of þe banyer
Item payd to þe berer of ye baner
Item payd for beryng of baner
Item payd for beryng of the baner

of Thyssame is payd to þe menstrell
payd to ye berar of ye baner
Item to the berer of the baner

div.p: The three accounts on ff 61–1v are undated.
The three accounts on ff 611v are undated.

div.head: Item 1, single membrane (9 February) (Bill of complaint)
div.ab: To the Kings moste excellent Maiestie./

In moste humble manner Complayning sheweth vnto your Highnes your humble Subiect Thomas Hall of Culpho in your Highnes Cownty of Suffolk gentleman That whereas your humble Subiect is possessed of and + in one Mesuage or Tenement in Culpho afforesaide for ‸the Terme of dyvers yeares yet enduring. And whereas also your sayd humble Subiect with his wief Children & famylie were in the sayd howse in the peace of God and of your Maiestie vpon the Eight day of August last past that is to saye in the ffirst yeare of your Highnes reigne of England ffraunce & Ireland and of Scotland the xxxvijth. Soe yt is (if yt maye please your moste excellent Maiestie) That one Charles Wolverston of Culpho aforesaid gentleman Edward Wolverston of the same gentleman Thomas ffosdike of the same Laborer ffrauncys Vfford Laborer. Henry Thacker laborer. Ioseph Boughton husbandman (then Constable of the said towne of Culphoe) ‸Iohn Welles Laborer Richard King laborer, Nathaniell London Tayler Vyncent Carter Tayler, ‸all of Culpho aforesaid Roberte BircheRoberte Birche: written over erasure of Grundisburghe in your Highnes said Cownty of Suffolk TaylorTaylor: written over erasure William Man Thatcher Richard Thacker Laborer, William Mixter yoman Anthony+ ffynche Labourer. Iohn ffynche Laborer William Lea yoman Anthony Withe Laborer George ffyncheGeorge ffynche: a cross is written above the name Laborer Willyam Hall Laborer Iohn GoslinIohn: a cross is written above the name Labourer Richard CockerillRichard Cockerill: a cross is written above the name blacksmyth +Henrye MorfowldHenrye Morfowld: a cross is written above the name Laborer and Robart Carver Laborer ‸and Walter WrightWalter Wright: a cross is written above the name laborer all of Grundisburghe aforesaid and divers others to the nomber of Threeskore persons yet vnknowen to your saide humble Subiect (whose names when they shalbe knowen your humble Subiect desires may be inserted into this his Bill of Complainte) being all armed & arrayed in maner of warre with Bowes Bylles Goonnes swordes daggers long pyked staves & other Weapons aswell defensive as invasive Vpon the said Eight day of August in the sayd ffirst yeare of your Highnes moste happy reigne over theis your Highnes Realmes of England ffraunce and Ireland & of Scotland the xxxvijth about Twelue of the Clock in the Night of the same day of a malicyous intent & purpose againste your saide humble Subiect) dyd ryotously and in maner of a Rowte assemble & gather themselues togither about your Subiectes saide Mesuage or dwelling howse And then & there they the said ryotous persons did make a moste Lowde vilde and terrible Noise sometymes showting sometymes hallowing hissing & Clapping of their handes. & sometymes singing in maner of a harvest Songe the foote of which Song was theis filthie wordes following videlicit Come kisse our arse holesCome … holes: written in italic script To the great terror and feare of your said humble Subiect his wief Children and famylie being then in the said howse, & (at that dead tyme of the night) fast asleep in their beds By occacion whereof your said Subiect & his weif Children and famylie were sodaynlie and fearfully awaked out of their sleeps, and being greatly amased with the greate nomber of the said ryotous and rowtous persons. and with the unacquaynted noyse that they so made your humble Subiectes wief arose, & calling out at a windowe to the sayd ryotous & rowtous persons to knowe what they meant, and what their intencion was to doe by this their ryotous & Rowtous disorder They the said ryotous and rowtous persons would make noe aunswer at all but still persisted & Contynewed in their ryotous and rowtous Crying hissing and hallowing afforesaid. Wherupon your humble Subiectes said wief with her Maides (by your Subiectes dyrection) went downe out of her Chamber to the said ryotous and rowtous persons and demaunded of them the said ryotous & rowtous persons what they were, & wherfore they came thither at that tyme of the night and in that ryotous rowtous and disordered maner. To whome the said Charles Wolverston (being Captaine and Ringleader of all the rest of the said ryotous and rowtous persons, the rest being all mufled vp & their faces hidden with their Cloakes & other thinges) stept forth & vsed theis swaggering & vnsemely words, togither with theis fearfull & abhominable oathes following videlicit By Gods wounds & by Gods heartBy … heart: in italic script yt is I (setting both his handes by his sides, grynding his Teeth & shaking his head) And againe swore, by Gods bloudGods bloud: in italic script here will I stay and sing despight of thee theis two houres, gett thee in, what doest thou here, send out that raskally knave & Rogue thy husband. By Gods Woundes and bloudBy … bloud: in italic script if wee had him here wee would Chop him in peeces as small as wortes to the pott, Often repeating & saying Oh Gods WoundesOh Gods Woundes: in italic script that wee had that raskally knaue & Rogue thy husband here, my ffingers doe ytche at him, And asking where one William Gallowes (being your said humble Subiectes servant, calling & tearming him by the name of bald pated knaue) was, againe swearing Oh Gods WoundesOh Gods Woundes: in italic script that wee had him here And therupon your humble Subiects said wief rebuking him the said Charles Wolverston for his swearing & blasphemyng of the name of God in so vile a maner, & desiring him to leave of and not to goe on in that his so outragious & disordered behauiour Saying that she would Cause the Towne to be raysed vpon them, & that she would make the Worshippfull of the Shire acquaynted with yt if they did not departe The said Charles Wolverston in moste scornfull & scoffing maner (& in Contempt of all aucthoritie & magistracie) made aunswer in theis wordes and scoffing tearmes following videlicet What, will yow make the WorshipfooleWorshipfoole: in italic script of the Shire acquainted with yt. what the Worshipfoole: the Worshipfoole?Worshipfoole: the Worshipfoole?: in italic script & with that threwe+ durte & other filthie thinges in the face of your humble Subiectes said wief, & in the faces of her Maides that were then & there with her ‸and did then and there drawe forthe theire privytyes at her said Maydes vsinge most vnchaste and abhominable termes to them. Calling your said humble Subiectes wief Gill fflurtes and many other very vnsemely & filthy names. And saying further vnto your humble Subiectes said wief theis wordes following vizt By Gods Woundes. I haue shitt in thy husbandes Porridge pot any day this ffortnight, & swore by Gods Woundes that he and all his Company would shite in his Pond (meaning a pond out of which your humble Subiect vseth Comonly to fetch all his water for his necessary vse and to dresse his meate withall) before they would goe away; And aswell the said Charles Woluerston as all the rest of the sayd ryotous & rowtous persons dyd accordingly presently performe the same. And in this ryotous rowtous and and disordered maner all the ryotous & Rowtous persons abouesaide contynewed about your Subiects said howse by the space of an howre & more. All which Ryottes Rowtes and other Misdemeanores aforesaid were Comytted and done since her late Maiesties last moste gracious generall and free Pardon, Againste the Lawes Statutes and Ordynaunces of this your Maiesties Realme of England, And tend to the manifest breache of your Highnes peace and to the evyll & very daungerous example of others like malicious & wicked . mynded persons. In tender Consideracion whereof may yt please your moste excellent Maiestie not onely to graunte vnto your saide humble Subiect your Highnes moste gracious wrytt of Sub pena to the said Charles Wolverston, Edward Wolverston, Thomas ffosdike, ffrauncys Vfford, Henry Thacker Ioseph Boughton ‸Iohn Welles ./ Richard King, Nathaniell London, Vincent Carter Robert Byrche+Robert Byrche: written over erasure William Man Richard Thacker, William Mixter Anthony ffinche, Iohn ffinche, William Lea, Anthony Withe, George ffinche William Hall Iohn Goslin Richard Cockerell+ Henrye Henrye: written in different hand Morfowld and Robart CarverGeorge ffinch … Robart Carver: each of the six names has a cross written above it ‸and Walter Wright and every of them to be directed, Comaunding them and every of them therby at a certeyn day and vnder a certeyn payne therein to be lymited personally to appeare before your Maiestie and your honorable Cowncell in your Highnes moste highe Courte of Starchamber Then & there to aunswere the premisses But also take such further order for the punnyshement of the saide Ryottes Rowtes and other the fowle Misdemeanores aforesaide as the same doe deserue, And your Highnes said humble Subiect shall (according to his bownden duty) Contynually pray to God for your Maiesties Long and moste happy reigne over vs.

div.head: Item 2, single membrane (18 March) (Answer of Charles Wolverston)
div.ab: The sayed defendant by protestacion sayeth that as he is informed the said Bill of Complaint is very vncerteyne and insufficient in the Lawe to bee aunsweared vnto And the matters therin agaynst him Conteyned deuised imagyned and sett fourth to vex and trowble his defendant without iust cause The exceptions to the vncertaynetye and insufficionsie wherof to this defendant nowe and att all tymes hearafter saued for aunsweare vnto the said Bill hee sayeth that he this defendant is not guiltye of the Ryotous and Rowtouse assemblie, and gatherynge together, in the dead of the night abought the howse of the said Complainant in the said bill named, Or of the lewde vilde and terrable noyse, Or of the filthie wordes, blasphemouse swearynge Riotous and Rowtous hissinge, scornefull scoffynges in contempte of authorytie and Maiestracion Thretynge to Cutt the Complainant as small as worttes to the pitte, drawinge him by the pryvities, and other the misdemeanores and offences agaynest him and the said other defendantes in the said Bill of Complaint declared, nor ‸of any parte nor parcell then in ‸such manner and forme as the same bene by the saide bill of Complaint against this defendant and the said other defendantes in the said bill of complaint named very vntrewly and slaunderousely devised imagined settfourth and declared Neuerthe lesse this defendant doth most humblye confesse vnto this honorable Courte, that neere aboutes the tyme and place of the said supposed riotous assemblie, in the said Bill of Complaint intended, That is to saye aboutes eyght of the clocke of the afternoone of the daye he He this defendant together with some other of the defendantes in the said Bill of Complaint likewise named beinge then in the kynges high waye neere the dwellinge house of the Complainant in the said Bill named syngeinge of a songe Commonly called a harvest songe Not myndynge at all eyther to breake the kynges Maiesties peace or to commytt any outradge or misdemeanure whatsoeuer weare by the prouocacion of the Complainantes wife accompayned with certayne woemen servantes th‸rough hir and their and then vnwoemanly and furiouse : 50mm of erasure with line fillermisdemeanore vrged vnadvisedly to speake and aunsweare vnto them diuerse wordes and spetches (which no doubt might with more discreacion haue leyn best vnspoken the very certaynetie wherof this Complainant now remembreth not The same beinge yett farr otherwise and not so wilde and vnciuill as in the said Bill is most vntrewly sett fourth and declared fforthe which of this most honorable Courte shall thinke him blame worthey he must humblie craueth pardon of this most honorable Courte for the same Which he hoopeth to obteyne the rather for that though the same shalbe iudged worthey reprehention yet because yt both appeareth by the Complainantes owne shewinge that thoccation of that which passed beinge only wordes one the defendantes parte happned through ‸the Complainantes sendynge his wife and seruantes out of the house to worde which this and the other defendantes and allso because by the authory of the Iustices of peace of the said County of Suffolk their hath leyn vppon the Complainantes spetiall persute heretofore a sceveare censure gyuen for the punishment therof at a spetiall Sesyions by him purchased which in parte hath beyn executed in the same County This defendant hoopeth that this honorable Courte will not thinke yt fitt to be further troubled with the examynacion therof Espetyally consyderynge allso that by the defendantes owne showinge it appeareth their was not any bludd drawen nor so much as one stroke strucken Excepte by the Complainantes Wife who struck at this defendant and andand and: dittography other defendant in the byll named) Neyther was there in truth any one weapon brought : 50mm of erasure with line filler on the parte of the defendant wher with to brake the kynges peace drawe bludd or stryke And if their hadd beyn the same hadd beyn Occationed through the prouocacion and begynnynge of the said Complainantes wife and seruant And to the ende It maye appeare vnto this honorable Courte wherfore this defendant and the said other defendantes did comme s neare vnto the Complainantes howse to synge the said harvest songe He most humblye and most trewly by waye of aunsweare sheweth vnto the same That their is and for all the tyme wherof the memorye of mann is not to the contrary their hath beyn a Neybourly vsadge and sauyinge the reformacion of this honorable Courte emongestt quiett and well disposed people a harmelesse Custome through the said County of Suffolk yearely abought the latter ende of harvest for the harvest folke to assemble themselues together to synge as they call them) harvest songes at or neere the dwellynge howses of the gentlemen or Cheife men of euery parish And the gentlemen or Cheife menn of euery parish haue and dooe vse in recompence of their love to bestowe haruest Cheire vppon sutch syngers when they singe aswell as when they worke And in sutch places as their happend twoe men of the better sorte to dwell in one towne or neere one to the other theire harvest Forke vse cesyinge and in their syngeinge to aunsweare thon to thother scryminge and Contendynge (yett without quarrell or intent to offende the lawe or breake the peace) attributynge the victory or best in sutch stryuynge or Contendynge to that parte that doth Contynewe syngeinge longest As yt ‸hadd happned a little a littlea little a little: dittography before the supposed Riot in the Bill named betweyne the servantes and harvest laborers of the Complaint And the seruantes and harvest labores of one Robert Wolferston esquyre this defendantes ffather And for that the said seruantes and haruest laborers hadd songe thon Company against thother diuerse tymes not longe before the tyme of the said supposed Riott neyther partie yeldynge to the other the better in theise synginges Wher vppon yt was giuen out by the said Complainant or somme of his servauntes as this defendant is Creadyblie informed and hopeth to praie to this honorable Courte, that they woulde haue the victory in synginge of the said Mr Wolferstons haruest folke Or their Master Woulde bestowe tenn poundes vppon a haruest syngeinge And theirvpon diuerse of the laborers their aboutes herynge therof repayred somme to the howse of the said Robert Wolferston and as this defendant is informed somme other to the howse of the said Complainant as this defendant thinketh to singe And aboutes eyght and before neyne of the clock in the after noone of the daye both the said Companyes begann to synge, and did singe, and answeare ‸syngeinge thonne to thother diuerse tymes, And And when it appeared that the greater number affected to take parte with the haruest folke of the said Mr Wolferston. so as it semed lykely that that parte woulde in their synginge weary and ouersynge those of the Complainantes parte ffor anger theirof as this defendant supposeth the Complainantes wife by the Complainantes direction as hs he setteth forth in his bill ‸ of Complaint with hir mayde seruantes as the Complainant acknowledgeth Came fourth to the seruantes and haruest laborers of the said Robert Wolferston which are the supposed Rioters in the said Bill named this defendant beinge one of the CompanyCompany: 60mm erasure, line filler And interrupted their singinge and vsed vnto them many vntemperate speaches and receyued like aunsweares, Which was all the ryotouse and routouse assemblie and gatherynge together in the dead of night abought the Complainantes house and the vilde and terrable noyse makynge and the filthie wordes and blasphemous Swearynge and Riotous and Rowtous hissinge Scornefull scoffinge Threttynge and other misdemeanures wherof the said Complainant in his said bill of Complaint doth so greauously complayne And Concernynge the defylinge of the porridge pott or pond of Water in the Bill named this defendant for aunsweare sayeth that the saied ffather : 70mm erasure with line filler; as many as 13 characters hath within his seuerall free houlde not farr from the Complainantes howse a pond which this defendant Called a porredge pott which by him and diuerse others hath beyn vsed as a privie or valte Out of the which the Complainant hath vsed to fetche water the premisses not withstandynge what the consent of the Complainantes ffather not hauynge any iust Right or tytle thervnto Without that that this defendant and the other defendantes in the bill named armed and arrayed in manner of Warre with Bowes Billes Gunnes swordes daggeres longe pyke staues and other weapons aswell Invasiue as defensiue the said eight daye of august in the said first yeare of your highnesse most happie Raygne of theise your highnesse Realmes of Englande ffraunce and Ireland and of Scottlande the seuen and thirteth Aboute twelue of the clocke in the night of the same daye of a malitiouse intent and purpose against the Complainant did Riotouslye and in manner of a Rowte assemble and gather themselues together aboute the Complainantes messuadge or dwellynge howse in the said bill of Complaint named And then and their make a lewde vilde and terrable noyse In sutch manner and forme as lykewise in the said bill of Complaint a ‸likewise vntruly surmyse to the greate terrore and feare of the said Complainant his wife Children and famylie beinge then in the said house and at the deadtyme of the night fast asleepe in their beddes or that by the occation of the said Bill of Complaint suggested the said defendant his wife Children and famyle beinge suddenly and fearefully awaked out of their sleepes and beinge greatly amased with the number of persons in the said Bill named and surmysed And their vnacquainted noyse The said Complainantes wife arose and Called out of the windowe to this defendant and the other defendantes in the said bill of Complaint ‸named in sutch manner and forme as in the said Bill is sett downe and declared And ‸where therse that the Complainantes wife Went downe out of hir chamber to demande and aske sutch questyons of this defendant and the other defendantes as in the said Bill of Complaint is declared And without that that this defendant vsinge those swagringe and vnsemely wordes iestures and abhomynable and blasphemouse othes in the said Bill of Complaint rehearsed r reviled the Complainant And thrett to Chopp him as smale as wortes to the pott as in the said Bill of Complaint is likewise most vntrewly surmysed And without that that this defendant in most Scornefull and Scoffynge manner in Contempte of Authoritie and Maiestratie answered the said Complainantes wife in sutch manner and forme as in the said Bill of Complaint is likewise vntrewly surmysed And without that that this defendant did throwe durte and and otherthinges in thynges in the Complainant Wifes face and the faces of hir maydes and drawe his pryvyties at the said Maydes vsinge to them most vnchast and abhomynable termes as in the said Bill of Complaint is most vntrewly surmysed and Manerlessly expressed And without that that this defendant and the said other defendantes in the riotouse and disordered manner in the said Bill of Complaint Conteyned Contynued abought the defendantes howse by the space of one hower or more in sutch manner and forme as in the said Bill of Complaint is by the said Complainant sett fourth and declared And without that any other matter or thinge in the said Bill of Complaint Conteyned Materiall or effectuall in the lawe for the rest to aunsweare vnto to his knowledge and heeretofore on this aunsweare not sufficiently confessed and avoyded trauersed and denyed or otherwise aunswered vnto is trew All which matter this defendant is reddye to auerre and proue as this honorable Courte shall awarde And most humblie prayeth to be dismissed fourth of the same with his reasonable Costes and Chardges by him in this behalfe Wrongfully susteyned

div.p: Richard Scrivener (f 9) often appears in the accounts as a guest in December and January. His name immediately follows or precedes a payment to a harper a number of times, but only in this entry are he and the harper connected by an ampersand. Scrivener remains unidentified, but Swabey assumes that he was a scrivener who performed important service for Agnes de Bryene (Medieval Gentlewoman, p 127).

div.p: According to Ffiona Swabey, two women, both named Agnes Whyte or White (f 9v), were occasionally present at the dinners of Alice de Bryene, and were both present on 11 May 1413. Swabey describes Agnes White, wife of John, as a household member who buys and sells produce, and Agnes Whyte, wife of Alex, as a household member who sells produce (pp 127, 180).

Sir Richard Waldegrave (f 10; c 1380–1435) was the son of another Sir Richard Waldegrave (c 1338–1410), who had been steward of the estates of Queen Anne in Norfolk and Suffolk by 1382, was JP for Suffolk and Essex, and was a member of Richard II's council from 1393 through 1397. The younger Waldegrave, like his father before him, was lord of the Manor of Bures St Mary, with residence at Smallbridge Hall in Bures St Mary, Suffolk. His father, the elder Sir Richard, had married the widowed mother of Dame Alice de Bryene in 1363. Their son, the Sir Richard of these records, was the half-brother of Alice, and was often a guest at her table.

div.head: f 17v (29 April)
div.ab: Iohannus Blake & j menstrallus per totum diem

div.head: f 17v (29 April)
div.ab: John Blake and one minstrel for the whole day

div.p: John Blake remains unidentified but other references in the account offer glimpses. Between 17 April and 16 May the accounts extraordinarily list Blake as a guest forty-three times, nineteen of those as a guest for the entire day. He is once listed with a minstrel, twice with a member of his household, and once with his son. Otherwise he appears alone in the accounts. In sum, he seems to have been a gentleman of some substance, who had a household of his own, and who was favoured as a guest by Dame Alice.

div.ab: Et solutum Willielmo ‸Prentyng Trumpet ixo. die Ianuarij anno ixo. in partem solucionis feodi sui apud Wyngefeld xiij s. iiij d. Et solutum Ricardo Gren. Bumbaro in partem feodi sui eisdem die & anno. vj.s. viij. d. Et solutum henrico Brigeferd Shalmoser in partem feodi sui eisdem die & anno. vj .s. viij. d. Et solutum Iohanni Lyon Shalmoser eodem die in partem feodi sui &c. j. s. viij .d.

div.head: mb 4 (August) (Gifts and rewards)
div.ab: Et datum iiij Ministrallis Comitis Somersetensis Venientibus ad Hospitium domini apud Wyngefeld dicto Mense auguste &c. de mandato domini. xiij. s. iiij. d.

div.head: mb 3 (9 January) (Payments to minstrels)
div.ab: And paid to William Prentyng, trumpet, on 9 January in the ninth year (of the reign of Henry IV) in part payment of his fee at Wingfield, 13s 4d. And paid to Richard Gren, bombard, in part (payment) of his fee on the same day and year, 6s 8d. And paid to Henry Brigeferd, shawmer, in part (payment) of his fee on the same day and year, 6s 8d. And to John Lyon, shawmer, on the same day in part (payment) of his fee, etc, 1s 8d.

div.head: mb 4 (August) (Gifts and rewards)
div.ab: And given to four minstrels of the earl of Somerset, who came to the lodging of the lord at Wingfield in the said month of August, etc, by command of the lord, 14s 4d

div.p: John Beaufort (c 1371–1409/10) was second earl of Somerset from 10 December 1395/6, with residences at Corfe Castle, Dorset, and in North Wales. See P&P.
