div.head: mb [22] (1 October 1401–29 September 1404) (Fees)
div.ab: And paid to Simon Huittebone, harper, who came in service of the lord on 23 March of the said fifth year in part payment of his fee until the Michaelmas at that time next following, 40s 26s 8d

row.cell: Item Resayuyd of the Wycheys gatheryng
Item Resayuyd of owr Cherche aell
Item Resayuyd of the lorde of myesrewlle

div.p: The witches' gathering may have had to do with Plough Monday activities, the day on which Dennington's churchwardens' accounts were declared and new wardens appointed (f [1]). Joseph Strutt's The Sports and Pastimes of the People of England, J. Charles Cox (ed), rev ed(London, 1903), p 274, observes that in nineteenth-century Huntingdonshire, the mummers on Plough Monday were referred to as 'Plough- Witchers,' but he offers no in-period evidence illustrating the use of witches' gatherings on Plough Monday. Whether the witches in Dennington were gathering for the parish on Plough Monday, and whether they were male or female, is unclear, but they do seem to have been involved in a traditional custom that may or may not have had mimetic elements. A Christmas ale held by the parish in 1500 (see Ipswich, Suffolk Archives HD 1260/1, f [2v]), and the lord of misrule in this account, would together appear to confirm that church ales and mimetic entertainments were sometimes connected in Dennington.

div.head: ff [1v–2] (Articles to be inquired of)
div.ab:
Also, whetherV./ any person or persons, what soeuer they be, do in any enterludes, plaies, songes, rimes, or by any other open wordes, declare or
speake any thyng in the derogation, deprauyng, or despysynge the sayd booke of Seruice.

div.p: This small book has no signature indicators.

div.head: sig A4v (Articles to be inquired of)
div.ab: 10 Item, whether there be amonge you any blasphemers of the name of almighty God, adulterers, fornicators, baudes, or receauers of such persons. Any suspected of incest or any other notoriouse fault, sin or crime. Any dronkardes, ribaldes, common slaunderers of their neighboures, raylers or scolders, sowers of discorde betweene neighboures, by playes, rimes, famouse libels, or otherwise.

div.p: The articles on sigs A4v and A5 are incorrectly numbered. This is the seventeenth, not the tenth, article according to the order in which they are printed and the numbering given on the other leaves.

div.head: sigs Aiii-iiiv (Injunctions for the churchwardens, questmen and others)
div.ab:
Item, that no person or persons calling them 4 selues lordes of misrule in the Christms tyme, or other vnreuerent persons at any other tyme, presume to come into ye church vnreuerently playing their lewd partes, with scoffing, iesting, or rebaldry talke, & if any such haue alredy offended herein,
to present them and their names to the Ordinary.

div.head: sig Aiiii
div.ab: 15. Whether your person, Vicar, or Curate, keepe any suspected woman either in his house or elswhere or is geven to idlenes, drunkennes, a haunter of Ta= verns, alehouses, or any other suspected places, or a common Hunter, Hawker, Dicer, Carder, Bowler, Tableplayer, Swearer, Dauncer, or geven to any such like wanton and undecent sportes, or suspected of such or like notorious crimes.

div.head: sig Bii
div.ab: 27. Whether there be any within your Parishe that keepe open Innes, alehowses, vitlinge, or tiplinge, in the tyme of Service, or Sermon, upon Sundayes, Holidayes, and other festivall dayes appointed by lawe, or suffer any gamynge, or playinge, within ther howses in those dayes and tymes. And whether any Butchers or others that sell victuall doe in tyme of Common Prayer or Sermon, upon the dayes afore=saide, keepe open shoppes, and sell their victuall. And whether in fayres fallinge on Sundayes there bee any shewinge of any wares before Morninge Prayer bee donne and that at the accustomed hower and tyme, And whether ther bee any selling of wares in any Church or Churchyeard by common packemen or pedlers, or any other.

div.head: sig Biii verso
div.ab: 33. Whether any within your Parishe doe use any charmes or unlawfull invocations or Prayers, or any sorcery or wichcrafte or bee suspected for the same, and whether any doe resorte to suche for helpe or councell. Also of all Blasphemers, Swearers, adulterers, for=nicators, incestuous Persons, Bawdes receavers of women with child being unmarried, conveying them alwaye before they make satisfaction to the congrega=tion, Drunkardes, Ribawdes, Malicious and con=tentious Persons, common scoldes, slaunderers of their neighbors, Raylers, sowers of discorde betwine party and partie and such like.

div.head: sig B2v (Articles to be inquired of by churchwardens)
div.ab: 51 Item, Whether haue you or your predecessors Church-wardens there suffered since the last pardon, any plaies, feasts, banquets, Church ales, drinkings, or any other prophane vsages to be kept in your church, Chappell or church yard, or bels to be rung superstitously vpon hollidayes or daies abrogated by Lawe.

div.head: sig B (Concerning the parishioners)
div.ab: 10 Item, whether haue any in your parish maliciously quarrelled or stricken your Minister, and laid violent hands vpon him in any sort, or haue done þe like to others in any church or churchyard: or whether hath any of your parish disturbed the Minister in the time of diuine seruice, or haue libelled against him, or spoken slanderous words of him to the scandall of his Vocation.

12 Item, whether any in your parish, do vse to buy, sel, trade, or labor, or keep open any shops by themselus, or any vnderneath them, on the sonday or holiday, & whether doth any Inkeeper, alehousekeeper, or victualer, or any other person in your parish, admit any person to eat, drinke, play, or be idle in their houses in the time of diuine seruice, sermon, or homily: & whether do you vpon the 5. of August, and the 5. of Nouember, assemble in the church, and giue God thanks for his Maiesties deliuerance from the danger of those daies, acording as it is prouided by publike authority.

div.head: sig B2 (Touching the churchwardens and sidemen)
div.ab: 1 Whether you and the Church-wardens, Questsmen or Sidemen, from time to time, do, and haue done their diligences, in not suffering any idle person to abide either in the Church or churchporch in seruice or sermon time; but causing them either to come into the Church to heare Diuine Seruice, or to depart, and not disturbe such as be hearers there: and whether haue they, and do you diligently see the parishioners dulie resort to the Church euery Sunday and Holiday, and there to remaine, during Seruice and Sermon: and whether you or your predecessors, Churchwardens there, suffer any playes, feasts, drinkings, or any other prophane vsages, to be kept in your Church, Chappell, or Churchyarde, or haue suffered to your or their vtmost power and endeauor, any person or persons to be tipling or drinking in any Inne or victualling house in your parish, during the time of Diuine Seruice or Sermon, on Sundaies and holydayes?

div.head: sig B3v (Articles concerning the church and churchyard)
div.ab: 12 Item, whether haue there beene kept in your Church any Playes, Feasts, Banquets, Church-ales, drinkings, or any other prophane vsages by laying of Drums or Guns in your Church or Steeple, and discharging them there, and by whose commandement and appointment?

div.head: sig A2v (Articles concerning religion and doctrine)
div.ab: 5. Item, WhetherPopish Recusants. be there any abiding, or resorting to your Parish, that bee, or are commonly reputed to bee ill affected in matters of Religion professed in our Church, or taken to be Recusant Papists, refusing to repaire vnto the Church to heare diuine Seruice, and receiue the holy Communion, and being disobedient to his Highnesse Lawes in that behalfe prouided. Or doe any publish, sell, or disperse any superstitious bookes or writings; or other bookes, libells, or writings of any lectuaries touching the Religion, State, or Ecclesiasticall gouernement of this Kingdome of England. Present their names, qualities, and conditions. Doeth any Papist keepe a Schoolemaster in his house, which commeth not to Church as is required. What is his name, and how long hath he taught there or elsewhere.

div.head: sig A2v (Articles concerning religion and doctrine)
div.ab: 5. Item, WhetherPopish Recusants. be there any abiding, or resorting to your Parish, that be, or are commonly reputed to bee ill affected in matters of Religion professed in our Church or taken to bee Recusant Papists, refusing to repaire vnto the Church to heare diuine Seruice, and receiue the holy Communion, and being disobedient to his Highnesse Lawes in that behalfe prouided. Or doe any publish, sell, or disperse any superstitious bookes or writings; or other bookes, libells, or writings of any lectuaries touching the Religion, State, or Ecclesiasticall gouernement of this Kingdome of England. Present their names, qualities, and conditions. Doeth any Papist keepe a Schoolemaster in his house, which commeth not to Church as is required. What is his name, and how long hath he taught there or elsewhere.

div.head: sigs A2–2v (Articles concerning religion and doctrine)
div.ab:
5. Item, Whether be there any abiding or resorting to your Parish, : right marginale likely missing due to tear in page that be, or are commonly reputed to be ill affected in matters of religion professed in our Church, or taken to be Recusant Papists, refusing to repair unto the Church to heare divine Service, and receive the holy Communion, and being disobedient to his Highnesse Laws in that behalf provided? Or do any publish, sell, or disperse any superstitious books or writings; or other books, libells, or writings of any
lectuaries touching the Religion, State, or Ecclesiasticall government of this Kingdome of England? Present their names, qualities, and conditions. Doth any Papist keep a Schoolmaster in his house, which cometh not to Church as is required? What is his name, and how long hath he taught there or elsewhere?

div.head: sig [B1] (Articles concerning parishioners)
div.ab: 17 Whether any person in your Parish, doe exercise any Trade or labour, buy or sell, or keep open Shops or Ware-houses vpon any Sunday or Holyday by themselues, their Seruants, or Apprentices, or haue otherwise prophaned the said dayes, contrary to the orders of the Church of England? And whether there be any Inne-keepers, Alehouse keepers, Victuallers or other persons, that permit any persons in their houses, to eate, drinke, or play, during the time of Diuine Seruice or Sermon, or reading the Homilies in the forenoone or afternoone, vpon those dayes?

div.head: sigs [B1v-B2] (Articles concerning churchwardens and sidemen)
div.ab: 1 Whether you and the Church-wardens, Quest-men or Side-men, from time to time, do, and haue done their diligence, in not suffering any idle person to abide either in the Church yard or Church porch in Seruice or Sermon time; but causing them either to come into the Church to heare Diuine Seruice, or to depart, and not disturbe such as be hearers there? And whether they haue, and you doe diligently see the parishioners duely resort to the Church euery Sunday and Holiday, and there to remaine During Seruice and Sermon? And whether you or your predecessors, Churchwardens there, suffer any Playes, Feasts, Drinkings, or any other profaneing in any Inne or Victualling house in your parish, during the time of Diuine Seruice or Sermon, on Sundaies and Holydayes?

div.head: sig A2 (Concerning religion and doctrine)
div.ab: 4 Be there any abiding in, or resorting to your Parish, that are commonly reputed to be ill affected in matter of the religion professed in our Church, or taken to be Recusant Papists, or factious separatists, refusing to repaire vnto the Church, to heare diuine Seruice, and to receive the holy Communion? Or that haue or do publish, sell or disperse any superstitious, seditious, or schismaticall Bookes, Libels, or Writings, touching the Religion, State, or Ecclesiasticall gouernment of this Kingdome of England? Present their names, qualities, and conditions, if you know or haue heard of any.

div.head: sigs A3–3v) (Concerning the church, furniture, and possessions)
div.ab:
7 Is your Church-yard, or Chappell-yard well fenced, and kept without abuse? and if not, whose is the default? Hath any person within your memorie, or that you haue credibly heard of, incroached vpon the Church-yard, by setting vp any kinde of building or fence vpon it, or by opening any doore, gate, or stile into it? Hath any vsed that place (consecrated to an holy vse) prophanely or wickedly? Hath any quarrelled or stricken one another, either in the Church or Church-yard? Hath any person behaued himselfe rudely and disorderly in either; or vsed any filthy or prophane talke, or
any other rude and immodest behauiour in them? Haue any Playes, Feasts, Banquets, Suppers, Church-ales, Drinkings, Temporall-Courts or Leets, Lay-iuries, Musters, exercise of dancing, Stoole- ball, Foote ball, or the like, or any other prophane vsage beene suffered to be kept in your Church, Chappell, or Church-yard?

div.head: sig B4 (Concerning the churchwardens and sidemen)
div.ab: 8 Haue the Churchwardens suffered the Church, Church-yard, or Chappell, to be prophaned by Playes, Games, Feasts, Banquets, Suppers, Church-ales, Drinkings, Temporall Courts, or Leets, Lay-iuries, Musters, etc. at any time acted, kept, or held in them?

div.head: sig B4v (Concerning the parishioners)
div.ab: 11 Are there within your Parish or thereunto resorting, any players on Stage, or with Puppets, or any Musitians, Fidlers, Rimers, or Iesters, which do vse any prophane or filthy passages, in their songs, speeches, or gestures, to the dishonour of God, abuse of Scripture, or the corrupting of good manners; or which do publish any thing scandalous to the State, or reproachfull to the Holy Clergie?

div.head: sig A3 (Articles concerning the churchyard and other consecrated appendages to the church)
div.ab: 7 Much lesse is itit: ie, the churchyard to be unhallowed with dancings, Morises, meetings at Easter, drinkings, Whitson-Ales, Midsommer merrimates,merrimates: for merrimakes? or the like nor by stoole-ball, foot-ball, wrastlings, wasters, or boyessports: if such abuse hath bin committed, say by whom, whose procurement, countenance, or abetting.

div.head: sig A2 (Articles concerning religion and doctrine)
div.ab: 8. Item, Is there any in your Parish, or resorting to it, that hath, or doth sell, publish, or disperse any superstitious, seditious, or schismaticall Bookes, Libels, or writings, touching, the Religion, State, or Ecclesiasticall goverment of this Kingdome, present their names, qualities, and conditions, if you know, or haue heard of any?

div.head: sigs A3v (Articles concerning the church, furniture, and possessions)
div.ab: 6. Item, Whether is your Churchyard or Chappellyard well fenced and kept, without abuse, and if not, whose is the default? hath any person within your memory, or that you have credibly heard of, encroached upon the Churchyard, by setting up any kind of building or fence upon it, or by opening any doore, gate, or stile into it? hath any used that place (consecrated to an holy use) prophanely, or wickedly? hath any quarrelled or stricken one another, either in the Church or Churchyard; hath any person behaved himselfe rudely and disorderly in either, or used any filthy or prophane talke, or any other rude and immodest behaviour in them? have any Playes, Feasts, Banquets, Suppers, Church-ales, Drinkings, temporall Courts, or Leets, Lay-iuries, Musters, exercise of Dancing, Stooleball, Football, or the like, or any other prophane usage beene suffered to be kept in your Church, Chappell, or Churchyard?

div.head: sig B2v (Articles concerning the parishioners)
div.ab: 1 Item, Whether doe any in your Parish prophane any Sunday or Holiday, by vnlawfull gaming, drinking or tipling in Taverns, Innes, or Alehouses, in the time of common prayer or Sermon; or by working, or doing the worke of their Trades and occupations? doe any in your Parish buy or sell, or keepe open their shops, or set out their wares to bee sold on Sundayes or Holidayes, by themselves, their servants or apprentices; or have they any other waies prophaned the said dayes? and hath the Kings declaration concerning lawfull recreations, beene published amongst you, yea or no? If so, when was it done? in what manner? and by whom?

div.p: The King's Declaration of Sports, also known as the Book of Sports was a pronouncement by James I, repeated by Charles I. Published in 1617, 1618, and 1633, it sanctioned the freedom of people to engage in a wide array of lawful sports, recreations and traditional customs on Sundays and other holy days, including May games, Whitsun ales, morris dances, baitings, interludes, and similar activities following divine services. Its purpose was to counteract the increasingly rigid prohibitions of such things by Puritan ministers and their followers who condoned only attendance at divine services and sometimes intolerably long sermons on the Sabbath.

div.head: sig A2 (Concerning religion and doctrine)
div.ab: 8. Item, Is there any in your Parish, or resorting to it, that hath, or doth sell, publish, or disperse any superstitious, seditious, or schismaticall Bookes, Libels, or writings, touching the Religion, State, or Ecclesiasticall goverment of this Kingdome, present their names, qualities, and conditions, if you know, or have heard of any?

div.head: sigs A3v (Concerning the church, furniture, and possessions)
div.ab: 6 Item, Whether is your Churchyard, or Chappelyard well fenced and kept, without abuse, and if not, whose is the default? hath any person within your memory, or that you have credibly heard of, encroached upon the Churchyard, by setting up any kind of building or fence upon it, or by opening any doore, gate, or stile into it? hath any used that place (consecrated to an holy use) prophanely, or wickedly? hath any quarrelled or stricken one another, either in the Church or Churchyard; hath any person behaved himselfe rudely or disorderly in either, or used any filthy or prophane talke, or any other rude and immodest behaviour in them? have any Playes, Feasts, Banquets, Suppers, Church-ales, Drinkings, temporall Courts, or Leets, Lay-iuries, Musters, exercise of Dauncing, Stooleball, Football, or the like, or any other prophane usage beene suffered to be kept in your Church, Chappell, or Churchyard?

div.head: sig B2v (Concerning the parishioners)
div.ab: 1 Item, Whether doe any in your Parish prophane any Sunday or Holiday, by vnlawfull gaming, drinking or tipling in Taverns, Innes, or Alehouses, in the time of common-prayer or Sermon, or by working, or doing the worke of their Trades and occupations? doe any in your Parish buy or sell, or keepe open their shops, or set out their wares to bee sold on Sundayes or Holidayes, by themselves, their servants or apprentices; or have they any other waies prophaned the said dayes? And hath the Kings declaration concerning lawfull recreations, beene published amongst you, yea or no? If so, when was it done? in what manner? and by whom?

div.p: The King's Declaration of Sports, also known as the Book of Sports was a pronouncement by James I, repeated by Charles I. Published in 1617, 1618, and 1633, it sanctioned the freedom of people to engage in a wide array of lawful sports, recreations and traditional customs on Sundays and other holy days, including May games, Whitsun ales, morris dances, baitings, interludes, and similar activities following divine services. Its purpose was to counteract the increasingly rigid prohibitions of such things by Puritan ministers and their followers who condoned only attendance at divine services and sometimes intolerably long sermons on the Sabbath.

row.cell: Item to the Lord Darbyes players

div.p: William Stanley (1561–1642) was fifteenth earl of Derby from 16 April 1594, with residences at Knowsley, Lathom, and New Park, Lancashire. See P&P.

row.cell: Item to the Erle of Darbyes players
Item to the Lord Oglye his players
Item to my Lord Admyrall his players

div.p: Cuthburt Ogle (c 1540–1497; f 25v) was seventh Lord Ogle from 1 August 1562, with seat at Bothal, Northumberland. See P&P.
The payment on f 26 was made between 19 and 26 August.
Charles Howard (c 1536–1624) was lord high admiral (f 26) from 1585, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.

row.cell: Item geuen to an Erle Menne yat woulde haue played in towne
Item paid to the Quene her Maiestie players and yet much discontented by Mr Allen scrivener

div.p: A note in the margin three entries before this one gives the date 5 March. The next dated entry (on the following leaf) is 16 July.
On f 46, someone contemporary (presumably the scribe) has written the date 20 March. The payments on f 45v would therefore have been made sometime before that date.
The identity of the earl (f 46) is not given in the account. Since the men were being paid not to play, it is obvious that they were a troupe of performers.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9.

row.cell: Item layed out to her Maiestie players

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9.
Charles Howard (c 1536–1624) was lord high admiral from 1585, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.

div.head: ff 101v–2 (7 October) (Assembly minutes)

cell.note: Thomas … Aleyn: the two names are encompassed by a brace pointing to the right
waightes: followed by a brace pointing to the right

row.cell:
Anthonie Padnall Master
William Ryme
Thomas Burradge IuratiWilliam … Iurati: a brace pointing towards Iurati encompasses the two names

div.ab: ffirstffirst: in display scriptit is at this presente Assemblye Ordeyned & graunted vnto that thafore named Mr ouer his men for Waightes/ the tyme being shall take & receiue such duties & other dutyes what soeuer incident therevnto for solonge tyme as he shall Contynew in the said seruice. And for his parte promiseth in Consideracion thereof well & trewlye to serue & keepe the said watche with his instrumentes by himself & Servantes from & after the Mondaie next after after Michaelmas daye last past vntill the ffeast of the Purification of St Mary the virgin than next ensewing Saving onely for the tyme & vtys of Christmas/

div.p: This entry presents two sets of names. A note in the left margin indicates that the first two names (Thomas Copping and Robert Aleyn) are members of the twenty-four burgesses, one of the two governing bodies of the town. Court headings on ff 101 and 121v provide further confirmation. To the right of Copping and Aleyn is a second entry giving the names of the town's three waits: Anthonie Padnall, William Ryme, and Thomas Burradge. In 1609 a Thomas Burrage would appear in the Ipswich civic records as a member of the city's company of musicians and would serve as master of that company from 1613 through 1637 (see his will). In 1614 the Dunwich Common Assembly does not name Burrage as being among their waits (f 261). It seems like that the Dunwich and Ipswich Burrages were one and the same person. Burrage had likely moved to Ipswich because by that time Dunwich had all but disappeared as a town. The names of Ryme and Burradge are followed by a brace and what I take to be the abbreviated form for juratores (municipal officers).

row.cell: Item for the charges of the Townesmen on the Coronacion Daye viz. Ringers gunners & dromers

div.p: The Historical Manuscripts Commission report for Dunwich dates this account as 1603/4 (p 90).
Thomas Howard (1585-1646) was 26th Earl of Arundel, with residences at Arundel Castle, Sussex and Padua, Italy.

AtAt: in display scriptthis assemblyeThelleccion of
the Wayghtes it is agreed by Mr Bayliffes and the rest of thassemblye and they haue nowe elected and Chosen Thomas Thomplinson to be the waight of this our said towne and burghe and execute that place for one yere from Michaellmas next and that he shall haue twoe more of his Companye at the least accordingly as in tymes past hath ben vsed/

James Stuart (1566–1625) was crowned James I of England on 24 March 1602/3. See P&P.

Item laid out to the kinges players

div.p: In this carefully dated account, the entry immediately preceding this payment to the King's players is dated 19 October, the one immediately following is dated 26 October.
James Stuart (f [3v]; 1566– 1625), was crowned James I of England on 24 March 1602/3. See P&P.

The entry following this one (f 275v) is dated 25 April 1615.
James Stuart (1566–1625), was crowned James I of England on 24 March 1602/3. See P&P.

row.cell: Item geuen to the Princes players
Item geuen to the Quenes Players
Item geuen to the Quenes Players
Item geuen to the Quenes Players at an other tyme

div.p: Charles Stuart (f 289v; 1600–1648/9) was prince of Wales from 4 November 1616 until his accession to the Crown on 27 March 1625.

As Wasson, Plays and Players, p 158, points out, the bailiff Thomas Gathercole (f 289v) died in office during the summer, 1616, following the payment on f 289v. The payments on ff 294v–5 were made by the bailiff William Robson, who served until Michaelmas.
Charles Stuart (1600–48/9) was crowned Charles I of England on 27 March 1625. See P&P.

div.head: f 113 (1 April)
div.ab: And also I will that Katherine my Daughter shall haue ye virginalls standinge in my haull

div.head: single membrane (March-May) (Interrogatories directed to the defendants)
div.ab: Item whither6 did you or any other to your knowledge or as you verelye beleve devise write or publishe the libell specified in the complaynantes bill of complaynt or any part thereof or were you aidinge asistinge or privy to the inventinge devisinge writinge readinge or publishing of the said libell or any part thereof or haue you herd the said libell or any part thereof red and was not the same red at the howse of one Iohn Bristo at Leystofft and in whose presence was the same red or did you reade the same your selfe and what person or persons brought or offered the same to be red and howe often haue you herd the same red and by whom ‸when and where

Item7 whither was not the said libell brought to the house of one Thomas durant of Carlton Colvile in the county of Suffolk and there red and was not the same brought thither by the said Hullock Everard and whoe red the same there and what persons did here the same red and whither was not the same there published or signefied to be made of the complaynant and thentent to sclander and disgrace the complaynant althoughe the name of Grombold ‸was vsid and insertid into the said libell to evade and color the misdemeanor of the making of the said libell/

Item whither8 was the said libell made or devised of or to the disgrace of any other person or persons then of the said complaynant and if it were then of whom and by whom was the said libell made and howe knowe you the same/

Item whither9 did your children or any of them lerne the said libell bihart or any part thereof and by whom were they lerned and whither did they singe the same and whither did they singe the same dyvers and many times or not and whither did you here them singe the same and did you not delight and take pleasure in the singinge thereof and whie did you not rebuke them for singing thereof/

Item whither10 haue you not comonly or many times iested of the said libell and shewid the said libell or any part thereof to any straungers and to whom and whither have you given any copie or copies of the said libill or of any part thereof to any person or persons and to whom/

Item whither11 doth not the complaynant dwell in the said towne of Carleton Colvell in the county of Suffolk by the highe waye and howe longe hath he dwelt there and whither did he dwell there at the makinge or devisinge of the said libell or not/

div.head: single membrane (26 June) (Deposition by Hullock Everard, yeoman)
div.ab: To the6. first parte of the sixt interrogatorie he can noe further depose then he have before declared in his answer nowe delyuered, and further he sayeth that he never harde anye lybell redd at the house of Iohn Bristowe in Lowstoft but this Examinate did reed a lybell at the house of William Hullocke one of the defendantes: but yt was somethinge differing from the lybell mentioned in the bill of Complaynte, but when he did reed the same he doeth not nowe remember and further to this interrogatorie he can not depose

To the7. vijth he sayeth that he this deponent brought the lybell mentioned in the interrogatorie to the house of Thomas durrante in Carleton Colvile where the courte was kepte when the sayd bill was delyuered vnto the Steward as he hath mentioned in his answer, wherevnto he referreth him selfe/
To the8. eight he sayeth that he doeth not knowe to the disgrace of whome the lybell was made, except yt were ageinst the complainant but by whome yt was made he knoweth not
To the9. ixth he sayeth that none of his Children did euer learne the sayd lybell by harte or anye parte thereof, neyther did they singe yt to his knowledge

To the10. xth he sayeth that concerninge the lybell mentioned in the interrogatorie he hath bene menye at the same; but he neuer delyuered the same or anye Coppie thereof to anye person, saving onelye to the Steward as he haue before deposed
To the11. xith he sayeth that the Complainant dwelleth nere the highewaye in Carleton Colvile and did dwell there when the libell mentioned in the interrogatorie was fownde/

To the6. vjth he sayeth that he did neyther wright, publishe or devise the lybell specified in the Complainantes bill neyther doeth he knowe or was privye to the wryghtwryght: edge of page missing; likely 'wryghting' thereof, or anye parte thereof And further sayeth that there was a wrightinge carriecarrie: edge of page missing; likely 'carried' to Iohn Bristowes in Lowstofe by this deponent, and there readd by Edward Browne mentioned in the bill of Complainte and that in the same wrightinge was conteyned dyue wordes, whereof some of those wordes were conteyned in the lybell mentioned in the sa bill of Complainte

To the9. ixth he sayeth that his daughter, and one other guirle dwellinge with him this ExaExa: edge of page missing; likely 'Examinant' haue songe some parte of the lybell mentioned in the interrogatorie and sayeth that he haue dyvers tymes rebuked them for soe doinge

div.p: The interrogatories for March–May also asked questions related to the defendants' claims concerning the plaintiff: whether the defendants had knowledge that the plaintiff Corbold had engaged in usury, or had otherwise cheated anyone financially, or had comitted adultery, or improperly fattened then sold cattle, or had caused forfeiture by anyone to whom he had lent money; or that the defendants themselves had called the plaintiff 'Burnt Breche,' or had asked a poor boy whose mother the plaintiff had befriended whether he was in fact 'younge Grymbold,' all of which are alluded to in the ballad.

On 26 June, defendant Hullock Everard, in answering interrogatories 14 and 15, admits that in speaking to one Thomas Howard he referred to the plaintiff as Grombold. In responding to interrogatory 9, his wife Prudence gives the same answer as her husband: her daughter and another girl living with them at the time had sung words from the libellous ballad in the family's house (dorse).

div.head: Item [1], ff [9-9v] (4 July) (Deposition by Thomas Hullock, yeoman)
div.ab: To the vjth Interrogatorie this defendant saieth that neither he this defendant nor anie other to this defendantes knowledge & by his privitie did devise write or publishe the Libell specified in the said Bill of Complainte or anie parte thereof nor was present to the inventinge nor hath hearde anie parte thereof Reade at the house of I Iohn Bristowe, or at anie other tyme then at such tymes as the same was reade to this defendant by the said Complainantes Bill & more he saieth not to the Interrogatorie

To the vijth Interrogatorie this defendant saieth that Tho Hullocke Everarde mencioned in the Interrogatorie did vpon a tyme tell this defendant that he . had receiued a papir sealed vpp to the house of the said Thomas Durrant
But did not ‸tell this defendant what the same papir conteyned but yet afterwardes this defendant did heare that the same was a Libell, And whether the same was read & published at the said Durrantes house & more or otherwise to the Interrogatorie this defendant saieth he cannot depose.

To the 9 Interrogatorie he saieth that none of this defendantes Children did or have learned the said Libell ‸by harte or anie parte thereof as is supposed neither did this defendant at anie tyme heare his said Children at anie tyme singe the said Libell or anie parte thereof & more he saieth not to the Interrogatorie.

To the 11 Interrogatorie this defendant saieth that the said now Complainant doth dwell at ‸in the said Towne of Carlton Collvell by the highway syde, & did dwell there at the tyme when ‸it is reported the saied Libell was made or devised, as this defendant thinketh.

div.head: ff [11-11v] (11 July) (Deposition by Edward Browne, gentleman, of Beccles)
div.ab:
To the vjth Interrogatorie this defendant saieth That he is not charged ‸as he taketh it by the said Complainantes Bill with the devisinge or publishinge of the saied Libell notwithstandinge this defendant saieth as before he hath oftentymes protested
to the saied now Complainant ‸in ye presence of diuers persons that neither he this defendant nor anie other to his ‸ certen knowledge did devise write or publish the Libell specified in the saied Complainantes bill nor anie parte ‸ thereof neither was the defendant aidinge assistinge or privie to the inventinge writinge, Readinge or publishinge of the said Libell ‸as is mencioned in the said Bill or anie parte thereof Neither doth this defendant know that the same supposed Libell ‸mencioned in the said Bill was Read at the house of the said Iohn Bristow & more or otherwise he saieth not to the interrogatorie

To the 8. Interrogatorie this defendant saieth that he doth not know to whose Disgrace the said Libell was made or devized ‸but ye same as this defendant taketh it . might aswell be ment of some other as of the said Complainant, neither doth this defendant thinke that the same wold have turned to the said plaintiffs disgrace ‸so much as it semeth now to be but that he the said Plaintiff doth ‸ bewraie & accuse himself therein ‸& goe about to purchase his owne disgrace as may appere by his proceedinges & more he saieth not to the Interrogatorie

To the 10.th Interrogatorie this defendant saieth that he did never see the said supposed Libell ‸mencioned in the said Bill before the tyme that it was shewed to this defendant by the said plaintiffs Bill in this honorable Courte Remayninge

div.head: Item no. [5], single mb (6 February)
div.ab: To the Quenes most Excellent Maiestie./

In most lamentable wise complayninge sheweth vnto your most excellent maiestie your highnes poore and loyall Subiect Robert Corbold of Carleton Colvell in your maiesties Countie of Suffolk yeoman That whereas one William Hullock of Gisleham in your maiesties said Countye of Suffolk yeoman was lawfully stayed in his demesne as of ffee of and in thirtie acres errable land and pasture or there aboughtes lyinge in Gisleham aforesaid in three seuerall Closes And so beinge thereof seized the sayd william Hullock in or abought the seaven and twentyth day of marche last by paroll and word of his mouthe in the presence of dyvers credible and honest witnesses did demise and lease the same vnto your said Subiect from that tyme vntill the feast of the annuncyacion of the virgine Mary next ensueinge In consideracion whereof your said Subiect did contract and agree with the said William Hullock the same fower and twentie acres parcell of the said premisses with peases ffetches and oates and at harvest then followeinge to yeld vnto the said William Hullock the moyetie of the Corne by reason of the sayd soweinge then to growe vppon the sayd fower and twentie acres in and for satisffaccion and as a consideracion or rent of the said premisses for the sayd tyme so demised the said Corne to be cut downe mowen and parted at the equall costes and chardges of the said William Hullock and of your said Subiect By force of which demise and agreament your sayd Subiect entred into the premisses so to him demised and was therof possessed accordingly and so beinge thereof possessed at his owne proper costes and chardges did plough and sowe the said fower and twentie acres with peases ffetches and oates But so it is if it may please your most excellent Maiestie that the sayd William Hullock accompanyed with prudence Hullock his wief Thomas Hullock of Gisleham aforesaid yeoman and Mary his wief, Hulllock Everard of the same towne yeoman and Thomas Chapman Thomas Meryman alias Vyn / Robert Vennell Christofer Nelson Iohn Palmer Erasmus Watson and Elizabeth his wief and Alice Hayward wydowe of Gisleham aforesaid and other persons to your Subiect yet vnknowen beinge armed and some of them then haueinge hokes Rakes pitcheforkes and some of them beinge armed with swordes and Daggers and other weapons aswell Invasyve as defensyve the second third and fourthe dayes of September last past in most riotuous and routuous sort and manner did forcible and ryotuously enter vppon the sayd demised premisses and your said Subiect beinge then and there in godes peace and your Maiesties did then and there violently assalt and take by the thorote and your said Subiect hauinge his horse and Cart there redy to haue caryed his part of the said Pease fetches and oates did violently forceciblyforcecibly: for forcibly and riotuously eiect and put oute your sayd Subiect of the possession of the premisses and in like violent and riotuos Manner did cut in sunder the trayses of your said Subiectes horses and Cart And did in violent and riotuous manner take and carry away the most of the said Corne and the residue and such part thereof as they did not cary away he the sayd William Hullock did most vnorderly distray and consume with his hogges horse and other cattell contrary to your maiesties lawes and peace of your land and to the evill example and encorragement of the like malefactors and offendors to do the like if condigne punishement should be not to them extended in this behalf. And so it is further if it may please your most excellent Maiestie That whereas your pore Subiect is your highnes loyall and faythfull Subiect and as the good loyall and honest Subiect of your highnes and of divers of your progenitors from his Birth tyme hetherto hath remayned and lyved and by all the said tyme hath contynewed and lyved of good name fame credit and estimacion aswell amongest men of worshipp as other your highnes good and faythfull Subiectes withoute lendinge of money to vsury or cosonynge or deceyvinge of any of your highnes Subiectes or committinge of Advltry or leadinge of any such lewde or filthie lief or beinge suspected of the crymes or offences aforesaid or any of them By reason of which your said Subiect his sayd honest lief and conuersacion your said Subiect did not only gett the favour good opinyon and good will of your highnes said worshipfull and other good Subiectes But also by lawfull buyeinge and sellinge amongest your said good and honest Subiectes did obteyne and gett divers profittes and commodities in maynetenaunce of him self and his famylie and the increase of his poore estate But so it is further if it may please your most excellent maiestie that one Edward Browne of Beccles in your highnes said Countie of Suffolk gentleman Iohn Beamont of Mutford in your Maiesties sayd County Clerk and the sayd Hullock Everard William Hullock and Thomas Hullock not contented with ther foresaid misdemeasnors but malicinge the good estate of your sayd poore Subiect and entendinge asmuch as in them might lye to take awaye the good name and creditt of your said Subiect and to bringe him your said Subiect into the evill opinion of your worshipfull and other good Subiectes whereby he might loose that good meanes by which he your sayd Subiect did gett his lyveinge they the said Edward Browne Iohn Beamont Hullock Everard William Hullock and Thomas Hullock : line filler written over erasure of as many as 13 characters afterwardes that is to say in or about the tenth daye of October last past did writ or cause or procure to be written in paper one false and sclaunderous libell of your said Subiect to the greate defamacion discredit and slaunder of your said Subiect in these wordes followinge viz. A wise report there runnes abroade; in Carleton there doth dwell, a cosonynge crosbitinge knave, which beares away the Bell, ffrom all the knaves within the towne or ells where for or neare I dare even boldly set it downe, this knave shall fynde no pere, his name I knowe not very well, but is I do heare say, some call him Grumbold some Burntbrich he dwelles nere the high way, This Grombold is both prowde and stowte, for no man he doth care, his frende or father to deceyve, for gayne he will not spare, he hath a bold and brasen face, he will booth crake and lye his neighbors thinke hym past all grace, his dedes no lesse do trye, ffirst he his ffather toke in hand and would haue turned him oute even from his house and all his lande, I put you oute of doubt, This was the kyndnes that he fownde, of this his gracelesse son, if he had fownde no better frendes he had ben quite vndone, This Grumbold nowe hath sold his land, and as I do heare say, he meanes to live by vsury, which is an easy way, ffor he can still to give a grippe, if men fall in his hand, they shalbe sure for to pay the forfett of there band, Althoughe that he before ther day tell them they nede not feare, for thoughe they vnprovided be; he may them well forbeare, yet when the daye and tyme is past, he comes vpon the rownde, and tells that he for want of paye, hath lost even many a pownde, for profe of this I can bringe forth, good witnes two or three, and on the backsyde of this booke, there names recorded be, Oh Grombold this is a knavishe trick, you can it not excuse, all honest men such knavishe shifte, will vtterly refuse, Grombold hath other knavishe trickes and badly leades his lief, and certenly he loves a whore, much better then his wief, ffor profe thereof if that you please, To Debenham to repayer, there is but fewe within that towne, But they can well declare, for in that towne longe tyme he lay, by reason of a blowe, his Instrumenttes were burnt of the trueth if you will knowe, nowe for this tyme I say no more thoughe I muche more could say, but Grombold kepe a k in stoare, till I come by that way. And the said Edward Browne Iohn Beamont Hullock Everard, william Hullock, and Thomas Hullock to give further creditt to ther said false and slanderous libell in or about the daye and yere last aforesaid did writt or cause or procure to be written vpon the same libell thre names viz. ffraunces Mawfey Richard Scarlett and George Rippinge and further indorsed the same with these wordes followinge These Ballettes are to be sold in the house of Iohn Haltwaye of Burneby nere vnto the Smithes fforge or ells at the house of Edmond Harys nere HoburHobur: as many as 7 characters erased Hill And the said Hullock Everard William Hullock and Prudence his wief Thomas Hullock and Mary his wief practizinge howe to vrge the said false and slanderous libell to the further discreditt and disgrace of your said Subiect did not only the day and yere, last abouesaid publishe the said false and slanderous libell knoweinge the same to be false and slaunderous and vse to singe the same in there houses and other places in divers companyes but also do from tyme to tyme teach and instruct there Children and servauntes to say behart and singe the said false and sclaunderous libell to the greate disquiet and discountenaunce of your said poore Subiect to the evill example and encouragement of the like offendors and malefactours to do the like if condigne punishment be not therein provided and contrary to your Maiesties peas and lawes of your highnes Realme in that case made and provided And your said Subiect Averreth and saith that althoughe the said parties writers and devisors of the said vntrue and sclanderous libell did insert there into the name of Grombold yet they ment and entended the same only of your said Subiect and to his sclaunder and reproche and did insert and vse the said name of Grumbold but for an Invasion and to colour ther said misdemesnours as your said Subiect will most manifestly prove to your most excellent Maiestie In tender consideracion whereof and for that the sayd offences are directly against your Maiesties good and holesome lawes and deserve severe punishment May it please your most excellent Maiestie of your accustomed goodnes to graunte vnto your said Subiect your highnes most honorable writt of Subpena to be directed to the said William Hullock and Prudence his wief Thomas Hullock and Mary his wief Hullock Everard, Thomas Chapman, Thomas Meryman alias Vyn Robert Vennell, Christofer Nelson, Iohn Palmer, Erasmus Watson and Elizabeth his wief Alice Hayward Edward Browne and Iohn Beamont commandinge them and every of them parsonally to appere before your most excellent Maiestie in your hignes Court of Starchamber at westminster then and there to make answere to the premisses and further to stand to and abyde such order and direction herein as to your maiesties most honorabale privye Councell shall seme to stand with your Maiesties lawes of this realme And your said Subiect accordinge to his most bownden allegiance shall dayly pray vnto almightie god for your Maiesties longe lief and most happie and prosperous reigne over vs/../ Amen./

div.head: single membrane (11 February)
div.ab: To the Kynges most Excellent Maiestie

In most humble wise complayninge sheweth & informeth vnto your most Excellent Maiestie your Loyall faithfull & obedient subiecte Paule Powle of Great Waldingfeild in the Countie of Suffolk gentleman, That wheras about the xjth daye of Maye in the Sixte yeare of your heighnes most happie Reigne over vs, your said subiect beinge an Attorny of your Heighnes Corte of Kinges Benche & a Phylizor of the said Corte : 6mm of erasure with line filler at the instant request & entreatie of one Thomas Rogers Clarke Parson of horninger in the Countie aforesaid : 165mm of erasure with line filler did for the some of Twentie powndes of lawfull english money to be payd to your said subiect by the said Thomas Rogers entertayne into his howse & service. Robert Rogers his sonne to instruct & teach in the practice & skyll of an Attorney ffor which twenty poundes the said Thomas Rogers became bound to your sayd Subiect in foure severall Bylls) And for thintent aforesaid the said Robert Rogers to & with the consent of the said Thomas Rogers his said father became bound by Indenture. vnto your said Subiecte to remayne & dwell with your said subiect as his servant & Apprentice from the ffeast of Saint Iohn Baptiste in the said Sixt yeare of your said heignes Reigne vnto the full end & Terme of ffowre yeares from thence next ensewinge & fully to be compleat & ended By which his said Indenture he did covenaunt & promise to & with your said subiect, That your said Subiect he should well & trulie serve in preceptes lawfull & honest he shold doe, his Secretes he shold keepe close hurt or damage to your said subiect he shold not doe nor see to be done by any other But to his power shold lett the same, & warne your said Subiect therof, the Goodes of your said Subiect he shold not imbezill, Alehowses he shold not hawnte, matrymony with any woman he shold not contract, ffrom the service of your said Subiect he shold not departe nor absent himself, But in all thinges as a good & feithfull servant and Apprentice to your said subiecte he should beare & behave himself as by the said Indenture bearinge date aboute the xjth day of Maye aforesaid more at lardge yt doth & may appeare, But soe yt is may it please your most excellent Maiestie, That the said Robert Rogers havinge contynued with your said subiect from the sayd xjth daye of Maye vntill the xiiijth day of September then next followinge By all which time aswell of his owne malicious nature as therowe the perswacion & instigacion of one William Coleman of great waldingfeild aforesaid yoman a professed adversary to your said Subiect as heerafter shall appeare hath not only during the time aforesaid behaved himself very stoburnlie & perverslie towardes your said subiect in denyinge to doe those businesses for his practice as an Attorny in writinge owte presidentes & such like for his Instruccion, & hath disclosed your subiectes secreates Alehowses he hath hawnted Matrymony he sought & endeav to contract But allso hath most maliciouslie & slaunderouslie in the time aforesaid wrote dyvers lettres to one mr Isaack WincollIsaack Wincoll: Isaac Wincoll (b. 1594), gentleman, of Twinstead Hall, Essex, who married Mary, daughter of Thomas Waldegave of the Ferrers in Bures Hamlet Essex. of Twinsted in the Countie of Essex Esquier vnckle to the said Robert Rogers in manner of a lybell against your said Subiect wherin amongest other thinges he taxeth your said subiect as followeth viz That by an vnfortunate wynd he was blowne to the flotinge shore of croked destynyes & seekinge some better harbor was the boulder with the said mr Wincoll to desire his furtherance in the waye of his better fortunes (by reason he was placed to a man (meaninge your said subiect both to his owne discredytt & not to any present Benefitt, And lastlie oute of hope & weye of future preferment, And he beinge thus made a bond slave as he writeth to a man of most base Condicions (meaninge your said Subiect) he amongest many vnseemelie speeches desireth the favor of the said mr wincoll to place him eyther with Sir Edward LewknorEdward Lewknor: Edward Lewknor (1587–1618), Denham near Bury, sheriff of Suffolk, JP for Suffolk c 1614–15 or later or Sir Henry Gawdie,Henry Gawdie: Henry Gawdie(c 1553–1621, Claxton, Norfolk, JP for Suffolk from 1593 And duringe the time of his said bond with your said subiect as his servant & Apprentice as aforesaid he wrote another libellinge lettre to the said mr wincoll wherin most maliciouslie & vntrulie he slaundereth & taxeth your said subiect. And after your said subiect had knowledge of the foresaid vnnaturall & treacherous practises plotted & acted, by the said Robert Rogers as aforesaid, your said subiect did forthwith acqueynt the said Isaak Wincoll by his lettres That you said subiect had knowledge of the lettres sent to him by the said Rogers his servant. acquetinge the said Isaacke Wincoll therin that the said Rogers was your said Subiectes servant & apprentice, & therefore wished him not to intermeddle with the placinge or displacinge of him, And afterwardes the said Robert Rogers perceivinge his practises lybellinge lettres, & his malicious & slaunderous endeavors against your said subiect to be layd open, And nowe not fearinge to proceed to any owtrage or misdemeanor against your said subiect knowinge his frendes to be very riche & welthie & able to beare him owte against your said subiecte beinge but of a meane estate in Welth in respect of them, & not able to contend with them in sutes & trobles of the Lawe, And nowe to loath your said subiect whollie of him & of his bad Cariage, did about the moneth of August in the said Sixte yere of your heighnes Reigne write pen & publishe a most infamous and scandalous lybell in meeter & Ryme against your said subiect & his wife, The tenor wherof followeth in theise wordes./ Behold ambitious trewe begotten Sonne, for in resemblance he is more lyke none, No greedy wolfe he hunteth after Wardes to keepe his place mowthd wise in welth & gardes he feyneth frendship yet he loves them not because hopes he ther's somwhat to be gott, And clawes & soothes men vp at enye word yet is his frendshipp fatall as an edgd sword, Soe lyves he to the wretched world aloane, loathsome to all thatt longes to see him gone. If such he bee as such he is in deede, Thers nothinge worse for nothinge worse can breed, he dwells in hate & lyves lyke cursed Cayne, for nothinge Will his harte nor conscience steyne, Stryve not to rayse thie fortunes by oppression. But satisfie thie self with thie possession, lett shame from such a vice thie life exempt, That make the riche in nothinge but contempt, Thow elvish Caytife & accursed Kyte, I say be satisfied with thats thie righte And cease from seekinge with sinyster gaine Thie wife in hiest pride for to meynteyne, knowe thow that nothinge is vnknowne to him that sees, how plannetes move, & howe the world agrees, If that a man wold paynte a monster right, sett forth but even this one to others sight, Paynt all the harmes that he to harmeles bringes, And sure this snake will shewe ten thowsand stinges, Revenge to him I leave that all doth swaye whoe doubtles will at lengthe his spight display, And nowe in fyne I councell the to have. A mynd to thincke of death & eke of grave Geve to the poore that thow hast gott by wronge, ffor assure thie self thy dayes cannot be longe ffolowe this frendlie councell that I give, Or else in shame & hatred shalt thow lyve, Or Dead those Messengers that spies thie grave shall say heer lyes a brokinge brybinge knave, And after your said subiecte had knowledge of this Lybell your said subiect beinge growne vnto great dislyke of the said Robert Rogers & with his dealinges as aforesaid And callinge in question the said Robert Rogers for the same in the presence of the said Thomas Rogers his father, And shewed the sayd Lybell to the said Robert Rogers (beinge very fayrely written & penned vnder his owne hand writinge, And ymediatelie the said Robert confessed the makinge inditinge & publishinge of the said Libell against your subiecte & his wife, whervppon after many bitter speeches vsed by the said Thomas Rogers to the said Robert his Sonne for theise his great abuses & misdemeanors. The said Robert Rogers asked your said subiect forgivenes vppon his knees for theis his offences & promised never to offend in the lyke agayne. And for that your said subiect did then thincke & conceive that he was led & drawne to the said owtragious courses partlie of his owne prowd & malicious nature & partlie by thinstigacion of the said William ColemanWilliam Coleman: yeoman, Great Waldingfield whoe enveagled him from the service of your said subiect & caused him to drawe his affection & dewty from him) your said subiect hopinge of his recouery by his fathers good admonitions did not onlie give the said Lybell beinge vnder the hand writinge of the said Robert Rogers to the said Thomas Rogers his father not myndinge or entendinge to have compleyned any further of theise his misdemeenaors, But did allso quietlie parte with him & his service & suffred him to be placed else where at his fathers pleasure, And did also delyver to the said Thomas Rogers aswell the foresaid Indenture of Covenauntes wherin the said Robert Rogers stood bound to your said subiect to be his Apprentice & servant as aforesaid, And allso the foresaid fowre Bylls wherin the said Thomas Rogers stood bounden to your said subiect for the payment of the foresaid twenty powndes The said Thomas Rogers allowing to your said subiect fyve markes for the dyett of his said sonn Robert for fowre monethes & for other chardges your said subiect had layd owte for him, But soe yt is may yt please your most Excellent Maiestie That after such time as the said Robert Rogers was gone from the service of your said subiect And beinge placed with one Richard HolboroughRichard Holborough: uncle of Robert Rogers of Acton in the County aforesaid beinge his vnckle not above a myle distant from your subiectes dwellinge howse as aforesaid, And the said Robert Rogers seeinge his Lewd corses aforesaid tooke such good effecte, & that he escaped soe currantlie without any mannor of punishment or correction therfore. he estsoones in your subiectes absence did oftentymes privatelie repayre to your said subiectes dwelling howses in waldingfeild aforesaid, And there both with your said subiectes servantes & with others that were dwellinge & inhabitinge in the said howses the said Robert Rogers did deprave your said subiect & did publishe & declare his foresaid scandalous Lybell in great scorne and derision against your said subiect and his wife as aforesaid, whervppon your said subiecte beinge greatlie greived to see the vntowardnes of the said Robert Rogers whom your said subiect did intreate with much ‸love & care of his good all the time he was servant with your said subiecte, & therevppon your said subiecte wrote a lettre to him wishinge him not to come or frequent your subiectes howses, wherat the said Rogers not onlie would desiste & forbeare cominge at your said orators howse, but in great contempt would come in despight of your said subiect & beard him at his owne dores, And to showe his mallice further he the said Robert about the xxvjth daye of September in the sayd Sixte yeare of your said Maiesties yeare wrote a lettre to your said subiecte in nature of a lybell beinge open & not sealed & delyvered the same to one William Saunder of Acton aforesaid Taylor to bringe to your said subiecte whoe fyndinge not your said subiecte at home lefte the same at your said subiectes howse, The tenor of which lybell or scandalous lettre is as followeth The superscripcion beinge thus viz. To Paule Powle delyver this scrowle./ I cannot but much mervayle that this Longe vacacion should leave yow soe vacant of Clyentes or that your worshipps affayres in the Corte of Wardes & Kinges Benche, should be at soe lowe an ebb soe neere Terme your self beinge a man of soe large a profession that yow can fynd noe other way to exercise your little wittes then in framinge your lerned Epistle the which I knowe not to what end yow sent yf not to give others notice of the rare Wantes wherwith your self is endowed withall, And nowe to returne your self an aunswere of the Epistle above premised in aunswere therof lett these be sufficient to give yow notice, that having of your love some little experience I cannot say certenlie whither yt holdes yow by motions or minutes But when I have occacion to travell to Boxford, I Will enquire (your self knowes where) in what pryvie partes your self conteynes yt self, And concerninge your service had your worshipp byne Mayor of Monkes Eleigh yow cold not have had better service & attendance then was performed by my self vnto yow, And nowe by reason of my absence, your worshipp seeminge vtterly destitute of some compleat yowth to attend vppon your satten sute that I mought supplie your wantes heerin by another in my place nowe uterlie destitute as aforesaid, whoe lykewise may afford yow thother five markes, my best endeavors tend, your Actions towardes me I omytt at this time to reherse, And seeinge they are most lyke your self I leave them to your self to whom they are best knowne, And allthoughe yow professe great love and kyndnes to my father for old acqueyntance sake betwixt yow by reason of which profession yow made him the more tractable to yowr desires when time & place offred yow fytt oportunyty, yet sure I thinck your idle serious lettre sent to a Worshipfull gentleman whom I refuse to nominate to suche a etc. as your self hath degenerated him from that that which yow take him to be & refuseth any acqueyntance with such as your self, And where yow terme it to proceed of old acqueyntance sake, I rather thinck for the monyes sake, And therfore he is more beholdinge for his mony then your love & acqueyntance, And for your dealinges with him & the rest of my frendes expect to vnderstand, And further of any thinge that yow can either say or thincke of my vnckle I thincke him indifferent seeinge your duty cannot hurte him nor your favor grace him beinge a man of better esteeme then your self ever deserved, And further to proceed concerninge some vile hatefull & Lewd corses in your lettre specified which I dare not inferr vppon your self I cease at this instant to omyt, And for your companye I have yt in such heighe esteeme that I greatly desire wee may once more meete at the blewe bore without Algate where wee Will helth yt in spite of the fates allthough We make all split against & gage our gilt for my ostes securyty, Tho Trespasses in your lettre mencioned with thinterrogacion pointe I cannot fully resolve yow of, And concerning the displeasure of your frendes I thincke yow need not greatlie sett by for I knowe none your worshipp hath, And further as yow Terme him cursed that entertayne me into his service, I deeme him that shall light into such a service as yours borne to most disaster mishaps & crooked destynyes. And nowe to conclude in forewarninge me your ground I chardge yow from coming into any parte of the mansion howse of my inhabitacion or any of my ground at your worshipps perill by attemptinge the same, And thus with my Remembrance to my younge master vntill we meet at Algate afore premised I rest as yow shall fynd me Ro. Ro: September 27: 1608, yf your worshipp hath any more Epistles I pray lett me vnderstand therof, Nowe after your said subiect had received this Lybellinge lettre as aforesaid he vnderstood that not only this lettre; but allso the foresaid Lybellinge lettres and Lybells were published and often repeated and red over in the nowe dwellinge howse of the said William Coleman in great waldingfeild aforesaid with much laughter scorne and Reproache to your said subiecte & his wife, And the sayd William Coleman not therwith content but bearinge a most detestable hate as yt should seeme to your said subiect did in the said Sixte yeare of your said Maiesties Reigne & since publishe & delyver to dyvers of your Maiesties subiectes the contentes & scandalous matter specified & sett downe in the foresaid lybell and Lybellinge lettres to the disgrace & discreditt of your said Subiect tendinge to the evill example of other of your Maiesties Subiectes and contrary to the whollsome Lawes and Statutes of this your heighnes Realme, & to the breach of your heighnes peace and peaceable government, And further your said most Loyall and obedient subiect doth instance & enforme your Maiestie That the said william Coleman not heerwith content but of a most malicious and vntoward disposicion towardes your said subiect not satisfyinge himself with the publishinge broachinge and declaringe abroad of the foresaid Lybellinge lettres and Lybelles against your said Subiect with and amongest dyvers & sondry of your subiectes amongest whom he vseth to converse, But nowe of late most maliciouslie hath proceeded to newe plottinge & practisinge against your said Subiecte in this manner followinge That is to say, The said William Coleman well knowinge that there were sutes & controversies between your said Subiecte & one Phillip Goslyn of Groton in the Countie aforesaid yoman, & with one Iohn Spencer of Boxford in the County aforesaid promooter, he the said Coleman abowt the moneth of August in the seventh yeare of your maiesties Reigne & divers tymes sithence hath rydden over to the dwellinge howses of the said Goslyn & Spencer & with them did practice & combyne to bringe your said subiect in further shame slaunder & disgrace not only with the comon & inferior sorte of Subiectes of this your heignes Realme & Domynion, but allso with the Maiestrates therof, And to that end the said Coleman and Goslyn practiseth & plotteth with the said Spencer (beinge a most audacious & bold fellowe, & one given whollie to cosonage & cheeting of your Heighnes subiectes to promottinge, Barrettinge & settinge strife & dissention amongest his neighbours & other of your heighnes lovinge Subiectes, & one that is this instant in question in this your heighnes most honorable Corte of Starrchamber for manifest & open periurye & for divers & sondry oppressions & wronges done to your said Hignes Subiectes & for dyvers other most heynous abuses & misdemeanors) to make pen and delyver, And in truth about the moneth of IanuaryIanuary: 5 minims for nu in the said Seaventh yeare of your said heighnes Reigne did make & delyver a peticion in the names of the said Spencer Goslinge & Coleman against your said Subiect to the Right Worshipfull Sir William DanyellWilliam Danyell: William Daniel (d. 1610), JP for Suffolk, family from Over-Tabley, Cheshire. Knight one of your heighnes Iustices of the Common pleas & one of the Iustices of Assise for your heighnes Countie of Suffolk, And allso did make and contryve divers & sondry false & slanderous articles of sundry misdemeanors pretended to be done by your said Subiect against your Heighnes Subiectes and Lawes, Only to bringe your said Subiecte in publique & open infamy & disgrace amongest his Clyentes & other his goodes frendes in the Cuntry, And to that end the said Spencer in his owne name & in the names of the said Coleman and Goslinge did procure & obtayne a Reference of the said peticion from the said Sir William Danyell to Sir William Waldegrave William Waldegrave: William Waldegrave (1540–1613), of Smallbridge Hall, Suffolk, and Wormingford, Essex, JP for Suffolk from c 1564, MP for Suffolk, 1563, knighted 1576, sheriff of Suffolk and Norfolk in 1568-9, and knighted 1576 & Sir George Waldegrave Knightes & one Mr Iohn GurdonIohn Gurdon: John Gurdon (d. 1623), of Assington, Suffolk, JP for Suffolk, high sheriff of Suffolk Esquire Iustices of your heighnes peace for the Countie of Suffolk to examyne vppon the foresaid slaunderous articles all such witnesses as the said Spencer Goslyn and Coleman should produce before the said Iustices of peace to examyne the life & behavior of your said Subiect from his infancy hetherto to thend that if any misdemeanor might appeare in your said Subiect by relacion of my wytnes though never soe vntrue, & though an adversary to your said subiect & allso without oathe (for that the said Iustices had noe power to examyne wytnesses vppon oath) That then the said Iustices should declare the sayinges of such witnesses as should barelie say any thinge against your said Subiecte to the Iustices of Assise for the Countie of Suffolk, Where your said Subiect should be called in the open Assises in the face of the said County to aunswere to all manner of obiections that then and their should be laid against him at the promocion and instance of the said Spencer Coleman and Goslynge, Which their plottinges & practices is of purpose done by them against your said Subiect to disgrace him in the Cuntry where he dwell seeking therby your poore subiectes vtter vndoinge being an Attornye as aforesaid whose cheif meyntenaunce for his wife & children consistes vppon his credyt & honest endeavors & paynes That your said Subiect takes for his Clyentes their cawses, Whoe when they shall see & vnderstand your said subiect soe brought into open question by the said Spencer Goslyn & Coleman & by the publishinge of such Scandalous articles as they have most falslye & most maliciousie contryved & penned against your said Subiect (The ‸said Goslynge beinge knowne to be a most infamous person, a plotter of mischeifs a slaunderer of maiestiary a comon Barrator a styrrer vp & meyntener of Sutes & debates amongest dyvers of your heighnes lovinge Subiectes & a man that hath committed dyvers & sondry most heynous misdemeanors./ And for soe much as the foresaid Lybells & by Lybellinge lettres made & published by the said Rogers, Coleman & Saunders, And the foresaid misdemeanors plottinges & practises of the said Spencer Coleman and Goslyn doe tend to the disturbance of your Maiesties peace, And are directlie contrary and oppugnant to the wholsome Lawes and Statutes of this your heighnes Realme & domynions May it please your heighnes the premisses considered to graunt vnto your poore Subiect your heighnes most gracious Wrytes of Subpoena to be directed to the said Robert Rogers William Saunders William Coleman Phillip Goslyn and Iohn Spencer, Comaunding them & euery of them at at certen daye and vnder a certen payne therin to be lymitted personallie to be & appeare before your heighnes & the Lordes of your most honorable pryvy Councell in your heighnes Corte of Starr Chamber, then & there to aunswere the premisses and euery parte therof And further to stand to & abide such order punishmentes & further proceedinges for their said severall misdemeanors & offences as to your heighnes most honorable pryvie Councell in the said high Corte of Starr Chamber shall in their most honorable discrecions be thought fytt to stand with equitie & good Iustice. And your said subiect shall accordinge to his most bounden dewtie prey vnto allmightie god for your heighnes most happie & gracious Reigne longe to contynewe & Reigne over vs

div.p: These copes appear to have been used in boy bishop ceremonies. See a similar entry at Boxford in 1541–2 related to its own boy bishop. See

row.cell: Item payd ffor makyng ye stage yn the chorche & ffor nayls
x : only a remnant of d. remains

div.head: p 228 (6 May)
div.ab: A lettre to the high Sheriff of Suffolk, William Foorth, Iohn Gurdall, & (blank) Clopton Esquires: We do vnderstand by your lettre of the third of this instant of a purpose in the Towne of Hadley to make certaine Stage playes at this tyme of the Whitson holydaies next ensuinge; and thether to draw a Concourse of people out of the Country thereaboutes pretending heerein the benefit of the Towne; which purpose we do vtterly mislike, doubting what inconveniences may follow thereon especially at this tyme of scarcety when disordred people of the Comon sort wilbe apt to misdemeane themselues⹎ We do therefore require you straightly to prohibite the Officers and all others in the Towne of Hadley not to goe forward with the sayd playes, and to Cause the Stage prepared for them to be plucked downe; letting them know that they are to obey this our order as they will answere it at their perill. We thanck you for the Care you take to keepe the Country in good order. And so &c./

div.head: pp 268–9 (3 January) (Appointment of John Allen as Overseer of the Poor)
div.ab:
Item the said Iohn Allen dothe couenante that he shall not suffer any playes to be made within the guyldhall withowt consent of six of the cheef inhabitantes of the towne vnder their hand wryting And further that all suche plaies as shalbe made ther maye be ended in the daye time And also that if anye hurte or damage be made by the saide plaies or weddinges kept ther that then
the said Iohn Allen shall repaier and make the said houses in as good sorte as they are nowe, at his owne costes and charges In wittnes wherof theise be subscribed by the said inhabitantes and the said Iohn Allen the daye and yeere before named./

div.p: The Hadleigh guildhall (known today as 'The Hadleigh Town Hall and Guildhall Complex' is a fifteenth-century, timber-framed building sitting by the churchyard, facing the parish church of the Blessed Virgin Mary. The complex has three principal sections. The center section, constructed c 1451, is the Market Hall, a three-storey building 'with two shops built below.' To its left (as one faces the complex), constructed in 1433, is an attached two-storey structure now called the Long Room. It was described as 'one long house newly constructed called le markethows.' Its ground floor contained two almshouses, and its first floor was 'the former guildhall proper.' Behind the three-storey Market Hall, also dating from the mid-fifteenth century, is a detached hall, known today as the Guildhall (having replaced the Long Room in that capacity). It came to be used by Hadleigh's five religious guilds for their meetings and banquets. The feoffees' order makes clear that the town had been using the guildhall for weddings and the staging of plays that might run into the evening hours. On the Guildhall-Town Hall complex, see Pevsner, Suffolk, p 245; Andrews, Inventory, p 18; and Andrews and Springall, Hadleigh and the Alabaster Family, p 10. On the use of the guildhall and the area outside it for plays and other diversions, see Marjorie Keniston McIntosh, Poor Relief and Community in Hadleigh, Suffolk, 1547–1600 (Hatfield, Hertfordshire, 2013), 12-13.

div.head: pp [1]-[2] (6 February)
div.ab: To my singular honest Stationer, Mr. Robert Mylbourne, at his shop in decimo sexto, by the fourth doore of Pauls.

As you are a true Booke-seller, you must approue your selfe a true Booke- restorer: and therfore by hooke or by crooke, see that you send backe my Book. And yet not my Booke. For it was but a borrowed Booke, for which my promise and credit lye in mortage to the Author, the Schoolmaster of Hadley, who with some difficulty lent it me, hauing no other coppy of this English Lesson which he prepared for a By-exercise for his schollars at the last Carneual. He told me that hee huddled it vp in hast, and that it being onely an essay of his owne faculty, and of the actiuity of his tenderlings, he was loath it should come vnder
any other eye, then of those Parents and domestique friends who fauourably beheld it, when it was represented by the children. And therefore, I must be, and am tender of suffering it to wander I know not whither, by the out let of your friends hand: whom as I know not, so I cannot challenge of any trust; but require restitution of you, as the Author doth of me. So, expecting without delay, the return of this bird into the cage, I end with a threat, that if you faile, you must looke to haue this Comedy turned into a Tragedy, and, for detaining this booke, to haue your name set on the backside of my booke. Whereto I adde yet a deeper curse, that next time you meet with good fellowes in Epping Forrest, you may not be so happy, as to feed them with nuts in stead of money.

ab.hi: Yours as you shall deserue the en-

div.ab: From Hadley aforesaid
The aforesaid Stationers answer.

Louing, Challenging, Threatening friend, E. W. I pray you extend your loue so farre to your friend, and your friends friend, as to thinke that neither the first will defraud you of your borrowed Booke, nor the second expose the Author to any inconuenience. The truth is, my friend, vpon the sight of this Morall, Scholasticall, Theatricall Treatise, protested that the Author should receiue much right in being thus wronged; and vpon sufficient bond vndertooke to saue me harmelesse if I made it more publique than euer was intended. And withall hee armed me with a legall defence, that, if I restored tenne fold for the principall, the Author (notwithstanding his modesty) could frame no iust quarrell against me or you at the barre of iustice
or reputation. Accordingly he incouraged me (if Master Schoolmaster of Hadley should schoole you for promise-breach) to stop his mouth with a dozen of chickens hatcht vnder his owne henne.
I pray you therefore instead of his owne single written Coppy, sfiesfie: for satisfie him with this packet of his owne mettall stamped and multiplied by the Printers Alchimy.

The worst I feare, is, that hee will complaine to Apollo of me that I haue proclaimed abroad his priuate Shreuing. For which I haue a defence from the Authors owne penne, that Apollos solemne visitation begins with Proclamation. Act. I. Scen. vltima. And I trow Proclamations are intended to flye abroad in print. So in hope that I shall receiue, if not thanks, yet pardon from him. I rather take, then begge, leaue to remaine still
London, April 25. 1627. From the small ve of my shop, where the South winde blowes into Pauls.

Apollo Shrouing.
Composed for the Schollars of
the Free-Schoole of Hadleigh in Suf
folke. And acted by them on Shroue-
tuesday, being the 6. of
February, 1626.
The Introduction.
Dramatis Personæ.

row.cell: Thuriger the Sexton of Apolloes Temple.
Geron an old man, his mournfull father.
Siren a sea nimph, messenger from Queene Hedone.
Captaine Complement a teacher of gestures and fashions.
Mistrisse Indulgence Gingle, a cog Mother.
Iohn Gingle her sonne a disciple of Captaine Compliments.
Iugge Rubbish maid-seruant to Mistrisse Gingle.

div.p: According to Bentley, the play was first performed by students in the schoolroom of Hadleigh School. The boys must have been a talented lot. Bentley notes that Joseph Beaumont, who played two roles and delivered the Epilogue, was a friend of Crashaw, and the author of Psyche, or Love's Mystery. John Kidby, another of the actors, would later have a part in Peter Haustead's Rival Friends at Cambridge. Bentley praises the play as 'more amusing than one might expect,' its quality suggesting that 'there may have been more dramatic talent in Caroline schools than is generally thought' (Jacobean and Caroline Stage, vol 4, pp 538–9). He cites with caution the argument of the play's first editor that the play is 'a general imitation of [Ben Jonson's] Cynthia's Revels' (p 539); see Rhoads (ed), Wm. Hawkins' Apollo Shroving, pp 84–70). According to Jones, Hadleigh Through the Ages, p 57, a few lines of this play 'may perhaps have been in the mind of John Milton writing Paradise Lost forty years later. Jones, p 57, observes that Corolla Varia 'contains Latin poems recited by [students of] the school before some members of that university who had come to Hadleigh to escape the plague at Cambridge in 1630.'

div.p: The patron on f 5 whose bearward was paid at the order of Sir John Howard was Thomas Stanley (1433–1504), second Baron Stanley from 20 February 1458/9, with residences at Greenhalgh Castle, Lancashire, and at other Lancashire places. This entry was written after the original account in the top margin in a different hand.

div.p: The lord of Clarence (f 20) who was owed 20s was George Plantagenet (1449–77/8), third duke of Clarence from 1461, with residence at Warwick Castle.

Edward Plantagenet (28 April 1442-9 April 1483), son of Richard Plantagenet, Duke of York, and Cecily Neville, was Edward IV, King of England 1461-70 (when deposed), then restored as king from 1471 until his death in 1483. See P&P.
The previous payment was at Westminster, and to the king's minstrels, so this event probably occurred in London.

A number of entries in the accounts (ff 46v, 50v–51v, 52v, 64v, 67v, 82, 132v, 135, 137, 138–8v) are payments for 'baytynge' during Sir John Howard's travels. In this context, the word appears simply to mean the providing of food and drink for his horses, as on f 132v a payment for baiting his horse.
On f 48, Howard reimbursed Sir William Warner for money laid out at tennis.

body.head: Suffolk, Howard of Stoke-by-Nayland and Framlingham 1463/4 SUHW05

Item for Corde for the taberettes taberetes

div.p: John de la Pole (f 65; 1442–92), second duke of Suffolk from 1463, with residence at Wingfield, Suffolk.

The hockpot (f 65) was the container that in many communities held the proceeds from a post-Easter game, a mock battle, in which the women of the parish 'captured' the men with ropes, pulling their captives to them and granting their release when the men had paid a contribution to the parish fund. This uniquely English game is generally thought to dramatize what had originally been the celebration of an English defeat of, and liberation from, the rule of the Danish king Hardicnute in 1041, or a similar battlefield event (Joseph Strutt, The Sports and Pastimes of the People of England (London, 1903), 274–5).
