div.p: The lord of Warwick, whose six minstrels were rewarded on f 65v, was Richard Neville (1428–71), sixteenth earl of Warwick from 3 January 1448/9, with residences at Middleham and Sheriff Hutton, Yorkshire, North Riding.

Edward Plantagenet (28 April 1442-9 April 1483), son of Richard Plantagenet, Duke of York, and Cecily Neville, was Edward IV, King of England 1461-70 (when deposed), then restored as king from 1471 until his death in 1483. See P&P.
The lord of Norfolk whose trumpeters were also rewarded on f 65v was Sir John de Mowbray (1444–1475/6), fourth duke of Norfolk from 1461, with residence at Framlingham Castle, Suffolk. See P&P
The entries on ff 72v, 73 are written in Howard's hand.
The lord of Oxford, whose minstrel was rewarded on f 83, was John de Vere (1442–1512/13), thirteenth earl of Oxford from 26 January 1461/2, with residence at Hedingham Castle, Essex.
The lord of St John, whose men were rewarded on f 92, was John Saint John de St John (1426–88), esquire, who had his residence at Bletsoe Castle, Bledsoe, Bedfordshire, and lands in Essex.
All three payments were apparently made at Stoke.

div.p: According to Botfield, the payments on p 483 to performers occurred on f 26 of the original manuscript. Made on 1 January 1464/5, the payments likely occurred at Reading when Howard was there, attending on the king.
According to Botfield, the payment on p 485 occurs on f 26v of a book of Howard's accounts now lost.
According to Botfield, the payment on p 508 occurs on f 44v of a book of Howard's accounts now lost.

A hockpot (pp 510–11) was the container that held the proceeds from a post- Easter mimetic game in which women 'captured' men with ropes, pulling their captives to them. The men earned their freedom by making a contribution to the parish fund. This uniquely English game is generally thought to dramatize what had originally been a celebration of the English defeat of, and liberation from, the rule of Hardicnut in 1041, or of a similar event (Strutt and Cox, Sports and Pastimes, pp 274–5).

According to Botfield, the payment occurs on f 45 of a book of Howard's accounts now lost. On f 45 of Add. MS 46349 there is an 'Item delivred to the wyves in party off payment,' but there is no indication of what the payment was for.
According to Botfield, the payment on p 511 occurs on f 45v of a book of Howard's accounts now lost.

Thomas Moleyns was a senior member of Howard's household, entrusted with financial and business matters of many kinds, including reimbursements, payments of wages, collections of rents, purchasing in London and elsewhere, delivery of a warrant to the king's man, and more, amply recorded in the Howard accounts. On 26 August 1463 he received payment for 24 'tawyd' (dressed) sheep skins (f 47). On 5 May 1464 Howard advanced him 40s to purchase fish for the household at Manningtree (f 66). Two days late, the lord reimbursed him for having taken wages to a member of the household (66v). On 11 April 1466 he received several reimbursements for travelling to London on his lord's behalf (travel and food for himself and his companion, the copying of a letter, and entertaining of a king's man, and so on) (f 111v). Acting as a collector, Moleyns delivered £6 to Howard on 1 January 1466/7 (f 131). On 11 June 1467 acting on behalf of Howard, Moleyns disbursed parcels of money totalling £6 for the crew of Howard's ship, The Edward, preparatory to a voyage to Calais (f 140). Other of Moleyns' important sevices to Howard are recorded on ff 86, 138v, 141, 148, and 150v.

div.p: Lord Wenlock, whose taboret was rewarded on f 125, was John Lord Wenloke (c 1400/4–71), first Baron Wenloke, with seat at Someries Castle, Luton, Bedfordshire. He was slain at the battle of Tewksbury. The entries on f 125 are written in Howard's hand.

Concerning the clerks of St Nicholas who were rewarded on f 130, boy bishops were elected on St Nicholas Day (6 December), and (sometimes known as the clerks of St Nicholas) customarily processed, singing, before the great and the good, collecting contributions for their performance.

div.p: In late spring 1481 (f 4v, col 2), after negotiations between England and Scotland to establish a peace treaty had failed and the Scots had increased their raiding and pillaging of the English borderlands, Edward IV ordered a military campaign against the Scots, led by Richard, duke of Gloucester (by land) in concert with the forces of Sir John Howard (by sea). Howard took command of a fleet of eight ships carrying 3,000 men and set out for the Firth of Forth, where he successfully engaged and defeated the unprepared local Scots. The remaining part of Howard's contribution to the campaign involved often unsuccessful raiding forays along the Scottish coast before his sixteen-week commission came to an end (see Anne Crawford, Yorkist Lord: John Howard, Duke of Norfolk, c. 1425-1486 (London, 2010), 91–4).

John Luter, who is named on f 5v, col 2, appears as the first name in a list of nine men under the heading 'Sencler.' This same list of nine men occurs in the entry on f 20 below, where it says that they were impressed by John Sencler (Sinclair?), gentleman, into the Duke's forces.

div.head: f 102 (10 December)
div.ab: and the same day my lord toke thomas seynclow his costes in to Flandres x s. and v crownys and v s. that tharper toke hym

row.cell: Item I toke to tomas Herperd
Item for þe children of the chapel þe xxj yere of þe king & on christemes day for þer patins & poyntes
Item þe xxvj day of December my Lord toke þe plaiers of kokesaleKokesale: Coggeshall, Essex
Item to þe mynstrel was here on/ christemes day
Item to þe plaiers of HadleyHadley: Hadleigh, Suffolkand þe olde man and ij children
Item to the trompetȝ for a rewarde

div.p: On f 42, these two payments, plus one for his drink, were made to John Sherle, armourer. The single sum of xxvij s. viij d. is the total for both entries concerning Sherle's work on banners and standards.

On f 91v, the lord of Gloucester whose trumpets were being paid was Richard Plantagenet (1452–1485), lord protector from 1483, third duke of Gloucester from 1 November 1461, and king of England from 1483.

The lady Norfolk (f 92) whose minstrels were paid was Elizabeth (Talbot) Mowbray (c 1435-1507), dowager duchess of Norfolk, widow of John de Mowbray (1444-1475/6), fourth Duke of Norfolk, with residence (among other places) at Framlingham Castle, Suffolk.

The lord of Buckingham (f 94v) whose minstrels were paid was Henry Stafford (1455–83), second duke of Buckingham from 1460, with residences at Penshurst, Kent and Stafford Castle, Staffordshire. He was beheaded.

On f 105, concerning the children of the chapel whose patins and points were paid for by Howard on f 105, Collier claims that Howard kept four to six children (the number varied) for his chapel at Stoke, where the records show that he paid for their services, livery, sustenance, and instruction. He retained one 'Gorum, master of the children of St Anthony' (Household Books, p xxii–xxiii; see f 116). Both the mansion at Stoke and the Lord's Chapel had organs and music books, so the children likely performed in both religious and festive settings.

body.head: Suffolk, Howard of Stoke-by-Nayland and Framlingham 1481/2 SUHW02

The xv day of feuerer my lord boght of (blank) cawwodde a singer of powles a contrepoint of verdyrs contenyng In breede iiij yerdes & demi And In lengeth v yerdes & demi
þat is iij s. & iiij d. a yerde

div.ab: Item toone cauwode & þe brotheierbrotheier: for botheier(?); ie, boat-hire xx d.

div.p: Concerning the Children of the Chapel who received livery on f 108, and musical books on f 116, see the endnote to the entry on f 105.
On f 108, Henry Bourchier (c 1408–83) was fourteenth earl of Essex from 30 June 1461, with residence in Little Easton, Essex, and lands in Suffolk and five other counties.

div.p: Howard, who gave a reward to the maidens of Colchester on f 136, also gave 4d to 'the maydens' at Newgate on 14 May (f 136v). Although not demonstrably given for entertaining him, this payment at Newgate is similar to neighbouring payments made to women in connection with performances.
On f 144v, Richard Plantagenet (1452–85) was lord protector from 1483, third duke of Gloucester from 1 November 1461, and king of England from 1483.

body.head: Suffolk, Howard of Stoke-by-Nayland and Framlingham 1482 SUHW03

Item the same day my lord made couenaunte with william wastell of london harper that he shall have the sone of Iohn Colet of ofof of: dittography colchester harper for a yere to teche hym hymhym hym: dittography to harpe and toWilliam Wastell harper for a chylde synge for þe whiche techynge my lord shall geve hym xiij s. iiij d. & a gown whereof my lord toke hym in ernest vj s. viij d.
and at þe ende of þe yere he shall have þe remenaunt and is gown and he is bound to endentur to my lord to performe this covenauntes before wreten
ItemPleyersPleyers: followed by left pointing brace encompassing both entries on s Crystemas day my lord gaff to iiij pleyers of my lord of gloucestres

div.p: The payment on f 3 for mending the fool's coast occurred at Stoke by Nayland. Payments on ff 3–3v make clear that on 2 and 3 August Howard was enroute to London, but that Lady Howard was at Stoke. In the entry immediately preceding the payment for the fool's coat, Lady Howard paid a man from Kelsale 'for bryngyng of a buk to Stoke' (Collier, Household Books, p 286).
On f 31v the patron, Richard Plantagenet (1452–1485), was lord protector from 1483, third duke of Gloucester from 1 November 1461, and king of England from 1483.

div.head: f 34v (15 January)
div.ab: Item paid to bolocke þat he paid to þe waytes xx d.

row.cell: Item to Thomas stowe the mynstrell of hadleyth þe same day

div.p: The patron identified as master woodes on ff 33v–4 is Sir John Wood (d. 1484), speaker of the House from between 21 January and 18 February 1482/3. He was knighted after parliament ended on 18 February 1482/3 and so was not yet a knight when called Mr Woodes in the Howard account book. His residences were Ryvers Hall, Sussex and East Molesey Manor in Surrey, near Kingston.

body.head: Suffolk, Howard of Stoke-by-Nayland and Framlingham 1483 SUHW03

div.head: f 105v (15 October)
div.ab: ItemW to a mynstrell xx d.

row.cell: Item to the taberett for his taber

div.p: Concerning the payments to harpers on f 90, Howard arrived in Norwich on 19 August. On that same day, he made a series of payments, including those to the harpers.

Entries on ff 90v and 91 further confirm that Howard was continuing to progress from town to town. On 22 August (f 90v) he paid performers in Durham and later that same day in Thetford. About 10 entries later, the date given in the records is Sunday, 24 August. On that same day (f 91) the records indicate that his journey had taken him to Bury St Edmunds. Three entries later, on Sunday 24 August, the prior of Thetford 'paid for my Lord at Bury, for his offering ther, followed by some further payments for offerings and alms at Bury. Then the Prior paid Buckingham's trumpet 'at the said town [Bury]'. Four entries later he gave 20s 'to the offecerys of the Abbey of Bury.' Thus the payment on f 91 was made at Bury, not Thetford.
The trumpets paid on f 91 were those of Henry Stafford (1455–1483), second duke of Buckingham from 1460, with residences at Penshurst, Kent, and Stafford Castle, Stafordshire.

The earl of Kent whose minstrel received a reward on f 91 was Edmund Grey (1416–1490), eleventh earl of Kent from 30 May 1465, with residences at Wrest Park, Bedfordshire, and Ruthin Castle, Denbighshire.

Of possible relevance to the payment made to Robin Hood for his arrows on f 100, on 3 October one John a Godsalfe and John Skelton (likely the poet and playwright then in the duke's household) both received money from the accountant to purchase their livery gowns (f 101).

body.head: Suffolk, Howard of Stoke-by-Nayland and Framlingham 1526–7 SUHW04

div.p: 'my lord{es} of Essex' (f 41) refers to Sir John de Vere (1482-1539/40), knight, fifteenth earl of Oxford (1526–40), of Colne and Castle Hedingham, Essex. He became fifteenth earl when his second cousin, John de Vere (1499–1526), fourteenth earl of Oxford, died on 14 July 1526.

div.p: The constitution shows the connection between the procession and the pageants, some of which (the Ship Pageant, for example) clearly had dramatic content. The striking feature of the list giving the order of companies (and some pageants) in the procession is that the references to saints, in red ink beside bracketed companies, have been scratched out (though they remain readable under ultraviolet). The only pageants permitted to remain from those in red were the dolphin and the ship, perhaps because Ipswich was so important a port.

div.p: The list of pageants is undated, but the same leaf includes a list of English kings from Eldred to Henry VI. Except for Henry VI, that list gives the number of years that each king reigned. Based on that list of kings, Wasson tentatively dates the list of pageants as c 1437, midway through the reign of Henry VI (Plays and Players, p 171). The list does certainly seem to be from the time of Henry VI.

div.head: f 8v (29 August) (General court)
div.ab: Ad hanc Curiam Balliui & tota Communitas concesserunt Thome Denys Iohanni Caldewell Willelmo Rydout & Iohanni Causton totum proficium illius tenementi vocatum le Merssh cum domibus edificijs terris arabilibus pratis pascuis pasturis maresscis & omnibus Alijs suis pertinentibus A festo sancti Michaelis Archangeli vltimo preterito ante datam presencem vsque ad finem & terminum trium Annorum proxime sequentium complendorum Ad Sustentacionem & reparacionem de lez pagentis Gilde Corporis Christi predicte ville Gippewici

div.head: f 8v (29 August) (General court)
div.ab: At this court, the bailiffs and the whole commonalty granted to Thomas Denys, John Caldewell, William Rydout and John Causton all the profit of that tenement called the Merssh along with its houses, buildings, arable lands, grazing meadows, marshes, and all its other appurtenances from Michaelmas last past before the present date until the end and term of the three years next following to be completed for sustenance and maintenance of the the pageants of the guild of Corpus Christi of the aforesaid town of Ipswich.

div.head: f 9 (8 April) (General court)
div.ab: Ad eandem Curiam Iohannes Causton admissus est Burgensis intrinsecus et habet exitus Iohannem Henricum Thomam & Robertum & Iuratus est sub condicione quod idem Iohannes Causton per vij Annos proxime sequentes post datam presentis Curie diligenterBurgensis condicionaliter fideliter & Assidue secundum suum posse attendet ministrabitministrabit: b possibly written over r & custodiet ornamenta quecumque de lez pagentes Gilde Corporis Christi ac ordinabit & preuidebit circa reparacionem de lez pagentes & pro factura de lez Stages pro lusoribus tam de villa quam extra vna cum Thoma Bysshop Clerico Communi dicte ville Gippewici per superuisionem Balliuorum eiusdem ville qui pro tempore fuerint capiendo omnes & singulas expensas tam de pro reparacione de lez pagentes quam pro Conduccione Arraiamentorum vestimentorum & aliorum necessariorum que ad dicta Lez pagentes fuerint necessaria de firmarijs communis Marisci & prati portmanorum prout dictis Balliuis necesse videatur & oportunum quam diu &c.

Et ad eandem Curiam ordinatum est & concordatum per predictos Balliuos & Burgenses quod firmarij communis marisci ac prati portmanorum eiusdem ville qui pro tempore erunt Annuatim soluent vel solui facient Iohanni Caldwell pro expensis factis circa predictos lez pagentz Gilde corporis christi xl s. quousque expense predicte prefato Iohanni Caldewell aut eius certo attornato plenarie fuerint solute &c.

div.head: f 9 (8 April) (General court)
div.ab: At the same court, John Causton was admitted as a resident burgess and he has issue (namely) John, Henry, Thomas, and Robert, and he was sworn under the condition that the same John Causton shall for the seven years next following after the date of the present court diligentlyBurgess conditionally faithfully and assiduously according to his ability attend, administer, and guard any and all of the accoutrements of the pageants of the guild of Corpus Christi and arrange and make provision for the repair of the pageants and for the making of the stages for the players both from the town and from outside together with Thomas Bysshop, the common clerk of the said town of Ipswich by the supervision of the bailiffs of same town, who exist at the time, receiving all and every the expenses both for the repair of the pageants and for the hire of equipment, clothing, and other necessities which will be necessary for the said pageants from the tenants of the common marsh and the citizens' meadow just as appears necessary and opportune as long as, etc.

And at the same court it was ordained and agreed by the aforesaid bailiffs and burgesses that the tenants of the common marsh and of the citizens' meadow of the same town who exist for the time being shall pay annually or cause to be paid to John Caldwell for expenses made regarding the aforesaid pageants of the Guild of Corpus Christi 50s until the the aforesaid expenses are fully paid to the aforesaid John Caldewell or his assured attorney, etc.

div.p: A summary of this order has been written in the left margin in a later hand.

div.head: f 29 (8 May) (Ordinance)
div.ab: Et concessum est quod si lusores siue ffistyllatores veniuerint ad prandium quod tunc stipendium eorum erit collectum ad prandium

div.head: f 29 (8 May) (Ordinance)
div.ab: And it was granted that if players or pipers come to the dinner that then their stipend will be paid at the dinner.

div.head: mb 1 (4 October)
div.ab:
Et aco'aco': left edge of membrane missing; likely for Ordinacio ordinatum est quod omnes barbitonsores huius ville commorantes ibidem in festo Corporis Christi erunt adminicularieadminicularie: for adminicularij cum
tabernaculo Sancti Thome martyris transiente processionaliter prout consuetudinem ex Antiqua vsitati sint & inter se eligunt eligunt: for eligent ? ij prepositos eiusdem Artis ad faciendum etc.

div.head: mb 1 (4 October) (Ordinance)
div.ab: AndOrdinance it was ordained that all the barbers of this town who live there, will be bearers on the feast of Corpus Christi when the tabernacle of St Thomas the martyr passes by in procession, just as they have practiced the custom from ancient times, and they will choose amongst themselves two officials of the same art to do (this), etc.

div.head: pp 56–7 (17 August)
div.ab: Et ordinatum est quod quilibet Burgensis qui non soluit denarios pro corpore christi quodquod: for deletion soluerit denarios predictos ante dominicam ante festum Natiuitatis beate Marie proximum futurum sinautem quod sint ad proximam Curiam generalem ad dicendum si quid pro eis habeant ad dicendum sciant quare non disgradentur de Burgensia

Et concessum est Willielmo pernell in recompensacionem illius monete que sibi debenturdebentur: for debetur pro lez pagent videlicit illos denarios quosillos denarios quos: for illi denarij qui sunt in manibus Burgensium non solutossolutos: for soluti pro prandio
Et ordinauerunt quod quilibet Burgensis soluet annuatim Gilde Corpori Christi viij d. & non habebunt prandium
Et eligerunt Willelmum Pernell & Iohannem Balhed ad custodiendum omnia vtencilia & ornamenta Corporis Christi decetero

div.head: pp 56–7 (17 August)
div.ab: And it was ordered that any burgess who has not paid money for Corpus Christi will have paid the aforesaid money before the Sunday before the feast of the nativity of blessed Mary next to come, if not, that they be at the next general court to say whether they have anything to say for them(selves), to say they know why they should not be demoted from the burgessy.
And it was granted William Pernell as repayment of that money which is owed to him for the pagent, that is to say, that money which is in the hands of the burgesses (and) was not paid for the dinner.
And it was ordered that each burgess shall pay 7d annually to the guild of Corpus Christi and that they will not hold the dinner
And they chose William Pernell and John Balhed to guard all the tools and ornaments of Corpus Christi from henceforth

div.head: p 116 (26 April)
div.ab: Ad hanc Curiam eligerunt Iohannem Regner InburgensiamInburgensiam: for in burgensiam Intrincecam sub ista tamen Condicione quod decetero erit commorans & residens infra villam Gippiwici & scilicet erit auxiliator in omnibus pro le pagent de Corpore Christi secundum suum Ingenium in faciendo & emendando librum Corporis Christi & nichill habet extra & Iuratus est

Ad hanc Curiam Nicholaus Baker Iohannes hamond Edmundus Smyth Rogerus Mascall Thomas Halle Willelmus Lunt Iohannes Goche & Thomas Stubbe disgradati sunt de Burgensiis suis nisi venerint citra proximam Curiam &c ad dicendum si quid pro eis habeant aut dicere sciant quare non perderent libertatem suam Burgensie pro eo quod nolunt soluere ad sustentacionem Gilde Corporis Christi secundum ordinacionem & consuetudinem ville Gippiwici prout Iurati erant &c

Ad hanc Curiam eleg eligerunt Gardianos Gilde Corporis Christi videlicet Vincentium fferyngton Johannem Keche Thomam Phelyps & Robertum Halle Sherman pro anno Sequenti & quod Custodiant prandium prout prius Solebant aliquo actu prius in contrario facto InnichillInnichill: for in nichill obstanti & quod quilibet Burgensis Soluat pro prandio xvj d.
Ad eandem Curiam concesserunt pro sustentacione le pagent talem Summam de artificibus prout habuerunt proximo anno preterito

div.head: p 116 (26 April)
div.ab: At this court they elected John Regner to the civic burgessy, but under this condition: that from henceforth he will remain and reside in the town of Ipswich and, of course, that he will be a helper in all matters for the pageant of Corpus Christi according to his ability in making and correcting the book of Corpus Christi, and he will have nothing besides (these obligations). And he was sworn.

At this court, Nicholas Baker, John Hamond, Edmund Smyth, Roger Mascall, Thomas Halle, William Lunt, John Goche, and Thomas Stubbe have been demoted from their burgessies unless they come before the next court, etc, to say whether they have anything (to say) for them(selves), to say they know why they should not lose their liberty of the burgessy because they did not wish to play for the sustenance of the guild of Corpus Christi according to the regulation and custom of the town Ipswich as they had been sworn, etc.

At this court they elected the wardens of the guild of Corpus Christi, namely, Vincent Feryngton, John Keche, Thomas Phelyps and Robert Halle, sherman, for the following year and they (ordered) that they shall keep the dinner as they were formerly accustomed to–any act made earlier to the contrary notwithstanding– and that each burgess shall pay 16d for the dinner.
At the same court they granted for the maintenance of the pageant the same sum for the craftsmen as they had last year.

div.head: p 85 (8 May)
div.ab: At this court the bailiffs, townsmen, and the whole community granted that they shall pay for the maintenance of the Corpus Christi pagent just as they paid last year passed to be levied from the guilds of the same town, namely £3 11s etc.

From St George, 6s 8d; from St John, 5s; from St Thomas, 4s; from St Giles, 4s; from the carpenters, 5s; from the weavers, 3s; from the fullers, 5s; from the shoemakers, 6s; from the fishmongers, 3s; from the butchers, 5s; from the skinners, 3s; from the dyers, 3s 4d; from the mercers, 6s 8d; from the merchants, 8s; from the bakers, 3s 4d.
In total, £3 11s 6d

div.p: The hand specifying the sum total at the end of the first paragraph is the same as the one giving the detailed account of each guild's payment and the sum total in the second transcribed here. The two paragraphs are separated by two other paragraphs in the original hand which record other decisions taken at the session.

div.head: p 434 (24 April) (Ordinance)
div.ab: Ordinatum est quod decetero ludus siue le Pagent qui a multo tempore vsitabatur in die Corporis Christi & olim ad aliquod tempus non vsiebaturvsiebatur: for vsitabatur (?)quid per nobliyem modo concordatum est quod decetero inperpetuum tenebitur & custodiatur. Et ad supportandum illud quidam artifex ad illum convenient'convenient': for conveniens habebit annuatim pro termino certo .xl s. quod debet leuari ob formaforma: initially written foma; r written in afterwards so that it partially obscures o sequenti videlicet de quoque portmanno xvj d. & quoque xxiiijr xxiiijr: for xxiiijr s. viij d. que attingit ad xxxij s. & Residuum videlicet viij s. leuandi de residuis inhabitandisinhabitandis: for inhabitantibus sivibus xxiiijr

Insuper ordinatum quod nullus Balliuus pro suo tempore non impediet nec aliquid facietnullus … faciet: double negative to be disregarded in translation sic quod ludus siue le pagent auantdit non teneatur in dicto die Corporis Christi nisi sit per Curiam de portmanmote siue aliquod aliud speciale Sub pena utriusque Balliui x li. ad opus Gilde predicte
Thomas Baldry & William Ropkyn Balliui nominauerunt Robertum Godwyn & Ricardum Leneacre ad Colligendum pecunias pour le pagent in die Corporis Christi

div.head: p 434 (24 April) (Ordinance)
div.ab: ⸿ It has been determined that from henceforth the play or 'the pageant' which for a long time was performed on Corpus Christi day and sometimes was not performed at any time [anything by noble] now it has been agreed that from henceforth in perpetuity it will be observed and maintained. And to support that, a certain craftsman appropriate for that (purpose) will have 40s annually for a fixed term, which ought to be levied in the following manner, namely 16d from each councillor, and also 24s 8d which amounts to 32s, and the rest, that is 8s, is to be levied from [remaining inhabitants] twenty-four citizens.

Moreover, it was ordained that no baillif during his time (in office) shall impede or do anything so that the play or 'the aforesaid pageant' not be held on the said Corpus Christi day unless it be by portmanmoot court or some other special thing under penalty of £40 of each baillif for the use of the aforesaid guild.
Thomas Baldry and William Ropkyn, bailiffs, nominated Robert Godwyn and Richard Leneacre to collect money for the pagent on Corpus Christi day.

div.p: The first sentence of the first paragraph is poorly formed, having two governing clauses: 'Ordinatum est quod' and 'concordatum est quod'; rather than choose between the two, a literal translation has been given.

div.head: p 498 (8 April)
div.ab: They nominated Thomas Cady and Henry Stannard to collect 40s for the play on Corpus Christi day.

div.ab: and also he shall find various players as many sleeves and armrings for as many men each year for the same, 26s
all ornaments for the same game (or play) necessary for the term of twelve years keep at the

div.p: More than half of the page, on the left side, is missing. The translation is therefore incomplete and very tentative. It is impossible to know if the 'lusores' of this fragmentary entry are connected with the Corpus Christi play of the order that follows. Nathaniel Bacon summarizes the order as saying 'Granted to John Stangilts, 20s 8d yerely for 12 yeres, to finde the stageing for Corp' Chr'i play. And to John Parnell, 33s 4d, to find the ornaments during suche time, and collectors named of assessments for the play'(Annalls of Ipswiche, p 177).

All the inhabitants and occupations of the city are ordered to attend and they shall have their tentspenalty at the feast of Corpus Christi next to come under penalty of 6s 8d for each of them, etc, and they shall preserve the order of the procession just as is found in the book of constitutions.

Et Robertus Bird xij d. Et Michaelis Wright vj s. viij d. Et Iohannes Barbour xx d. Et Willelmus Cuttynge xx d. Et Thomas Miles xx d. Et Ricardus Spynk xij d. Et Iohannes Peeck xij d. Et quod prandium vocatum xx: likely for deletion Corpus Christi Dyner pro anno sequenti similiter dimittitur et differratur et quod quilibet burgensis soluet pro predicto anno sequenti v s. Sufficiencia presbit' inventa erit pro eodem anno ad selebrandum missam pro . animabus fratrum et sororum burgensium predicte ville illius viij d. &c. vel aliter nichil

div.head: p 330 (21 April)
div.ab: At this court it was agreed by the aforesaid burgesses that the pastime called the Corpus Christi play is cancelled for the following year and will not be played and that the meal called the Corpus Christi dinner is likewise cancelled and will be put off and that each burgess shall pay for the aforesaid following year 5s. A sufficient amount for the priest/s will be found for that year for celebrating the mass for the souls of the brothers and sisters of the burgesses of that aforesaid town 8d etc, or otherwise nothing.

div.head: p 186 (24 January)
div.ab: Corpus Christi pageant and dinner againe laid aside.

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 185 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 24 January.

div.head: p 188 (5 June)
div.ab: Corpus Christi play and dinner laide aside againe.
All the Utensiles belonging to Corpus Christi Guild shall be entred into a booke, to be kept safe by Iohn Butler to the use of the Guild

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 188 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 5 June.

A subsequent order, also on p 188, directs that the guild's many utensils (spoons, dishes, and so on) be kept safe. A connection between the play and the dinner (if there was any) is not clearly indicated in the records. Corpus Christi orders by the guild do often mention the play and dinner together in the same order, and the guild often pays for the building of scaffolds as part of guild feasts, which could indicate that the Corpus Christi play was indoors and was, therefore, intended for a small, privileged audience of burgesses and their wives as part of the feast (making the utensils a useful bit of evidence). But to take those considerations as fact would be to go beyond the evidence.

div.ab: ⸿ At this court they selected Robert Cobat and John Petman as wardens of the guild of Corpus Christi for the following year.

⸿ At this court they selected William Nottingham and Richard Humfrey as masters of pageant of the ship for the following year and it was agreed that they shall have the ship prepared on pain of forfeiture of £10.
⸿ At this court, it was agreed that the play called the Corpus Christi play shall be deferred for this year and shall not be played nor held.
⸿ At this court it was decided that each of the twenty-four shall have a robe with a cape (or cap) from Murrey dyed before the feast of Corpus Christi on pain of forfeiture.

div.ab: At this court they elected Thomas Bloise and John Petman, wardens of Corpus Christi for the near next to come and (it was decided) that the repast called 'the Corpus Christ dinner' is kept and held and that the play called 'the Corpus Christi play' is not played but shall be deferred.

div.head: mb [8] (29 September–29 September)(Payments)
div.ab: To Master brandon the Kynges Iugler

row.cell: Item payd to Master brandond the Kynges Iugler for hys Reward

div.ab: Mynstrelles pleyers & berewardes

row.cell: Item to the erle of Darbys pleyers
Item to the dewke off Northfolkes mynstrelles
Item to the lorde of schrewsburys mynstrelles
Item to the Kynges mynstrelles At a nothyr tyme
Item to the frenche quenys berward

div.p: Thomas Brandon, an entertainer, was a servant to Henry VIII. Although the King referred to him as 'our pleyer,' Brandon was neither an actor nor a juggler but, as John Southworth puts it, a 'stage magician' (a 'tregatour' or 'jouculator' in Latin usage). That he was much favoured is clear in that in 1522 Henry VIII requested the City of London to make him a freeman of the city, with the occupation of leather seller, a position that made it possible for Brandon to hire out his performing skills to the companies of London, bypassing the monopolistic control of the city's musicians and actors guild. Brandon traveled widely to perform throughout the kingdom, in venues as widely scattered as Shrewsbury, Thetford Priory in Norfolk, Exeter, and Barnstaple. He often performed at civic venues, including mayors' houses, on local celebration days. He was even cited with grudging admiration for his illusionist's skills by Reginald Scott Discovery of Witchcraft indicating that his fame had survived his death (Southworth, Fools and Jesters at the English Court (Stroud, 1998), 94–9).
Henry Tudor (1491–1546/7) was king of England from 22 April 1509. See P&P.
Edward Stanley (1509–72) was twelfth earl of Derby from 1521, with seats at Lathom and Knowsley, Lancashire. See P&P.
Thomas Howard (1473–1554) was duke of Norfolk from 1524 to 1546 and in 1553-4, with residence at Kenninghall, Norfolk. See P&P.
George Talbot (1468–1538) was seventh earl of Shrewsbury from 1473 until death, with residences at South Wingfield, Derbyshire, Shropshire, and Yorkshire. See P&P.
Mary Tudor (1496–1533), wife of Charles Brandon, fourth duke of Suffolk, had been crowned queen of France on 5 November 1514. See P&P.

div.head: p 336 (3 June)
div.ab: ⸿ Ad hanc Curiam concordatum est per prenominatos Balliuos portmannos & Burgenses quod ludus videlicet Corporis Christi pley pro hoc anno non luditur sed defertur

div.head: p 336 (3 June)
div.ab: ⸿ At this court it was agreed by by the aforesaid bailiffs, councillors, and burghers that the play, namnely the Corpus Christi play is not played but deferred for this year.

div.head: p 205 (30 January)
div.ab: Corpus Christi play laide for ever aside by order.

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 205 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 30 January.

div.head: p 212 (4 November)
div.ab: Granted to three waites, 13s 4d a peece yerely.

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 211 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 4 November.

div.head: p 219 (2 June)
div.ab: Every householder, with their family, shall follow the pageants of Corpus Christi in due order, under penalty of 4d, if lawfull cause be not shewen, except the 12 portmen and theire wives, and the 24ty.

Every Warden and Master of the Trade shall offer to theire Pageants uppon the day of Corpus Christi, each of them 1d, the one halfe whereof shall goe to ye parish preist, the other halfe shall be divided between the Clerk and the Sexton, and every defalter shall loose 4d.
Every Burgess shall offer on the Guild Sunday one halfe penny to the preist, to be divided, the one halfe to the preist, the other to the Clerke and Sexton, and every defalter shall loose 4d.

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 219 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 2 June.

The Ipswich civic records indicate that the town annually sponsored several processions as part of its celebration of Corpus Christi. As this order indicates, a civic procession of pageants, accompanied by the entire population of the town, occurred on Corpus Christi Day itself (Thursday of Corpus Christi week). The entire population also took part in a purely liturgical procession spanning Corpus Christi Day and the day after, in which they accompanied the Sacrament of Corpus Christi from the Church of St Lawrence to the fishmarket on the Corn Hill to the Tower Church, thence to Margaret's Green and around the town, arriving again at Tower Church where they heard a mass. The following day, the population accompanied the Sacrament on a return journey (this time including Brook Street) to the Church of St Lawrence. The portmen of the town, the twenty-four burgesses, and the torchers, all bearing torches, accompanied the Holy Sacrament (pp 215, 220). The records give no indication that the liturgical processions included pageantry or involved performance.

row.cell: Item payde to the Quynes gestre for a rewarde the xvj day of Iune

div.p: The queen's jester was likely James Lockwood, jester to Queen Mary; see John Southworth, Fools and Jesters at the English Court (Stroud, 1998), 99.

row.cell: Item Received of Iohn Wapolle mynstrell for the ffyne of his indeightment
Item paid to Lockwoode the Quens Iester
Item paid to the King and Quens plaiers

div.p: In 1559–60 Walpolle (f [2v]) was dwelling in the South Ward of Ipswich in that he is recorded in that year as giving 2s in 'the collection of the forreners of the sowthe warde'(C/3/4/1/2, p 9). See also Webb, Town Finances, p 25). Otherwise no biographical details have come to light.

James Lockwood (f [3]) was jester to Henry VIII, Mary, and Elizabeth I in turn. He appears in performance records between 1540/1 (at Nottingham) and 1570/1(at Leicester), as well as numerous other places. He is variously identified in performance records as 'the Kynges bourdur' and, almost always, as the king or queen's servant and/or jester. His travels to perform included an extraordinary number of cities and large towns throughout the kingdom (most often among them Leicester), and he is described by John Southworth as one among numerous 'semi-independent, peripatetic jesters' who performed in civic and private venues during the Tudor period, though he was never actually recorded at a performance before the Court (see Southworth, Fools and Jesters at the English Court (Stroud, 1998), 98–9).

Mary Tudor (f [6]; 1515/16–58) was queen of England from 1 October 1553 until her death on 17 November, 1558. Her husband, Philip Habsburg (1527–98) was king of Spain from 16 July 1556 and styled king of England from 27 July 1554. See P&P.

row.cell: Item paid to the Duke of Norfolkes players

div.p: Thomas Howard (1537/8-72) was duke of Norfolk from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex and Kenninghall, Norfolk; he was executed for treason. See P&P.

div.p: Peter Moone, a resident of Ipswich, was a tailor, actor, theatre-manager, gospeller, and radical reformist. According to John Webb, who has written a detailed article about him, he was a well-known character in the Tudor town' ('Peter Moone of Ipswiche (d. 1601),' Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology 38, pt 1 (1993), 35–55). He and his wife are recorded as having lived first in St Mary Tower parish, then in St Stevens parish in the North Ward. He sometimes drummed at musters for the town until giving way in that task in 1586–7 to John Minter, the town's newly appointed official drummer. In 1571–2 he was paid for drum heads and drum sticks (C/3/2/1/1, f 42v); he had repaired the town's ancient in 1578–9, and had repaired the town drum in 1586-7 (C/3/4/1/18, f 5v). Although Webb describes Moone as of 'low social status,' the many references to him in the records suggest a substantial person (though of limited financial means and always seeking ways to make money). Though originally a 'foreigner,' he was a burgess by 1560 (the year before his troupe performed) and he would serve as a burgess for the final twenty-eight years of his life. In 1581 he was fined for not wearing his gown at official ceremonies. In 1585, when town officials were particularly exercised about the proliferation of seditious rhymes, they hired (and paid the exorbitant amount of 30 li) to Moone to sleuth out the identity of two anonymous rhymers. He succeeded in identifying one of the two. He was a notable among his fellow burgesses, and was a trusted member of St Stevens parish in that he presented on behalf of the parish their contribution of 13s 4d in year's wages for the preacher (C/3/4/1/18, f 1; Webb, 'Peter Moon,' pp 35, 43–5).

Of particular resonance concerning this collection, Moone was one of the group of radical thinkers and writers present in Ipswich in the 1530's. In 1548 he published 'A short treatise of certayne things abused in the Popysh Church,' 'a rhyming tract of thirty-seven eight-line stanzas.' The tract is reprinted in Webb, 'Peter Moone,' pp 46-52. Moone's use of language shows him to have been a talented writer. While the tract is a sermon of sorts, in form it is a dramatic monologue. In the first stanza, he refers to 'this audience.' During the reign of Mary, he was fined and jailed in London for four months on suspicion of conspiracy and during the subsequent reign he acted as a source of contemporary witness by John Foxe in his Acts and Monuments. Some scholars have postulated that when Queen Elizabeth visited Ipswich on 5–11 August, 1561 – arriving by boat from Dunmow, Essex – the program of events staged in her honor included a performance by Moone's troupe of John Bale's King Johan. However, no evidence to confirm that suggestion has yet come to light (Webb, 'Peter Moone,' pp 37–8, 42).
Whether Moone's troupe comprised actors recruited for this one event or was a sustaining troupe whose patron was Moone is impossible to know.

William Martin (f [4v]) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors. Martin further served as the Clerk of the Market; see Stokes, 'Waits' pp 19–21).
John de Vere (c 1516–62) was sixteenth earl of Oxford from 21 March 1539/40, with residence at Hedingham Castle, Essex. See P&P.

Katherine Willoughby (1518/19–80) was likely twelfth Baroness Willoughby of Eresby, duchess of Suffolk, with seats at Grimsthorpe Castle and Tattershall Castle, Lincolnshire from c 1536, with a residence at Westhorpe, Suffolk, from c 1528. See P&P.

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

Katherine Willoughby (1518/19–80) was likely twelfth Baroness Willoughby of Eresby, duchess of Suffolk, with seats at Grimsthorpe Castle and Tattershall Castle, Lincolnshire from c 1536, with a residence at Westhorpe, Suffolk, from c 1528. See P&P.

Romsey (f [3v]) was almost certainly John Ramsey, a carver or joiner, and the same Ramsey who was paid by the burgesses two years later for staging another play on 8 December (C/3/2/1/1, f 8). Ramsey was part of a group of radical reformists including Peter Moone and Richard Argentine alias Sexten who were active in Ipswich from the 1530's on. A talented group, they wrote and published their own anti-Catholic tracts as well as those of continental authors, and preached in the town, reciting their own tracts which combined poetry, dramatic monologue, politics, and evangelical arguments underpinned by scriptural quotations (John Webb, 'Peter Moone of Ipswiche (d. 1601),' Publications of the Suffolk Institute for Archaeology 38, pt 1 (1993), 36). Ramsey is thought to have authored the undated A Corosyfe to be layed hard unto the hartes of all faythfull Professours of Christes Gospel, Gathered out of the sciptures by Iohn Ramsey. Given the evangelical content of the work, its sermonly rhetorical approach, and the fact that Ramsey was nearly 60 years old in 1562-3, together with the fact that Ramsey was 'an uncommon Ipswich surname,' Webb concludes that 'he Ramsey may well have been described as "Father"'(Webb, p 42). Ramsey also served as bailiff of Ipswich Manor of Christchurch for Edmund Withipoll in the mid-1540's, suffered for his views during the reign of Mary, and, like Moone, later served as a contemporary witness for John Foxe in his writing of Acts and Monuments (Webb, pp 36, 38).
John de Vere (1516–62) was sixteenth earl of Oxford from 21 March 1539/40, with residence at Hedingham Castle, Essex. See P&P.

Robert Dudley (1532–1588) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. He was knighted but generally styled Lord Robert Dudley. See P&P.

row.cell: Item payde to younge braine for playinge on the drome at ther goinge forthe

div.p: This payment occurred in June. The 'goinge forthe' could refer either to a military exercise of some kind, as in a muster, or to a processional event that was typical of the civic guild in its activities.

div.p: Robert Dudley (f [4v]; 1532–1588) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. He was knighted but generally styled Lord Robert Dudley. See P&P.
William Willoughby (f [5v]; 1515–70) was first Baron Willoughby of Parham from 1546/7, with residence at Parham, Suffolk. See P&P.

William Smart (f [6]) was an important and trusted official of the town, who served as treasurer in 1560–1, and as bailiff in 1586–7 (ff 126, 149). In 1596 when the town was wanting in cash, he lent it £300 (f11). He appears many times in the accounts as a benefactor, collector, and witness of the accounts.
Sir Ralph Sadler (f [6v]; 1507–87) was knighted in 1540, with residence at Standon, Hertfordshire. See ODNB.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.
Francis Russell (f [7]; 1527–85) was fourth earl of Bedford from 14 March 1554/5, with residences at Amersham and Chenies, and Woburn Abbey, Buckinghamshire. See P&P.
Robert Rich (ca.1537-81), was second Baron Rich from 1567, with residences at Leigh's Priory and Rochford Hall, Essex. See P&P.

div.p: The heading of this treasurer's account (by the treasurer, Robert Sallowse) says that it was made on 8 December in 10 Elizabeth for the year before (that is, for 1567–8). But the heading does not specify the year, as most of the accounts in this series do. The account immediately follows the treasurer's account for 1577–8 (by Henry Hannam), and precedes Hannam's account for 1578–9, and has thus been placed out of sequence in the volume of accounts.

William Martin (f 166) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 277 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 24 September.

div.p: While Becon (f 19v) has not been identified with certainty, John Wasson concludes that he is probably Sir John Becon, father of John Becon (d. 1587), LLD, of Suffolk, distinguished Cambridge scholar, canon of Norwich, 1574, and chancellor of the diocese of Norwich, 1576; and of Richard Becon, an 'official in Ireland under Queen Elizabeth' (Wasson, Plays and Players, p 214).
The entry following the payment to 'Becones men' is a payment made on 6 November.
Robert Rich (f 20v; c 1537–1580/1) was second Lord Rich from 12 June 1567, with seats at Leighs Priory and Rochford Hall, Essex. See P&P.

'Mr Foskewes' (f 21) probably refers to Sir Henry Fortescue (by 1515–by 1576), succeeded on 8 August 1517, with his seat at Faulkbourne, Essex. He had extensive lands in Essex and his players were active in the period (several entries). See P&P.

The entry on f 21v following the bearward is dated 1 June. 'dewekes' likely refers to Thomas Howard (1537/8–1572), who was duke of Norfolk from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex and Kenninghall, Norfolk; he was executed for treason. See P&P.
George Tuke (1525-74) was sheriff of Essex in 1567, with residence at Layer Marney, situated between Colchester and Maldon, Essex. See P&P.

The entry on f 6 does not confirm that 'my Lord Riches men' were players, but the wording of the entry and the fact that Rich's troupe often visited suggest that the men being paid may have been players. Robert Rich (c 1537–80/1) was second Lord Rich from 12 June 1567, with seats at Leighs Priory and Rochford Hall, Essex. See P&P.

div.p: Only three of the entries following the queen's players on ff [5v] are dated: 16 October and Christmas and 15 January (. Those dated entries must, respectively, be for 1572, 1572, and 1572/3. Therefore the payment to the queen's players must have occurred during a one-month period in The queen was Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3), crowned 15 January See P&P.

Henry Cheyne (1540–87), Lord Cheyne, knight from 1563, was first Baron Cheyne (of Toddington) from 1572, with residences at Toddington Manor, Bedfordshire and Shurland Hall, Kent, plus lands in Essex. See P&P.

The payment to Lord Talbot's players (f [6v]) happened after 30 June. Francis Talbot (1550–82), Baron Talbot, assumed Lord Talbot 1560; son of George Talbot, sixth earl of Shrewsbury. His father's residence was Sheffield Castle, Yorkshire. See P&P.

div.head: mbs 3-4 (16 May)
div.ab:
Et ultimo damus & concedemus pro nobis heredibus & successoribus nostris prefatis Balliuis Burgensibus & Communitati ville nostre predicte & sucessoribus suis imperpetuum quod bene liceat & licebit tam predictis Balliuis Burgensibis & Comunitati pro tempore existente quam eisdem & talibus gubernatoribus officiarijs vel ministris quos & quales predicti Balliui Burgenses & Communitat'Communitat': for Communitas appunctuabunt siue ordinabunt de tempore in tempus esse gubernatores officiarios vel ministros sub se euisdem domus vocate Christes hospitall aut illarum aliarum domorum eidem hospitali spectanti & tribus vel duobus eorum officiariorum omnino post hac de tempore in tempus tam infra Burgum & villam predictos & suburbijssuburbijs: for suburbia eiusdem quam alibi infra dictum Comitatum nostrum Suffolicie inquirere & examinare diligenter omnibus vijs & modis quibus melius scire potuerint secundum eorum prudenciam & discrecionem omnes & omnimoda suspiciosas domos tabernas diuersaria alieatoriaalieatoria: for aleatoria ludos saltatorios ac locos alios quoscumque suspiciosos & libertatem siue libertates & locos exemptos quoscumque suspiciosos infra dictum Burgum & villam & suburbia eiusdem & dictum Comitatum nostrum Suffolicie quibuscumque nominibus seu titulis illa seu eorum alique sint aut erunt vocata nuncupata aut appelata acetiam scrutari inuestigare ac inquirere omnes & singulas domos aliquo modo suspectas siue locos quoscumque suspectos pro ociosis ruffianis ignauis ganionibus vagabundis & vallidis mendicis siue alijs quibuscumque personis suspectis & hominibus quibuscumque & mulieribus seu viris mali nominis & fame Et eosdem Ruffianos ganiones vagabundos & mendicos non solum apprehendere infra easdem domos suspectas seu locos libertatem vel libertates ‸& locos exemptos suspectos existentes infra dictam villam & suburbia eiusdem seu infra dictum Comitatum nostrum Suffolicie Sed etiam tenentes magistros Dominos siue Custodes talium domorum vel locorum suspectorum vbi aliquis talis vel tales inuenti
fuerint vnacum personis suspectis in domum occupacionum de Christes hospitall predicto per aduisamentum & superuisum dictorum quatuor gubernatorum committere aut aliquo alio modo eos omnes & singulos punire per aduisamentum & superuisum predictos prout bonum & legitimum tunc eisdem gubernatoribus expedire videbitur nisi honeste & iuste talium domorum & locorum tenentes magistri Dominj siue Custodes & suspecte persone predicte se excusare atque exonerare possint coram prefatis Balliuis seu quatuor gubernatoribus hospitalis predictis pro tempore existentibus quare tales ociosos Ruffianos & suspectas & vagabundas personas ita alant & nutriant seu permittant in suis domibus iacere conuersari & frequentare atque eciam nisi talis vel tales homines seu mulieres ita suspecti & vagabundi existentes sic capti sufficienter & plene monstrare seu palam facere possunt vel possit pro sua honestate & bona conuersacione & iustam racionem reddere quibus modis victitent vel victitet & quam ob causam ita vagantur vel vagatur & ingrediatur seu ingrediantur huiusmodi suspectos : line filler over erasure domos & absconditeabscondite: for absconditos seu prohibitos locos atque eciam sic apprehensi quod bene licebit dictis Balliuis capere de eisdem suspectibus sufficientem securitatem quod honeste se posthac gerent & quilibet eorum geret.

div.head: mb 3-4 (16 May)
div.ab:
And finally we give and grant on behalf of ourselves, our heirs, and successors to the aforesaid bailiffs, burgesses, and commonalty of our aforesaid town and their successors in perpetuity that it be fully permitted and will be permitted both for the aforesaid bailiffs, burgesses, and commonalty existing at the time and for the same and such governors, officers, or ministers whom and of what kind the aforesaid bailiffs, burgesses, and commonalty will appoint or ordain from time to time to be governers, officers, or ministers under themselves of the same house called Christ's Hospital or of those other houses belonging to the same hospital, and to three or two of their officers in any circumstance after this from time to time both within the aforesaid borough and town and the suburbs of the same as well as elsewhere in our said county of Suffolk to inquire and examine diligently by all ways and means by which they might better know according to their wisdom and discretion, all and all manner of suspected houses, taverns, inns, gaming houses, dancing schools, and whatsoever other suspected places and liberty or liberties and whatsoever suspected exempt places, within the said borough and town and the suburbs of the same, and our said county of Suffolk, by whatever names or titles they or any of them is or will be called, named, or designated, and also to search, investigate, and seek out each and every house in any way suspected, or any places whatsoever, suspected for idle ruffians, lazy gluttons, vagabonds, and sturdy beggars or other suspected persons, whosoever they be, and any people, whosoever they be, both women and men, of evil name and repute, and not only to apprehend within the same suspected house or places, liberty or liberties, and suspected exempt places which are within the said town and suburbs of the same, or within our said county of Suffolk, the same ruffians, gluttons, vagabonds, and beggars, but also to commit the tenants, masters, lords, or keepers of such houses or suspected places where any such person or persons shall be found
together with suspected persons into the house of occupations of the aforesaid Christ's Hospital by deliberation and examination of the said four governors or in any other way to punish each and everyone of them, by the aforesaid deliberation and examination just as it seems (proportionate) at that time to the same governers to expedite the good and lawful, unless the tenants, the masters, lords, or keepers of those houses and places and the aforesaid suspected persons are able to excuse and exonerate themselves honestly and justly before the aforesaid bailiffs or four governors of the aforesaid hospital for the time being, and to show sufficiently and fully why they so feed and nourish such lazy ruffians and suspected persons and vagabonds or permit them to lodge in, dwell in, and frequent their houses, and also unless any such person or any such men or women so suspected and taken as living as vagabonds is able or are able to show sufficiently and fully or to make known with regard to their honesty and good way of life and give just account by what means they live or she or he lives and for what reason they so wander or she or he wanders, and she or he enters or they enter suspected houses of this kind or hidden or prohibited places, and also having been so apprehended that it be quite legal for the bailiffs to take from the same suspects sufficient surety that they will conduct themselves and each of them will conduct him or herself honestly hereafter.

row.cell: Item paid to Martyne & his companye for ther musick at ye yeld

div.p: William Martin (f 50v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

row.cell: paid to the Erle of Sussex players by Mr Bayliffes Comaundement the viijth of October
Item paid to therle of Southe hamptons players the xxijth of ffebruarye by comaundement
paid to the Erle of Leycetters pleyers the xviijth of Iune by Mr Cutlers comaundement
paid to the Italian Tumbler at Mr Bayliff Cutlers comaundement for playenge before him & his brotheren the xxixth of Iune
paid to the Erle of Sussex players the iij of August by Master B ‸ Bayliffes commaundement
alsoe of xiij s. iiij d. parcell of ij Inditementes assessed vppon Iohn Ionson minstrell & pardoned by the Iustices Iustices
Item paid for wyne spent at the gylde dynner & supper
Item paid to william Marten for musicke at ye gylde

div.p: Thomas Radcliffe (f 70v; 1526–83) was Lord Fitzwalter from 27 May 1542 and eight earl of Sussex from 17 May 1556/7, with residences at New Hall, Essex, and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.
Henry Wriothesley (f 71v; 1545–81), third earl of Southampton from 1550, with residences at Tichfield and Itchell, near Dogmersfield, Hampshire. See P&P.
Robert Dudley (f 72v; 1532 or 1533–88), fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.
Thomas Radcliffe (1526–83) was Lord Fitzwalter from 27 May 1542 and eighth earl of Sussex from 17 May 1556/7, with residences at New Hall, Essex and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.

William Martin (f 80) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the Clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

row.cell: geven to my lorde Chamberleynes players at Master Bayliffes comaundement the xviijth of Maye
paid to the playeres of Norwich by Master Bayliffes comaundement the viijth of August
geven my lorde Staffordes players the xviijth of August at the comaundement of Master Bayliffes

div.p: The players of Norwich (f 98v) were likely the waits of Norwich, since there exists no evidence that the City of Norwich financially supported a dedicated company of actors. There is, however, evidence that, in addition to their music, the Norwich waits received the city's permission to act in comedies, interludes, and tragedies. David Galloway assumed that all those performances by the waits as actors occurred locally, and he found no evidence indicating that the company toured. If the troupe that was paid in Ipswich on 8 August 1575 was the waits, that would be the first record confirming that the waits did indeed tour. On the Norwich waits as actors, see Galloway, Norwich, pp xxxi, xxxix, lxxxvi n 3, and 57.
Charles Howard (1536–1624) was lord chamberlain from 1574, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Edward Stafford (f 99; 1535/6–1603) was twelfth Baron Stafford from 1 January 1565/6, with his seat at Stafford Castle, Staffordshire. See P&P.

row.cell: Item payd more to the sayd DabneDabne: Robert Dabne, a craftsman skilled in working with metal and wood for taken down of the bordes & the tresselles & mendyng of them for the geld & settyng them vpp for iij days work
Item payd to willyam marten for hys service at the gyld by a warant

div.p: Preparations for the annual guild feast (f 10) often involved the building, and subsequently the taking down, of staging for the guild day (or guild feast commonly called 'the guild'). Because that feast always involved performance of one kind or another, it seems reasonable to conclude that the staging likely related to those performances, whether for music by the six waits (as happened this year at the annual guild feast, for staging drama, or for viewing pageants or another spectacle by the guild's worthies. Drama in Suffolk, as we have it in the records, often involved scaffold staging).

William Martin (f 11v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, the bailiffs' entries into the city, and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors. Martin further served as the Clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' 19–21).

Itemsecunda payd to wyllyam Marten Clark of the markett for his quarterli wages dew at owr lady day by a warant the 30 day of march
Item3a payd to wyllyam marten Clark of the markett the 24 day dayday day: dittographyof Ivne for his quarterli wages

Item4a payd to wyllyam marten clark of the markett for his quarterli wages dew at Myhellmes

div.p: William Martin was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568-9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

div.head: p 174 (29 September–29 September)
div.ab: In the 17th of Elizabeth, the Guild feast was ordered to be held henceforth upon the Sunday fortnight next after Midsummer day; and in the next year, the "occupacions" or trades of the town were newly drawn into companies. At that day they consisted of four only "Mercers, drapers, tailors, and shoemakers," into which all others merged. The Taylors' included, "cutlers, smyths, barbers, chandlers, pewterers, mynstrells, pedlers, plumbers, pynners, millers, millwrights, cowpers, shermen, glasiers, turners, tynkers, taylors, and two others."

div.p: This description by Wodderspoon is (presumably) taken from a now-lost court book). While his summary identifies the year of the order as being 18 Elizabeth (1575–6), he does not include the specific date of the court on which the order was made.

row.cell: paid to the Lorde chamberlynes players by master balyffes order Somme
paid to my Lorde Robertes players by master balyffesbalyffes: a written over y order

div.p: Dated entries on ff [5v] and [6] indicate that the payment to the lord chamberlain's players occurred between 30 January 1575/6 and 7 May 1576. Thomas Radcliffe (f [5v]; c 1526–83) was lord chamberlain from 1572 and earl of Sussex from 1557, with his seat at New Hall, Essex, Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.

Lord Robert (f [6]) is likely Robert Dudley (c 1532) who was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex; or, less likely, Robert Devereux (1566–1600/1) who was eighteenth earl of Essex from 22 September 1576 with seats at Chartley, Staffordshire and Lamphey, Pembrokeshire. See P&P.

row.cell: Item paid to william Marten Clarke of the Markett more the xxvtie daye of Iune by a warrant for Musike at ye gilde dinner

div.p: William Martin (f 102) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

row.cell: Item paid to the players the 29 of maye
Item paid to my Lord Chamberlyns players þe 30 of may

of IohnRemytid
the 8 of
november
by the 12.
and 24/ Ionson mynstrell

div.p: Thomas Radcliffe (f 5; c 1526–83) was lord chamberlain from 1572 and earl of Sussex from 1557, with seat at New Hall and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.

On f 8v, Johnson's is one of five remitted fines that are bracketed by the marginal note. The 12 and 24 are two bodies of burgesses. In later years, in the 1601–2 chamberlains' account, John Johnson would be described as clerk of the Market, for which he was paid 40s in wages and an additional 26s 8d 'for lokinge to the butchers' (C/3/3/2/34, ff 113–14 (see also Webb, Elizabethan Finances, pp 138–9). On f 114 of the same account Webb was twice listed among a group of persons no longer required, for various reasons, to pay a local subsidy tax charged to those who had achieved a certain level of wealth.

Having a minstrel serve as clerk of the Market was not without precedent. In 1575–6 and again in 1576–7 William Martin, master of the town's company of waits at that time, was paid both his quarterly wages as clerk of the Market and additional payments by warrant for his music at the annual guild dinner (C/3/2/1/1, f 102 and C/3/4/1/9, f [3v]). The records give no indication that Johnson was one of the town waits under the mastership of either William Martin or John Bettes, though he well may have been one of Martin's waits since the members of Martin's troupe are never named in the records.

row.cell: Paid to william Martyn the xjth of Iune for musicke at the guild last holden
Paid to Mr Smart to the vse of Iohn Mynter by warrant of the grete courte holden þe xviij of September

div.p: William Martin (f 120v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).
Mynter was the town drummer, who often performed with the waits.

row.cell: Itemin Iune payde to Iohn Pytman for making of ij formes for the halle agaynste the guylde
paid to Robert Dabeny for placyng of the tables at the guilde, and laying vp of the same
for certen nayles spente about the hanging and Trymmyng of the halle
payde to Christopher Lymmer for wyne spent at the Gylde
for mendinge of the auncyant and for silke for the same

div.p: The words 'in Iune' are written in the left margin at the top of this folio, confirming that these payments occurred during that month.

row.cell: Item payd to my Lords howards players the 24 of october
payd vnto my Lord vassys Sarvantes being here with bears the 6 of Ianevary by Mr balyffes apoyntment
Item payd vnto the earll of Darbys players the 28 of maye by Mr Balyffes apoyntment
Item payd vnto Dawes the tumbler the .12. of ffebrewary for makyng pastyme at the hawll by the apoyntment of Mr Ballyffes
payd vnto my Lord of Leysetors players the 10 of September

div.p: 'Lord vassy' (f [4v]) is possibly William Vesey (d. 1577), lord of Cockerells Hall Manor, Buxhall, Suffolk, owner of the manor of Hintlesham Priory, Suffolk, and lord of Wix Manor and Abbey,in Essex.
Charles Howard (f 4; 1536–1624) was Lord Howard from 1573, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Henry Stanley (f [5v] 1531–93) was thirteen earl of Derby from 1572, with seats at Lathom and Knowsley, Lancashire. See P&P.
Robert Dudley (f [6]; c1532–33–88) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: Paid to william Martyn for musicke at the guylde
Payed to Iohn Beckett for chardges of the pagent made by Mr Kynge the skryvener at the guilde daie
Payed to Iohn Kynge Skryvener for his paynes & chardges employed aboute preparacions A geinst the quenes Maiesties commyng

div.p: William Martin (f 135v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

John Kynge (f 136) is identified in the records as a scrivener and schoolmaster, though there is no indication that he was the headmaster of Ipswich school. He was talented in making pageants and staging celebrations, shows and dramatizations, which the town paid him to do between 1578 and 1584, at which point he appears to have had a falling out with the town's officials and ceased to perfom those services thereafter.

div.head: f 11v (26 June)
div.ab:
fforsomychpersons
Apoynted
to devise
agens the
quenes commyng As yt thought ‸is supposed the Quenes Maiesty is to comme to this Towne at this prog her progresse into Suffolk It is Agreed at this Assemblye that the persones herafter named videlicet ‸mr Augustine Parker & ‸ mr Edward Goodyng aldermen George Coppyng Thomas Blosse Thomas bennett william mydnall & Olyver Cowper shall haue Auctorytie dev to devise the order such orders & matters As shalbe mete & necessarye for ‸touchyng the recyuyng of her Maiestie into this Towne & to Also yt is Agred that the persones herafter shall haue Auctorytie to devise that what shall be necessarye to make demaund for of the quenes Maiesty touching the liberties ‸Incresing & Augmentacion of the such liberties ‸ & Iuresdicions of this Towne ‸ as they shall think proper vz Mr Clench Mr Smart Mr Scryven Iohn Hawys Henry Hannan & Edward Cage

div.head: f 14v (1 September)
div.ab:
Itemorder for
< . >tynge yt is Agreed where Iohn Kyng scryvener at the Assignes of Master bayliffes & others Apoynted / have disbursed in thinges touching the setting forthe of pagentes Ageinst the quenes maiestys commyng to þe somme xs ixd besydes for workemens labors & he toke yt by the treasurer & for his paynes taken about the same is referrd to þe next Assembly

div.head: f 15 (5 September)
div.ab: It is Agreed that forsomycheArrerages order for kyng / as Iohn Kynge Scryvener hath taken paynes for the Towne about the setting forthe of pagentes aswell at þe yeld as Ageinst the quenes Comynge/ the said Iohn Kynge shall haue geven to him of the Treasury of the Towne by the Towne treasurer xl s./

div.p: The town made these (f 11v) and numerous other elaborate preparations for the expected visit by Elizabeth I, but in spite of long-held local belief to the contrary, there is no evidence in the records that her visit ever actually happened. Her progress into Suffolk and Norfolk during August 1578 did take her, in turn, to Long Melford, Bury St Edmunds, Hawsted, Euston, and Hengrave. She then made her way through Norfolk, staying at Swaffam, Kenninghall (with a side trip to Redgrave, Suffolk), Bracon Ash, Norwich, Kimberley, Woodrising, Thetford, and again to Hengrave, Suffolk. She then progressed on into Cambridge. In each place she stayed in the palatial residences of important members of the gentry, whose entertainments staged on her behalf are richly detailed in numerous contemporary sources, including those by Thomas Churchyard. In no place were performances more lavishly staged or cleverly conceived than in Norwich between 15 and 22 August (see David Galloway (ed), Norwich 15401642 REED (Toronto, Buffalo, and London, 1984), pp 292–340). According to John Nichols, a year later, on 22–6 August 1579, the Queen spent four nights in Ipswich, having sailed up the Orwell from Essex. But once again local records offer no evidence confirming what Nichols, with some detail, claimed. Diarmaid MacCulloch (as reported by John Webb) offers factual reasons why the visit was not likely to have occurred, for example, the plague in Ipswich and the presence of the Queen's French suitor, the Duke of Anjou, at Greenwich during that time (Webb, Town Finances, p 46, n 4).

row.cell: Item paid by Mr Ballyffes commandement to the lord Stranges players in Reward
Item paid the Lord Vasses bearewardes in reward
Item paid the beareward yat bayted on the guyld day
Item paid the Lord charles howerdes players
Item paid the Lord bartletes players

Itemyt ys allowed for thys
tyme & vtterly forbydden
her afterpaid to Kinge scriviner ffor the pagent At the guild as appeare by warrant
ij li. iiij s. viij d.

div.p: The entry concerning Strange's players on f 5 is the third payment made in the account. Ferdinando Stanley (c 1559–94) was thirteen Baron Strange (of Knokyn) from 1572, with seat at Stanley House, Chester, Cheshire. See P&P.

'Lord Vasse,' patron of the bearward onf 5v, is possibly William Vesey (d. 1577), lord of Cockerells Hall Manor, Buxhall, Suffolk, owner of the Manor of Hintlesham Priory, Suffolk, and lord of Wix Manor and Abbey, in Essex.
Following the payment to Vassey's bearward on f [5v], the next dated entry twelve payments later is for 12 April.

Guild Day, identified as 'The Guild' on f 6, was the annual feast days of the Corpus Christi/Merchants Guild that was held during the summer on days that changed through the decades. The Guild Day (or the guild) included a dinner, ceremonies, music, and other kinds of performance. In 1574–5 the burgesses ordered the day to be permanently changed to the 'Sunday se'nnight next, after Midsummer-day,' though even that date proved subject to change, given the circumstances (Fitch, ' Corpus Christi Guild,' p 158).
Charles Howard (1536–1624) was Lord Howard from 1573, with a residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Henry Berkeley (1534–1613) was seventh Baron Berkeley, with residence at Caludon Castle, Warwickshire. See P&P.

John Kinge (f [6v]), scrivener and schoolmaster, possessed the ability both to make pageants and to stage events that involved pageants. In 1578 the town paid him for both those tasks on Guild Day and in its preparations for an expected visit by the Queen. In 1579 he again supplied 'the pageant' for Guild Day and for the annual commemoration of the Queen's Coronation, and in 1579 he made a ship pageant 'with certen convenynt speches therein.' He appears in the records a final time in 1584. Between 1578 and 1584, Kinge clearly was the town's central figure in the mounting of civic shows. SeeStokes, 'Waits,' pp 22–4).

row.cell: paid to William Marten for his musike at the Guylde

The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

Paid For caryinge a letter to Mr Kempe
paid to therle of essex plaiers

div.p: Robert Dudley (c 1532–3–88) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

Mr Kempe was perhaps William Kempe, of Akenham, bailiff of a Mr Townesende, to whom the treasurer of Ipswich, Christopher Crane, had paid 3s in rent money owed by the town in 1571–2 (C/3/2/1/1, f 42v; see also Webb, Town Finances, p 44).
Robert Devereux (1565-1600/1) was second earl of Essex from 1576, with seat at Cassiobury House, near Watford, Hertfordshire. See P&P.

row.cell: paid to william Martyn for his musick at the guild

div.p: William Martin (f 135v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

Ambrose Dudley (1528–89/90), knight, was twenty-first earl of Warwick from 26 November 1561 with residences at North Hall, Northaw, Hertfordshire, and Warwick Castle, Warwickshire. See P&P.

The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. div.p: The entry following the payment to Lord Chandos' players on f 227 is dated 3 August.
William Somerset (a 1527–1588/9), Lord Herbert, was eighth earl of Worcester from 26 November 1549, with a seat at Raglan, Monmouthshire and residence at Hackney, Middlesex. See P&P.
Edward Stafford (1535/6–1603) was twelfth Baron Stafford from 1 January 1565/6, with his seat at Stafford Castle, Staffordshire. See P&P.
Henry Stanley (1531–93) was thirteenth earl of Derby from 1572, with seats at Lathom and Knowsley, Lancashire. See P&P.
Giles Brydges (c 1548–1593/4) was third Baron Chandos from 11 March 1572/3, with seat at Sudley Castle, Gloucester. See P&P.
Thomas Radcliffe (c 1526–83) was lord chamberlain from 1572–8, and created earl of Sussex in 1557, with residences at New Hall, Essex, and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.
Henry Berkeley (f 227v; 1534–1613) was seventh Baron Berkeley from 26 November 1534, with residence at Caludon Castle, Warwickshire.

The patron of 'lord Robertes players' was either Robert Dudley (1532 or 1533–88) who was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex, or Robert Devereux (1565-1600/1) who was second earl of Essex from 1576, with seat at Cassiobury House, near Watford, Hertfordshire. See P&P pages for Robert Dudley or Robert Devereux.
Frederick Windsor (1559–85) was fourth Baron Windsor of Stanwell from 1575, with residence at Stanwell, Surrey. See P&P.
Edward de Vere (1550–1604) was seventeenth earl of Oxford from 3 August 1562, with residences at Hedingham Castle, Essex, and Hackney, Middlesex. See P&P.

The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]).
