div.head: f 74v (6 April)
div.ab:
Andorder for
waytes it is ordered & agreed that at the request of William Marten musitian the said William Marten & his Company being 6 in all shall have waighteswaightes: ie, pipes or wind instruments rather than the players of them (see entry on f 216v) bought at the Townes Chardge & that he & they shall therwith serue the Towne for one yere in suche order as by the bayliffes shalbe thought mete & requisit And the said William & his Company to stand to the consideracion of the Towne for ther Wages in that behalf, And it is furder agreed by the consent of the said William that if the Towne shall not lyke of ther seruice at the yeres ende that then he the said William shall repaye the somme of mony the Towne shall so disburse backe ageyne And for the better assurance of payment therof the said William promiseth to stonde bound With sufficient suerties accordyngly as by Mr Bayliffes for the tyme being shall thinke mete and allowe of/.

div.p: William Martin (f 135v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

div.head: f 83 (19 December)
div.ab:
Wheras Iohn Kynge scolemaster in the xvij ten daye of november last wherinxl s. geven
to Kyng the Quenes maiesties reigne newly beganne ageyne was at Charge about certen pageantes & other Shewes in this Towne in Ioye of that daye. Item agreed that he shall have geven to him out of the Towne Treasur in full satisfaccion of & for his said Charges & paynes taken in that behalf fourty shillinges to be payd by the Threasurer

div.p: There is no evidence that John Kyne was schoolmaster at Ipswich School and he is more often identified in the records as a scrivener, but he was most certainly talented in the making of pageants (including a ship carrying actors who spoke lines) and the production of shows (including the writing of the speeches for those actors) on behalf of the town.

div.p: John Kynge (f 237v) is identified in the records as a scrivener and schoolmaster, though there is no indication that he was the headmaster of Ipswich school. He was talented in the making of pageants and staging of celebrations, shows and dramatizations, which the town hired him to do between 1578 and 1584, at which point he appears to have had a falling out with the town's officials and ceased to perfom those services thereafter.

row.cell: paid william buckrome the 12th of december .84. for Sixe yardes of blewe cloth for 4 leueries for the waytes at 10 s. the yarde

div.p: William Buckenham was presumably a tailor in that he routinely supplied blue cloth and made livery coats for the Ipswich waits between 1585 (when he was referred to as William Buckrome) and 1593–4. Mistress Buckenham, perhaps his wife, conducted the transaction in 1589–90. Between 1607–8 and 1619–20 Henry Buckenham, perhaps their son, made three similar payments.

row.cell: paid to Thomas Keele & his company for musicke at the Guylde, as bi warrant appereth
paid to my Lord Admyralles players the thethe the: dittography xxth of ffebruary bi commaundement
paid bi commaundement to my lorde of Essex players

div.p: Thomas Keele (f [4v]) was master of a company of musicians that briefly served, during a three-year period, as the town's waits. The records mention them in 1583–4, 1584–5, and here in 1585–6. The brevity of their tenure suggests that their hire was an interim measure at best. The company of William Martin that preceeded them served for twenty-one years, and John Bettes' company that followed them would serve for twenty years, from 1587 through 1607.
Charles Howard (f [5]; c 1536–1624) was lord high admiral from 1585, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Robert Devereux (f [5v]; 1565–1600/1) was nineteenth earl of Essex from 1576, with seat at Cassiobury House, near Watford, Hertfordshire. See P&P.
The next dated entry after the Essex payment is St Matthew's Day, 21 September, so the payment to Essex's players occurred sometime before that date.

row.cell: paide Iohn Minter the 9th of Marche by warrante
paide Richard Minter for his service for playinge vppon the drome in master Cutlers tyme
payde Richarde Mynter for playinge vppon the drome in master Mares tyme
paide Iohn Minter for Triminge the drome

div.p: In the audited accounts of Tooley's foundation (BL: Add MS 25343), John Mynter was paid 3s 4d for making four women's gowns (f 156v), and 3s 6d for making three pair of breeches and two pair of hose (f 156). John Minter was the town's drummer. Richard Minter succeeded him as the town's drummer.

div.head: f 84 7 January)
div.ab: wheras request is made by lettres from Sir ffrauncis walsingham knight Sir … knight: Francis Walsingham (c 1532–90) was secretary of state to Elizabeth I ‸aswell touching the Musitians wages of this Towne, dewe this yere by the Towne as also fos ‸for the colleccion of the benevelence of the Inhabitantes of this Towne, yt is Agred that they shall haue ther wages being iiij li. dewe by the Towne paid to them & for the rest commyng of the benevolence of the Towne Inhabitant of the Towne they shall collect that them selues/ And yt is furder agred that they shall not be chardged with x s. delyuerd to ballard nor with viij s. paid for his herse hyer to london, nor to v s. geven to the pursyvant which is for the said Musitcions

div.p: Francis Walsingham (c 1532–90) was secretary of state to Elizabeth I

div.head: ff 89v–90 (15 July)
div.ab:
wheras ther ben Appoynted vnder the chardge of Master Capten Carye twelue persons for the Towne to the seruice of the lowe Contries Contrye/ It is Agreed that those xij persons shall haue allowed to them seuerally ij s. vj d. of the Townes gyfte whiche is Agreed that the chamberlens shall paie presently & that Iohn Cressye
alias Mynster the yonger Apoynted for A dromme shall haue geven to him v s. towardes his Aparell & thes ben the names of the xij soldiers videlicet paule Grympston Robert Wollett William Wodes Edward Poughe Iohn Knagges Valentyne ffreman Lyonell Aylward Heue Goslyn Rychard Keye Iohn Robertson William Astyn & Rychard cake

div.p: The next entry in the Assembly book confirms that three of the soldiers (Grympston, Freman, and Wollett) had been prisoners in the jail before being impressed into service.

Item paid too my Lord admyralls players

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (f 2v; 1533-1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.
Charles Howard (c 1536-1624) (f 3v) was lord high admiral from 1585, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.

Queen's Children of the Chapel (f 4) whose patron was Elizabeth I (1533-1602/3). The Children of the Chapel was a company of boys first formed in its Tudor iteration in 1501, whose patrons were the successive Tudor monarchs through Elizabeth I, and thereafter with a revised name under the Stuarts. The company performed both musically and in drama, mainly for the Court until c 1585. Thereafter through 1592 they performed both provincially and in the commercial theatres of London. Many of the boys had been impressed (because of their talent) from choral schools around the kingdom - a process not always appreciated by the schools, who saw it as the poaching of their best talent. The boys wore brightly coloured gowns, coats, and bonnets; court records show that they enjoyed considerable financial support for their sustenance, educations, and the complexities of their travels to perform. See E.K. Chambers, The Elizabethan Stage, vol 2 (Oxford, 1923), 23–61).
Edward de Vere (1550-1604), was seventeenth Earl of Oxford, with residence at Plaistow House, Essex. See P&P
Henry Radcliffe (1533-1593), suceeded as 9th Earl of Sussex in 1583, with residence at New Hall, Essex. See P&P.

div.head: f 121v (20 October)
div.ab:
Itorder for
musitions is furderIt is furder: in display script agreed that Iohn Bettes musitian with his companye to the nomber of ffoure persons shall Inioye the offyce of the weyghtes within this Towne to serue in that offyce ffrom the daye of the date herof vntyll assenscion daye next & that they shall procede ther aboutes nightlye from two of the Clock vntyll they have gone throughout the Towne And further that they shalbe at the commaundement of the Towne duryng the whole yere for furder seruice in ther musyck and therrbye it is agreed that they shall haue for ther salarye & wages this yere iiij li. & convenyent lyveryes of the Townes Chardge & besydes receyve the benevolence of the Inhabitantes of the Towne as Iohn Marten the late musitions hertofore have vsed to collect the same prouided it is agreed that the said waytes shall prouide them ther cognizances of ther owne charg.echarg.e: likely a misplaced

row.cell:
To Bettes the waight player & his company for ther servis done one the Quens Daye 6 s. 8 d.
To Grenelefe for his paines taken the same day 1 s. 8 d.
& to Iohn Mynter for playnge one ye drome ye same day 1 s. 8 d.
to Mister Buckenom for .6. yeardes of blewe cloth for Lyveris for the waight plaiers
Item to Iohn Bettes the waight player of this Towen and his company
Item The 18 of Aprill to my Lord of Sussex his Plaiers
Item To my Lorde Shandoes plaiers
Item To the Earle of Essex his Plaiers
Item The 14. of September to the Earle of Lesiter his plaiers

div.p: The three payments on f [3v] have been bracketed together, with the total for the three entered in the columns at the right. John Bettes was master of the company of waits that served in Ipswich for twenty years, between 1587 and 1607. The chamberlains' account for 1601–2 identifies the variously spelled John Grenlef senior as being responsible for pressed soldiers (possibly former prisoners). He received 10s for conducting the soldiers to Snape, and 9s for supplying shoes for six of them. Both he and his son, John Grenleaf jr (so spelled) were tasked with responsibility for the soldiers. At a supper for nine of them, the younger Greenleaf was also reimbursed for his own supper C/3/3/2/34,unnumbered addendum (see also Webb, Town Finances, p 145).

John Cressey, alias Minter, was the town drummer between 1587 and 1604–5 (the last time he appears in the records). The city routinely financed his annual wages, his livery, and his repairs to drums. In 1594–5 it also paid him for mending the civic ensigne using levant, white taffeta, and black silk. In 1608–9 the city paid one Richard Minter for two days' service with his drum.

William Buckenham (f [7]) was presumably a tailor in that he routinely supplied blue cloth and made livery coats for the Ipswich waits between 1585 (when he was referred to as William Buckrome) and 1593–4. Mistress Buckenham, perhaps his wife, conducted the transaction in 1589–90. Between 1607–8 and 1619–20 Henry Buckenham, perhaps their son, made three similar payments.
Henry Radcliffe (1533-93) was ninth earl of Sussex (f [8v]) from 9 October 1583 with residence at New Hall, Essex. See P&P.
Giles Brydges (c 1548–93/4) was third Baron Chandos from 11 March 1572/3, with seat at Sudley Castle, Gloucester. See P&P.
Robert Devereux (1565-1600/1) was nineteenth earl of Essex from 1576, with seat at Cassiobury House, near Watford, Hertfordshire. See P&P.
Robert Dudley (1532 or 1533–88) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564 with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: ReceivedReceived: in display script of Iohn Bettes & Raffe owenden musitiones towardes ther leveris
Item geven to the Queenes players the xvij of December at the commandement of Mr Bayliffes
Item payd to Iohn mynter for his paynes taken with his Drome, by warant
Item geven to the Erell of Sussex playeres by Mr Bayliffes commandement the ffryst of march
Item payd to Iohn bettes & his company Mvsitiones of This Towne for ther yers ffee ended at Mihillmes 1589
Item geven to ye Queenes Players xxij of may by Mr Bayliffes commandement
Item payd by a warant the 29 of may toward Iohn Mynter levery this yeare
Item payd the vij of Ivne for the leveries for the Musitiones
Item payd for paper & thred to bynd vpp the gvnpowder agaynst the Coranation day & a other day of tryvmphe
Item payd to Hvghe Shill for powder by him delivered to the Town vse on the Coronacion day & at a nother day after for tryvmphe by warant

div.p: John Bettes (f [4]) was master of a company of musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1587–8 and 1607. Their initial hiring coincides with the city's celebration of Coronation Day after its three-year absence from the records and the troupe received payment 'for "ther servis done one the Quens Daye,' as did one Grenelefe and the drummer John Mynter. Raffe Owenden appears to have been fellow master of Bettes' company, if, as is most likely, he is the Rauff Oldham so described in 1590, 1591, and 1592–3, 1593–4,1594–5, and 1596–7. In 1595 Bettes and Oldham were jointly granted a licence freely to go 'beyonde the seas this sommer next.'
Elizabeth Tudor (f [5] 1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

John Cressey, alias Minter, was the town drummer between 1587 and 1604–5 (the last time he appears in the records). The city routinely financed his annual wages, his livery, and his repairs to drums. In 1594–5 it also paid him for mending the civic ensigne using levant, white taffeta, and black silk. In 1608–9 the city paid one Richard Minter for two days' service with his drum.
Henry Radcliffe (1533–93) was ninth earl of Sussex from 9 October 1583 with residence at New Hall, Essex. See P&P.

During this period, Coronation Day (f [7v]) remained as the primary annual civic spectacle (following the earlier demise of Corpus Christi)that was sponsored by the guild. Occasional payments (such as the building of stages and pageants) indicate that the event characteristically included mimetic elements. Triumphs, which begin to appear in the accounts in the wake of the victory over the Spanish Armada, appear to have included patriotic militaristic enactments, given the purchases of gunpowder. That is, the celebration would have had elements of 'story.' The use of gunpowder also occurred on Coronation Day, as the payment on f [8] shows.

div.head: f 5 (12 November)
div.ab: Item yt is agreed that Mr bailiffes shall haue Au Auctorytie to devise take order to make procure suche shewe & triumphe in the Quenes daie next commyng as they shall thinke mete at the chardg of the Towne

Item payd by warent to Iohn mentter for .3. drome heades.3. ss. & for .3. dayes playinge on the drome 6 ss. some of both ys

div.p: The waits (f [5]) at this time were the company of John Bettes and Raffe Owenden.
Edward Seymour (1561–c 1612), son of Edward, earl of Hertford, was Lord Beauchamp (f [6]) from 1561, with residence at Elvetham, Hampshire. See P&P.

'lord sangaye' (f [6]) remains unidentified, and other evidences of that name have not yet come to light. One wonders if the Ipswich scribe of these accounts pronounced Sankey as Sangaye. If so, Lord Sangaye may have been Thomas Sankey (d. 1592), lord of Sankey Hall, Cheshire, who had been granted the lordship of Sankey Hall and other lands in Warrington and Sankey by Robert Dudley, lord of Warrington (of which Sankey formed part).
Robert Devereux (1565–1600/1) was nineteenth earl of Essex from 1576, with seat at Cassiobury House, near Watford, Hertfordshire. See P&P.
Charles Howard (c 1536–1624) was lord high admiral (f [6v]) from 1585, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Henry Radcliffe (1533–93) was ninth earl of Sussex from 9 October 1583, with residence at New Hall, Essex. See P&P.

'mentter' (f [8]) was John Cressey, alias Minter, the town drummer between 1587 and 1604–5 (the last time he appears in the records). The city routinely financed his annual wages, his livery, and his repairs to drums. In 1594–5 it also paid him for mending the civic ensigne using levant, white taffeta, and black silk. In 1608–9 the city paid one Richard Minter for two days' service with his drum.

row.cell: Item paid to mistris buekenham for vj yardes of Azur Clothe for foure liueries for Iohn bettes & his Company the waightes At viij s. the yard As by warrant

div.p: The clerk who paginated the account gives a new number to every side of every leaf, but he precedes each of those page numbers with a 'fo' (for 'foliation) not a 'p' (for 'page'), leaving the impression that the original account is foliated, which it is not.

Mistress Buckenham was likely the wife of William Buckenham who was presumably a tailor in that he routinely supplied blue cloth and made livery coats for the Ipswich waits between 1585 (when he was referred to as William Buckrome) and 1593–4. Between 1607–8 and 1619–20, Henry Buckenham, perhaps their son, made three similar payments. John Bettes was master of the company of waits that served in Ipswich for twenty years, between 1587 and 1607.

div.head: f 150 (2 November)
div.ab:
Item it isItem it is: in display script agreed at this Court that the musitions & waytes of thisorder for the
waytesTowne shall contynewe in ther offices this yere accordyng to ther former retayner for such wages lyveris & ffees as heretofore hathe ben allowed them and that they shall have from henceforth tyll the feast of the annunciacion of our lady next & so forthe this yere as Master baliffes for the Tyme being shall thinke mete and in Consideracion therof it is agreed that if they have a fyfte man into ther Company that then ffyfte man shall also have a lyvery only as the other, Provided it is agreed that Iohn Bettes & Rauff oldham shalbe only masters of ther company aforsaid & have the Ioynt Gouernement of the rest of ther company

div.p: 'menter' (f [6v]) was John Cressey, alias Minter, the town drummer between 1587 and 1604–5 (the final time he appears in the records). The city routinely financed his annual wages, his livery, and his repairs to drums. In 1594–5 it also paid him for mending the civic ensigne using levant, white taffeta, and black silk. In 1608–9, the city paid one Richard Minter for two days' service with his drum.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth 1 on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.
Thomas Burgh (f [9]; c 1558–97) was fifth Baron Burgh of Gainsborough from 10 September 1584, with residence at Gainsborough Hall, Gainsborough, Lincolnshire. See P&P.
Giles Brydges (c 1548–1593/4) was third Baron Chandos from 11 March 1572/3, with seat at Sudley Castle, Gloucestershire. See P&P.

row.cell: Item delyvered by warrant to William Cooke Musicion for two Coates one for him selfe thother for his boye two yardes ‸demi half blew brode clothe at vij s. yardtwo yardes … yard: added in the same hand above space filler after initial writing

div.p: William Cooke remains unidentifible with certainty. However, the fact that the town is providing livery strongly indicates that he was one of the waits. Further, an order made on 2 November 1590 (a year earlier) by the council concerning John Bettes' company of the waits had agreed that if they were to add a fifth man to their company, he should have livery like theirs. The order makes no mention of a boy but including a singing boy in the troupe was a practice current in Ipswich, as confirmed in an order made in 1613.

div.head: f [70] (29 September)(Treasury warrant)
div.ab:
To Thomas Sickemore treasorer
of the Towne of Ipswiche

Thes are to Require you to paye to Iohn Bettes and Rauff owdham musitions for ther halfe yere wages ended this day the somme of ffourty Shillinges and this shalbe your warrant in that behalfe this xxixth of September 1591

div.p: Warrants of this kind were usually conveyed to one or another of the town's officials by the bailiff, reflecting a decision by the Assembly or the Great Court (Webb, Town Finances, p 6).

div.p: Edmund Sheffield (f [5] 1565–1646) was third Baron and Lord Sheffield from 1568, with residences at Hammersmith, Middlesex, and in Yorkshire. See P&P.
Ambrose Dudley (f [6v]; 1528–89/90) was twenty-first earl of Warwick from 26 November 1561, with residences at North Hall, Northaw, Hertfordshire, and Warwick Castle, Warwickshire. See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (f [7]; 1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

John Minter alias Cressey (f 7) appears in Ipswich records as the town's drummer twenty-one times between 1571 and 1604-5. Payments indicate that the town's Great Court routinely paid for his livery coat; for his repairing of drums, ensigns and other gear; for his service as drummer on the Queen's Coronation Day; for the Queen's visit in 1571; and for drumming on other civic occasions. He was described in 1571 as being impoverished, but the antiquarian John Wodderspoon described him as 'an addition to the harmony of the town (Memorials, p 183). A second drummer, Richard Minter, appears in the records nine times between 1580-1 and 1590-1, invariably for his services at musters and other military events. His relationship to John Minter is unclear, but the records begin to refer to John as John Cressey alias Minter after Richard Minter begins to appear. A few other drummers appear throughout the Elizabethan, Jacobean and Caroline records of Ipswich: Thomas Fraunces for drumming and John Cooke for a drum case in 1559-60; Young Braine at the going forth in 1562-3, and William Braine (likely the same person) for two days' drumming in 1579-80; Peter Moone for drum sticks and heads in 1571-2, and John Meller for a drum head and case in 1573-4. Otherwide, John Minter controlled civic drumming, receiving his first warrant from the Great Court in 1576-7 and the first funding of his livery in 1588-9.
Robert Devereux (1565–1600/1) (f [7]) was nineteenth earl of Essex from 1576, with seat at Cassiobury House, near Watford, Hertfordshire. See P&P.

William Buckenham (f [7v]) was presumably a tailor in that he supplied blue cloth and made livery coats for the Ipswich waits between 1585 (when he was referred to as William Buckrome)and 1593–4. Mistress Buckenham, perhaps his wife, conducted the transaction in 1589–90. Between 1607–8 and 1619–20, Henry Buckenham, perhaps their son, made three similar payments. Four other individuals received payments for the same kinds of service to the waits through the years between 1607–8 and 1629–30 (Mr Warde, Thomas Ives, Edward Page, and Mr Cooper). Sometimes, rather than paying a tailor, the town simply gave the money to the waits leaving them to contract with the tailor. In those instances, the civic accounts obviously mention no tailor by name. The town provided money for the waits' livery a first recorded time in 1538 (the earliest surviving civic account)and for a final time in 1635–6. The town designated the treasurer as the officer responsible for funding the livery of the waits (see C/4/3/1/4 in 1608), while the chamberlain disbursed the waits' annual stipends and the rewards for their perfomances. The treasurer also paid for the livery of the drummer, sergeants, and beadle.
Henry Stanley (f [8]; 1531-1593) was thirteenth earl of Derby from 1572, with seats at Lathom and Knowsley, Lancashire. See P&P.
Charles Howard (c 1536-1624) (f 8) was lord high admiral from 1585-7, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.

div.p: John Bettes (f [5]) was master of a company of musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1587–8 and 1607. Raffe Owenden appears to have been fellow master of Bettes' company, if, as is most likely, he is the Rauff Oldham so described in 1590, 1591, and 1592–3, 1593–4, 1594–5 and 1596–7. In 1595 Bettes and Oldham were jointly granted a licence freely to go 'beyonde the seas this sommer next.'
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–March 1602/3) was crowned 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.
Edward Somerset (f 6; c 1550–1627/8) was ninth earl of Worcester from 21 February 1588/9, with seat at Raglan, Monmouthshire and residence at Hackney, Middlesex. See P&P.
Henry Herbert (c 1538–1601) was twenty-first earl of Pembroke from 17 March 1569/70, with seat at Cardiff Castle, residences at Ludlow Castle, Shropshire and Wilton, Wiltshire. See P&P.
Charles Howard ((c 1536–1624) was lord high admiral from 1585-27, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Edward Stafford (1536–1603), twelfth Baron Stafford from 1565/6, with residence at Stafford Castle, Staffordshire. See P&P.
Edward Parker (1551–1618) was twelfth Baron Morley from 22 May 1577 and twelfth Lord Morley from 22 October 1577 with residences at Hallingbury Place, Essex and Hornby Castle, Lancashire. See P&P.

John Fisher is identified on f [6] as one of the sergeants of the town, who performed a variety of tasks and services. For example, the burgesses reimbursed him for his charges incurred 'About the fetching of a Bucke obteyned by force of the Lord Chamberlain's warrant' (C/3/3/2/30, f [5]).
Giles Brydges (c 1548–1593/4) was third Baron Chandos from 11 March 1572/3, with seat at Sudley Castle, Gloucestershire. See P&P.
Henry Radcliffe (1533–93) was ninth earl of Sussex from 9 October 1583, with residence at New Hall, Essex. See P&P.

William Buckenham (f 15) was a tailor or clothier who supplied cloth to the waits. He did the same in 1587-8 (), and in 1591-2 (). His wife, Mistress Buckenham did so in 1589-90 (), and Henry Buckenham, his successor, did so in 1607-8 ()

div.head: f 54v (24 October)
div.ab: It is Agreed that there shalbe xlspaid by the towne towardes A shewe & speche to be made vppon Coronacion daie And th Alsoe ‸þat there shalbe pa del bestowed xls ‸to be spent the same daiein powder in the shewing & trayning of the ordern ordernarie ffoot soldiers of this towne /.

div.head: f 182v (11 November)
div.ab:
Vppon the peticion of Iohn Betts & Rauffe Oldham musicions A libertie graunted
to the musicions to
goe beyonde ye seasof this Towne touchinge libertie of the goinge beyonde the seas this sommer next, It is nowe Agreed at this Courte that the said musicions shall haue libertie accordinglie to goe & passe at there pleasure.

div.p: The records provide no further context for the 'waits' coming summer of journeys across the sea. However, it does appear that they were not being impressed but were rather going of their own volition for their own reasons. Waits often travelled within the kingdom during the summer and on holidays, usually having been hired for an occasion by a great lord (see, for example, the talented and much-traveled Grantham waits (Stokes, Lincolnshire, vol 2, pp 448–9). However, evidence of travel overseas by waits is more unusual. Another East Anglian company, five waits of Norwich, accompanied Sir Francis Drake on his expedition in 1589 to destroy Spanish ships that had sought shelter in the Bay of Biscay, and to undertake other missions. As opposed to the Ipswich waits, however, the waits of Norwich had been impressed and during the campaign three of them would lose their lives (see David Galloway, Norwich, REED (Toronto, Buffalo, and London, 1984), pp 395–6).

John Bettes (f 19v) was master of a company of musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1587–8 and 1607. Rauffe Oldham is identified as fellow master of Bettes' company in 1590, 1591, 1592–3, 1593–4, 1594–5, and 1596–7. In 1595 Bettes and Oldham were jointly granted a license freely to go 'beyonde the seas this sommer next.'

John Cressey, alias Minter, (f 20) was the town drummer between 1587 and 1604–5 (the last time he appears in the records). The city routinely financed his annual wages, his livery, and his repairs to drums. In 1594–5 it also paid him for mending the civic ensigne using levant, white taffeta, and black silk. In 1608–9 the city paid one Richard Minter for two days' service with his drum.

div.p: The heading of this account dates it as being from Michaelmas (29 September) 1596 until . The previous treasurer's account runs from 25 March to 29 September 1596, and the treasurer's account following this one runs from Michaelmas 1597 to Michaelmas 1598, so this account is clearly 1596–7.

div.head: f 201 (22 March)
div.ab:
It is Agreed at this courte that there shall noe Guylde beAn order for not
Kepinge of ye Guylde holden or kept duringe this yere to come in respecte of the dearthe.

And it is Agreed that the Musicions of this Towne shalbe dischardged the Musicions
Dischardged of there
Former Retyner of there former Reteyner And that there shalbe noe money payde them for there wages after our ladie next by the town.

div.p: The dearth which caused the annual guild feast to be cancelled in this year would have been a severe shortage of corn (for brewing) and other food supplies caused by famine. It seems reasonable to think that the town discharged its waits for the same reason.

div.ab: Upon this same date is found the record of an addition to the harmony of the town, in the appointment of a town drummer
It is recorded that "Iohn CrossleyCrossley: ie, Cressy alias Minter is elected to be drummer to the town, and shall have yerely a livery and thirty shillings."

div.p: The original order from which Wodderspoon is taking his summary is a General or Great Court book, SA, Ipswich: C/2/2/2/1, f 216v, which identifies the date when the waits were appointed as being 16 November. Crossley (Cressey alias Minter) was appointed on the same day. On 16 December 1599 Minter remitted a fine for not paving in front of his house, but he subsequently made the payment. He appears every year among the guild's twenty-four council members (SA, Ipswich: C/2/2/3/1).

div.head: f 216v (16 November)
div.ab:
Attmusicions Reteyned this Courte Iohn Bettes & his Companye scilicet hughe wakefeld Allexander Thomas & Iohn Allen are Reteyned to be the musicions of this Towne from michaelmas last duringe the Townes plesure And to walke aboute the Towne with there weightes from michaelmas vntell our ladie daie, And it is Agreed that the said Iohn Bettes shall haue paid him in satisfaccion for his peynes with his said Companie ffoure poundes A yere to be paid quarterlie the first paiement thereof to begynne Att christmas next And that they shall haue Allowed them euerie yere that they shall make them liveries
Twelue shillinges A pece seas they shall goe decentlie Aparelled prouided that the said Iohn Bettes shall not att any tyme hereafter take any person into his Companye dwellinge out of this Towne without the Consent of the Bayliffes for the tyme beinge. & the Rest of the Portmen or the most of them, And that they shall Attende vppon the Towne as heretofore they haue done/

div.p: John Bettes was master of a company of musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1587–8 and 1607.

div.head: f 81v (29 September–29 September) (Treasurer's payments of fees, wages, and liveries)

row.cell: Item payd to Iohn Cressie alias Mynter by Consente of a greeat Court held on the xxte of October in the xxxix yere of her maiesties Raigne towardes his liuery as appereth by warrant dated the xix of Iuly laste
Item payde to Iohn Cressye alias Mynter for his yeres wages for sowndinge the Towne drome ended att michaelmas last past as appereth by warrante

div.p: John Cressey, alias Minter, was the town drummer between 1587 and 1604–5 (the last time he appears in the records). The city routinely financed his annual wages, his livery, and his repairs to drums. In 1594–5 it also paid him for mending the civic ensigne using levant, white taffeta, and black silk. In 1608–9 the city paid one Richard Minter for two days' service with his drum.

div.p: John Bettes (f [4]) was master of a company of musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1587–8 and 1607. Their initial hiring coincides with the city's celebration of Coronation Day after its three-year absence from the records and the troupe received payment 'for "ther servis done one the Quens Daye,' as did one Grenelefe and the drummer John Mynter.
John Cressy, alias Mynter, (f [5]) was the town drummer, who often performed with the waits.

div.p: George Hastings (f [3v]; 1540–1604) was twenty-first earl of Huntingdon from 1595, with residence at Dale, Derbyshire. See P&P.

The two payments to players on f [4] are part of a cluster of payments enclosed by the scribe's brackets, all having to do with proclamations, inquests, entertainment of noblemen, and performances. The records do not indicate whether the brackets serve to indicate that all the entries are part of what was a single great event.

div.head: f 216 (30 July)
div.ab: It is Agreed that th Iohn Bettes & his companye shall contynue f musicians of this towne vntell michaelmas next & then for there ordenarye wages yf vsinge them selues well & then to be dischardged, And that they shall haue noe newe lyveries for this yere/ geven them for this yere

div.p: The day of this assembly survives, but the part of the leaf giving the month is missing. However, the previous assembly was held on 18 July and the one following on 3 August, so this assembly must have been held on 30 July.

iiij li. xiiij s. vj d.

div.p: William Buckenham (f 162), presumably a tailor, made livery coats for the Ipswich waits between 1585 and 1593–4. Mistress Buckenham, perhaps his wife, conducted the transaction in 1589–90. Between 1607–8 and 1619–20, Henry Buckenham, perhaps their son, made three similar payments.

div.head: f 19v (5 August)
div.ab: Att this Assemblie Thomas Salter Thomas Muddes Alexander ‸Thomas Thomas Burrage Symon Minds & ffe Valentyne Wheyman It is Agreed that Thomas Salter & his Companye are Reteyned to be musicions of this towne to serue therein according to the Accustomed order during one yere ‸to come soeas they be of good behavior & shall haue there Accustomed wages & Al euerie one of them A lyverie coate Clothe for this yere to come/ betwene viij s. & x s. ye yard

more for ix yardes of blewe clothe att x s the yard for v musicions & kirke the bedell for there Coates

div.p: Between 1607–8 and the first half of 1613, Salter (f 170) was master of a company of six waits who served the town.

row.cell: Item paid by Mr Bailiffes appointment the 10 of Aprill 1610 to wy the quens players
Item to Iohn Garlande & Iosephe Tailour ‸players servauntes to the Duke of Yorke by Mr Bailiffes appointment by Warrant for their fee

div.p: Anne of Denmark (f [5]; 1574– 1618/19) was crowned queen of England on 25 July 1603. See P&P.

John Garland (f [6]; d. 1624) had been a member of the Queen's Men from 1583, apparently until the queen's death in 1603. He then served in the company of the Duke of Lennox and by 1610, as this payment shows, was serving the future Prince Charles, the Duke of York. Joseph Tailour (Taylor) was likely the person of that name who was baptised at St Andrew by the Wardrobe in Blackfriars on 6 February 1585/6, and who was a resident of Southwark for much of his life. He first turned up as a player in 1610, and must have joined the Duke of York's troupe only recently before this payment was made to him and Garland. He joined the troupe of Lady Elizabeth when it formed in 1611, so his stay with his original company, the Duke of York's, had been brief; however, he again joined the Duke of York's company (now known as Prince Charles' Men) in March 1616. From 1619 through 1642 he 'was one of the most prominent members of the King's company,' likely replacing Richard Burbage when he died. Taylor clearly became a distinguished theatre man, mentioned as a player in the First Folio, and in innumerable legal and financial documents; as yeoman of the Revels; as a shareholder in the Globe and Blackfriars theatres; and as a peerless actor in many of the most important plays of the period. When he died, he was buried at Richmond on 4 November 1652 (Edwin Nungezer, A Dictionary of Actors (New Haven, 1929; rpt 1968), 146–7, 366–72; G.E. Bentley, The Jacobean and Caroline Stage (Oxford, 1941; rpt 1966), vol 1: 198, 211 (John Garland); vol 2, 590-8 (Joseph Taylor)).
Charles Stuart (1600–48/9) was seventh duke of York from 6 December 1604/5 to 27 March 1625. See P&P.

div.head: ff 120v–1 (7 January)
div.ab:
It is Agreed that Thomas Burrage Richard Lowe Iohn Stone & Symon Mynes shall paie It is Agreed that Alexander Thomas shall haue towardes the meyntenance of the Singing boye ‸nowe in the keping of the said allexander soe long as he shall contynewe to sing singing, amongest ‸the musicians of this towne then the residewe of the musicians And that the Residewe of the musicians besides the said Alexander shall paie iiij li. yerelie ‸to the said allexander towardes the meyntenance of the said singing boye quarterlie/ prouided if the said Thomas Richard Iohn & Symon residewe of the musicians shall paie leste the said Thomas shall prouide a boye with a better bo voyse then the said paiement to se ceise
And it is Agreed that the mony that is shalbe geven to ye singing boy from henceforthe shalbe devided equallie Amongest the said Thomas Burrag Richard Lowe Alexander Thomas Iohn Stone & Symon mynes

div.head: f 132 (17 June)
div.ab: It is Agreed Att this Assemblye by Att this Assemblie that it shall not be lawfull from henceforth for the Bayliffes of this towne for the tyme being or any of them to geue any Allowance to any pleyers ‸of enterludes þat shall Resorte to this towne to pleye nor geue leve to any ‸suche pleyers pleyers to pleye in the motehall at any tyme, And if any the said Bayliffes ‸of this towne or any of them shall doe contrarie to this Agrement that then the said Bayliffes or suche of them that shall hereafter geue any suche Allowance or ‸ leave to pleye in the motehall shall forfett for euerie suche offence euery of themthem: 2 minims for m xx s.

row.cell: Item to the musicions there yeres wages
xiij li. vj s. viij d.
Item to the Musicions by order of An Assemblie towardes there cloakes
Item payd the drumer for one day at ye show

div.p: The nature of the show is uncertain from the entry. The town drummer played his drum at musters and at 'the shewe of bowe and pike' (1633–4). But he also drummed at spectacles staged at civic celebrations and on guild days. For example, the order to pay his wages in 1599–1600 says that he was paid in that year to drum 'at all tymes when Nede require.' In that same account, the town also paid someone for 'makinge of the stage on the Queens day.' However, in 1614–15 the reference to 'the shewe' clearly refers to a specific presentational event but fails to provide context, military or otherwise.

div.head: f 154v (15 May)
div.ab: It is agreed also the Towen Muscianes shall have the monie yat is vsuallye alowd them for Cotes towardes the biinge of livery Cotes so as they notwithstanding have livery Cotes Clokes at ther owen Cherge be Alowd the Towen

row.cell: Item paide to the towne Musicions for ther yeires wages
xiij li. vj s. viij d.

ab.del:
22 october 1613 musicians order entred
15 May 1615 An order for musitions clokes from Cotes

div.p: These two cancelled references-made on 30 August 1616 (f 191)-refer to earlier orders on ff 114v and 154v that had been made concerning the musicians. These two cancellations come in a summary section of cancelled entries referring to various orders between 4 February 1607 and 15 May 1615.

div.head: f 212 (15 July)
div.ab: It is Agreed that ‸Att this Assemblye Symon Mynes whoe one of the musicians of this towne shalbe is dischardged from his place for his that offence for his misbehavior for that he hath vnlawfullie hathe ben Accused with car being Accused by begotten with two children one Alice Ward of whose bodye he confesseth he had the vse severall tymes vnlawfullie to haue begotten her with withwith with: dittography child vnlawfullie, hathe confessed that whereof whoe hathe confessed that he haue had the vse of her bodie, And ‸it is Agreed that he shall not be suffred hereafter to be ‸o contynewe for oneof the Company of the musicions of this towne nor to weare the towne lyverie within this towne or in the company of of the said musicions or any of them

row.cell: Item to the Toune Musitians for there yeres wages
Item to Edward Page for one yarde & halfe of Cl bleue Clothe to make Symonde Myndes one of the Musitians A liuerye Coate att x s per yarde
Item to the Toune Musicions in monye insteade of Clothe as by warrant

div.p: Symond Myndes (or Symon Minds, f 248) first appears in the records in 1609 as a member of Thomas Salter's company of waits. He continued as a member of that troupe in 1613 when Thomas Burrage replaced Salter as the troupe's master. In 1616–17 Myndes was discharged as a member of the waits for unlawfully begetting two children, but he had been reinstated by the following year when the town paid for his livery coat, describing him as one of the musicians.

row.cell: Item payd by warent to the prinncs & the duke of lennox trumpetor
Item payd by warent to the quenes magestes players
Item payd by warent to the Kings magestes pleyers

div.p: Henry Frederick Stuart (1593/4–1612) was prince (f [3]) until the time of his death. See P&P.
Ludovic Stuart (1574–1623/4) was second duke and earl of Lennox from 1583, second duke of Richmond from 17 May 1623, with seat at Richmond Castle, Yorkshire, North Riding. See P&P.
Anne of Denmark (1574–1618/19) was crowned queen of England on 25 July 1603. See P&P.
James Stuart (f [3v]; 1566– 1625), was crowned James I of England on 24 March 1602/3. See P&P.

row.cell: Item to the Towne Musicions for there yeres wages
Item to himhim: Henry Buckenhamfor 9 yardes of blewe to make 6 musicions there liuerie Coates att 10 s per yarde

div.p: Henry Buckenham (f 260) was likely the son of William Buckenham, presumably a tailor who made livery coats for the Ipswich waits between 1585 and 1593–4, and Mistress Buckenham, likely the wife of William, who herself conducted transactions with the waits in 1589–90. Henry appears in his capacity as supplier of livery cloth to the waits between 1607–8 and 1619–20.

row.cell: Item giuen vnto the Ladye Elizabeths plaiers & to the princes plaiers

div.p: Elizabeth Stuart (1596–1661/2), daughter of James and Anne was crowned queen of Bohemia on 7 November 1619, with residences in Europe from 1613. See P&P.
Charles Stuart (1600-1648/9) was prince from 1612. See P&P.

div.p: Henry Buckenham (f 260) was likely the son of William Buckenham, presumably a tailor who made livery coats for the Ipswich waits between 1585 and 1593–4, and Mistress Buckenham, likely the wife of William, who herself conducted transactions with the waits in 1589–90. Henry appears in his capacity as supplier of livery cloth to the waits between 1607–8 and 1619–20.

div.p: Charles Stuart (1600–1648/9) was Prince of Wales from 1612 to 1625 (his accession as King of England). See P&P.

div.ab: It is agreed that the Office of blowinge the Trumpe & the fees there unto belonginge shallbe exercised & enjoied by Phillippe Courtnall from henceforthe duringe the Townes pleasure./.

row.cell: to the Towne Musicions for there wages
xiij li. vj s. viij d.
payde for ix yardes of fine blewe clothe to make Coates for the Musicions att x s the yard
to the Musicioners there yeres wages
xiij li. vj s. viij d.
for ix yardes of blewe Clothe to make the Musicions liveries
paid to ye plaiers which did shew the sightes att the ffryers per warrant

div.p: Likely 'the ffryers' refers to the former Blackfriars priory land and structures that the town had purchased 'as a municipal house for the poor' in 1568. The property received its charter as Christ's Hospital in 1572 (Frank Grace, 'The Growth of Oligarchical Government c. 1550-1660,' in Allen, Ipswich Bough Archives, p xxx). However, medieval Ipswich had once had at least seven Friars' houses and four hospitals.

div.head: f 86 (28 January)
div.ab: Att this Assemblie it is ordered & Agreed that the musicioners of this Towne shall Contynue there goeinge About this Towne vntell our ladie next & shall make there Colleccions About this Towne as the have formerlie done And that there former Reteyner of the beinge the Townes musicioners shall Cease & be me determined att our ladie next whereof there was notice geven to the said musicioners att this Assemblie

div.head: f 90 (3 November)
div.ab: Alsoe it is Agreed that Att this Assemblye Thomas Burrage Richard lowe Henrie Storie Iohn Stone Iarrett Barrie & Iohn Hyde shalbe are Reteyned to be Musicioners of this Towne from Michaelmas next last for one yere And ‸it is Agreed that they shalle goe About this Towne as they have vsuallie done mor iiijermorninges in euerie wee viz Mondaie tuesdaie Thursdaie & Satterdaie, And Attend & plaie Att Mr Bailiffes & the Comen Counce of this Towne Aswell vppon euerie solempe feast daie as vpp att other tymes when any of them shall Requier them to paie Come to there houses freelie without haveinge or expectinge any gratuitie for ther paynes besides there other then there dyett And that they shall have paid them by the treasurer of this Towne towardes ‸for there wages & paynes in that behalfe xiij li. vj s. viij d. & there liveries which they shall Constantlie weare/ with there Cognizances

div.p: Elizabeth Stuart (f 5; 1596–1661/2) was daughter to James and Anne; she was crowned queen of Bohemia 7 November 1619, with residences in Europe from 1613. See P&P.

div.head: f 103 (1 June)
div.ab: Att this Assemblie it is Agreed that There shalbe paid vnto Thomas Burrage Henrie Storie & the Rest of there Companie xiij li vj s viij d for there yeres wages from Michaelmas last to Michaelmas next for beinge the Townes Musicioners And for that the said Companie have neglected to weare there liverie Coates Accordinge to there former Reteyner, it is thought fitt & Agreed that the old Coates will serue & that they shall have no newe Coates this yere

div.head: f 106v (20 October)
div.ab: Allsoe Att this Assemblie Thomas Burrage Henrie Storie Richard lowe And the Rest of there Companie are Reteyned to be the Townes Musicioners for one yere from Michaelmas last Accordinge to there former Reteyner

row.cell: to the Towne Musicions there wages
for 9 yardes of Clothe att x s the yard for the Musicions Liveries
paid the Musitions by warrant for theire paines the fyft of November & other tymes
paid the Musitions for theire paines att the yeild feast
paid the Musitions for theire paines of the Coronation daye
Item paid to william Perry one of his Maiesties Reuellers a reward per warrant

div.p: William Perry was manager of the King's Revels when it visited Norwich on 24 May 1613, and he was mentioned in a licence given to the company on 17 February 1615. The troupe would visit Norwich on 17 July of that same year. Although the licence would be withdrawn from the company by the Master of the Revels, Sir Henry Herbert,the earl of Pembroke in 1616, the company was recorded in provincial revels until 1617. Perry was then a patentee of the Queen's Revels when it visited Norwich in 1618. Following the queen's death in 1619 the troupe became known as the Children of the Revels to the late Queen Anne; it was apparently disbanded by September 1619. On 18 September 1619 Perry 'received a commission to organize a group of players under the title of "His Majesty's servants of the city of York".' On 10 November 1619 Perry became co-manager of the Red Bull company and remained with them until 1641. During those years he was named in numerous provincial performance records. See, for example, David Galloway (ed), Norwich 1540–1642 REED (Toronto, Buffalo, and London, 1984), pp 143, 151, 157, 171–2, 175, 210–11, 213–14, 223, 363–4).

row.cell: paid to the Musitions for theire paines taken with theire Instrumentes att the Guildfeast kept this yeire and att the entertainment of the Right honorable the Lord keeper att his beinge here by warrant
paid to Mr william Sparrowe which he disbursed and laid out towardes the Entertainment of the Right Honorable the Lord Keeper att his beinge in Ipswich by warrant

div.p: Henry Montagu (f 384v, 1563–1635), first earl of Manchester, of Boughton, Northamptonshire, was lord keeper of the Privy Seal from 1628 to 1642.

row.cell: Payd to Thomas Burrage and the rest of the musytions for theyr atendance on Mr Bayliffes on the Cronation Daye
for giuen his Maiesties playeres as per warrant

div.p: Thomas Burrage first appears in the Ipswich records in 1609 as one of six musicians serving as the town's waits in a company whose master was Thomas Salter. By 1613, Burrage had replaced Salter (who disappears from the records) as master of the company, which now had five musicians and a singing boy. Burrage held that position until 1637, when the waits stopped appearing in the records. Entries in the records through the years also indicate that Burrage's company had permission to travel to perform whenever they had a licence from the town to do so. Burrage died in early 1669.
Charles Stuart (1600–48/9) was crowned Charles I of England on 27 March 1625. See P&P.

div.head: f 115 (18 January)
div.ab: Allsoe it is Agreed that there shalbe bestowed vppon ‸Thomas Burrage & the Rest of the Musicioners for there paynes taken with there Instrumentes vppon the vth of November last xxxs to be paid by the Treasorer

div.head: f 116v (30 April)
div.ab: Att this Assemblie it is agreed that there shalbe bestowed vppon the musicions for there paynes taken vppon the last Coronacion daye xx s to be paid by the Treasorer

row.cell: to Thomas Burradge & the Rest of the Compannie for there theire paines taken with theire Instrumentes vppon the Corronacion daye by warrant
to Thomas Burradge & the Rest of his Compannie for theire paines taken with theire Instrumentes the fyft of november by warrant.
Item paide to Thomas Burrage And the rest of the musicioners ffor their paines taken with there Instrumentes the xxtie daie of Awgust when the Townsmen of Colchester were here as aforesaide xx s.

Item Given to william daniell and his Company his Maiesties players As a Gratuety bestowed vpon them being his Maiesties players by the Towne to the end they should depart the Towne And not playe xiij s. iiij d.

div.p: Thomas Burrage (f [5]) first appears in the Ipswich records in 1609 as one of six musicians serving as the town's waits in a company whose master was Thomas Salter. By 1613 Burrage had replaced Salter (who disappears from the records) as master of the company, which now had five musicians and a singing boy. Burrage held that position until 1637, when the waits stopped appearing in the records. Entries in the records through the years also indicate that Burrage's company had permission to travel to perform whenever they had a licence from the town to do so. Burrage died in early 1669.

This visit involved an invitation by the officials of Ipswich to the townsmen of Colchester to attend a meeting to render an account concerning a Mr Harwick's gift. This page of the Chamberlains' Account records payments for provisions provided to the Colchester townsmen and musical entertainment by the waits at the meeting. Mr Harwick's identity is unclear, but his gift appears to have been large and to have been related to maritime matters concerning the port at Ipswich, since the portmen, among others, attended the meeting.

Between 1611 and 1637, William Daniel (f [6]) was associated with various iterations of the king's performers, an itinerant troupe. Between 1611 and 1623 'the King's Players,' led by him, performed several times at Canterbury. The King's Revels, with which he was subsquently associated, may have been the same company. On 18 November 1634 Daniel led a group of well more than five other actors who received a license to perform as 'the King's Revels.' In the three years between 1634–5 and 1636–7, this group is recorded at Coventry, Norwich, and Gloucester, in addition to Ipswich. See David Galloway (ed), Norwich 1540–1642 REED (Toronto, Buffalo, and London, 1984), 176, 220–1, 363–4; R.W. Ingram (ed), Coventry REED (Toronto and Buffalo, 1981), 353, 414, 437, 439–40, 597; and Audrey Douglas and Peter Greenfield (eds), Cumberland, Westmorland and Gloucestershire REED (Toronto, Buffalo, and London), 326.

div.head: ff 304v–5 (26 November)
div.ab:
That Mr Ward in his sermons by him made in St Mary tower Church in Ipswich in Anno Domini 1634 hath insinuated vnto his Auditory that there was cause to feare an Alteracion of Religion in the Kingdome.
That Mr Ward November 1633 hath preached by way of opposition to his Maiesties declaracion concerning recreations to bee permitted on the Sundayes. All which ye premises partly out of the Confession & personall aunsweres of the said Mr Ward & partly out of the deposicions of the witnesses examined ex parte officij against him the Court conceaued to be proued against Mr Ward, and pronounced him guilty of preaching all the said scandalous tenentes and positions formerly mencioned. And for that some of the said positions tended to the depraving of all sett formes of Prayer and the whole Leaturgie of the Church of England established by act of Parliament, some others of the said positions or tenentes tending to the broaching & nourishing of Schisme, and to make a rent in the Church, some other to put the people in a feare of alteracion of religion, some against Reuerence vsed in the Church, as also against conformity to his Maiesties Late instructions, as likewise against his Maiesties Late declaracion concerning Lawful Recreations to bee vsed on Sundayes, And Lastly some of them tending to the ouerthrowe of all manner of gouerment both in the Church and Common wealth as the court conceaued and pronounced for these thinges in regard of the publike scandall and offence giuen, he was adiudged well worthy to bee punished, and first in partem pænæ he was adiudged a man vnfitt to be continued Lecturer ‸there any longer and by sentence diffinitiue of the Court was remoued from his said Lecture & was suspended from the execucion of his Ministeriall function, and euery part thereof aswell there as else where.

div.p: The case was adjudicated at Lambeth before Thomas Mottershead, king's official. Ward's suspension was to stand until the king relaxed it, and Ward was to make a public submission and recantation orally and in published writing. He also had to pay court costs and was committed until he gave £200 bond.

div.head: f [70] (1 September) (Treasury warrant)
div.ab: we Requier you to paie vnto Thomas Burrage & the Rest of the musicioners Twentie Shillinges for there paynes taken with there Instrumentes the xxtie of August last when the Townesmen of Colchester were here And this shalbe your warrant geoven vnder our handes this first of September Anno domini 1635
To Thomas Knappes Robert Donckon Chamberlens
of the Towne of Ipswich

div.p: This order appears to have come to the chamberlains from the Great Court. The signatories, Edmund Keene and Thomas Seeley, served as the town's bailiffs in 1634–5. Keene had been chamberlain in 1614–15; Seely had served as a chamberlain in 1617-18 and treasurer in 1625–6.

div.head: f 129v (24 August)
div.ab: Allsoe it is Agreed that there shalbe xxs bestowed vppon the Musicioners for there paynes taken with there Instrumentes att when the ‸ maior &‸maior &: in red ink used for correctionsTownsemen of Colchester war att Ipswich the xxt of August last

div.head: f 131v (6 November)
div.ab: Att this Assemblie it is Agreed that there shalbe xxs paid by the Chamberlens of this Towne to Thomas Burrage & the Rest of the Musicions for there paynes taken yesterdaie with there Instrumentes on the behalfe of this Towne.

div.head: f 132 (16 December)
div.ab: Allsoe att this Assemblie Thomas it is Agreed that Thomas Burrage Henrie Storrie Iohn Stone Iarradd Berrie & Richard lowe Iunior shalbe the Townes Musicioners vntell Michaelmas next And shall goe About the Towne with there Instrumentes as formerlie they have done And that they shall have liverie Coates provided them att the Chardge of this Towne & xxs formerlie Agreed by Assemblie to be paid them And that they shall provide them a singinge boye soe sone as Convenientlie they maie

div.p: The year 1635 appears to be the last year in which Ipswich supported a company of waits. In 1637, 1638, and 1641 (see below), the city sought the best musicians available to play at official events. The records contain no references to musicians of any kind in 1639 and 1640.

row.cell: for 7 yardes & A halfe of blewe Clothe to make ffive Coates for Thomas Burrage Henrie Starre Iohn Stone Iarrad Burre & Richard Lowe Musicions of this Towne att x s.
To the Musicions for some service done by them this yere

div.head: f 138v (3 November)
div.ab: Att this Assemblie it is Agreed that there shalbe s the ‸ best Musicke provided Agenst the ffift of November next that maie be had & obteyned to plaie th vppon there Instrumentes before Master Bailiffes the portmen & xxiiijtie as Master Bailiffe shall thincke fitt

row.cell: And To Thomas Burradge Iohn Stone & the Rest of the Musicioners xx s for theire paynes taken with theire Instrumentes vppon vppon the fyft daye of November, last accordinge to Order Assemblie
To the Musitioners x s for theire paynes taken with theire Instrumentes the daye of the Kinges Coronacion
payed William Daniell one of his Maiesties seruantes of the Reuell for not Actinge here in Ipswich the second day of May 1637

div.p: Between 1611 and 1637 William Daniel was associated with various iterations of the king's performers, a touring troupe. Between 1611 and 1623 'the King's Players,' led by him, performed several times at Canterbury. The King's Revels, with which he was subsquently associated, may have been the same company. On 18 November 1634 Daniel led a group of more than five other actors who received a license to perform as 'the King's Revels.' In the three years between 1634–5 and 1636–7 this group is recorded at Coventry, Norwich, and Gloucester, in addition to Ipswich. See David Galloway (ed), Norwich 1540–1642 REED (Toronto, Buffalo, and London, 1984), 176, 220–1, 363–4; R.W. Ingram (ed), Coventry REED (Toronto and Buffalo, 1981), 353, 414, 437, 439–40, 597; and Audrey Douglas and Peter Greenfield (eds), Cumberland, Westmorland and Gloucestershire REED (Toronto, Buffalo, and London), 326.

div.head: single sheet (29 March)
div.ab: In the name of God Amen the xxixth day of March, Anno domini 1636 I Richard Lowe thelder of Ipswich in the County of Suffolk Musitian, being of sound and perfect mynde and memory (praysed be God) but yett and weake in bodie, hauing an intent and meaning to make and declare ‸ my will touching the disposicion of such worldly goodes and estate as God of his mercie hath bin pleased to leue me in this transitorie lief, doe publish and heerby declare such my intencion and meaning concerning the same as followeth Inprimis I giue vnto my deere and loving wiffe Sarah Lowe the summe of Thirtie powndes which Mr Iohn Ward Clarke Parson of Dinnington hath of myne, in his handes And ‸ all that money and plate goodes, Moveables, houshold stuffe, and personall estate which nowe, or att the tyme of my decease shall happen to bee in my possession, or of right belonging vnto me, To haue and enioye the same during the tearme of her naturall lief therewith to dispose att her will and pleasure, Provided notwithstanding the seuerall legacies heere ensuing be thereout deducted & defalted vizt I giue to my sonne Richard Lowe my Organ, a paire of Virginalles with a Vyall degam, a treable Vyallyn, A Bandore, A treable Cornett, with a siluer tipp therevpon, to be deliuered to him att his age of ffower and twentie yeeres, To my sonne William Lowe I giue A paire of Virginalles, A voyall Degam, A treable Vyollyn A Bandore, A Citherne, and a Cornett, And vnto Iohn my sonne I giue a paire of Virginalles, A Vyoll degam, a Citherne, and a Lute, these twoe last recited legacies to bee deliuered vnto my said twoe lastnamed sonnes att their seuerall ages of One and twentie yeeres Soe Constituting and appointing the said Sarah my wiffe sole Executrix of this my last will & Testament I doe pronounce and declare this present wryting to conteyne the same, wittnes my hand and seale heerunto sett and subscribed the day & yeere first abouewritten/

row.cell:
Sealed published and declared by the said
Testator as his last will & Testament the
presence of vs
Elisabeth. Em.Em.: Myles's markMyles her marke, wiffe of me
Edmund Myles Notary Publique//
Payd by warrant dated the xxith: of ffebruarie 1637 to Andrewe Keyne & his Company players beinge his Maiesties seruantes for nott playeinge in this Towne A gratuitie

div.head: f 150 (19 October)
div.ab: Allsoe it is Agreed that Mr Nashe Minister of Saint Marie att the Tower shalbe Intreated to preache att the Tower Churche the ffift of November next to And that the Bailiffes portmen & xxiiijtie shalbe Intreated to Mete att the Hall in the morninge of that daye & soe sollemplie to goe to Churche that daye as vsuallie they ‸ have done hathe done in there liverie Gownes And that Master Bailiffes shall provide the best Musicke they Canne gett to playe Afore them on lowde Musicke And that Mr Nashe shall have A pa xxs bestowed vppon him for his paynes in preachinge that sermon & xx Allsoe xxs for the sermon preached & preyers Reade vppon Michaelmas daye last And the said Musicions to have for there paynes ‸ As muche as Master Bayliffes shall thincke fitt

div.p: St Mary-le-Tower, on Tower Street, is 'the principal parish church of Ipswich' (Nicholas Pevsner, Suffolk, p 291).

row.cell: paid vnto one of those Accomptantes vppon warrant dated ye last of August 1640 for moneys by him disbursed (by the order of mr Bailiffes at their beinge at Colchester) to the poore to the musicions to the Ostler

div.p: Since Ipswich had stopped supporting its waits after 1637, the musicians being paid here seem most likely to have been the waits of Colchester, given that all the payments in this cluster appear to have occurred while the bailiffs were in Colchester.

div.head: f 162v (29 September)
div.ab: allsoe it is Agreed that there shalbe bestowed & geven to the Musicioners which latelie pleyed with there Instrumentes att the last yere the some of xls for there paynes & Chardges expended at that tyme

div.head: single membrane (29 September–29 September) (Money given)
div.ab: Idem computat datum ministrallis diuersorum dominorum in toto anno viij s.

div.head: single membrane (29 September–29 September) (Money given)
div.ab: The same (accountant) renders account of 8s given to minstrels of various lords during the whole year.

body.head: Suffolk, Jerningham of Somerleyton Hall 1582 SUWI21

div.head: ff 208–8v (20 August)
div.ab:
Also I doe giue vnto Ioane ffoole fower poundes in monney or twentye shillinges a yeeare as longe as she liveth whiche shalbe thought best for her at the discression of my executor my executor: her son, Henry Jerningham over and besydes thee ffower poundes yerely whiche was givenn her by my late husbande, and I giue vnto her one featherbed boulster and Coveringe and all theise premisses not otherwise excepte my sonne shall refuse to keepe her and maintaine her duringe her lief in his howse, the whiche I doe rather wish for him to keepe her for that shee hathe benne a Longe seruante, then to putt her awaye out of his house: Also from the tyme that Iohn Harvye shall not be kepte and maintayned in my Sonnes howse, I doe give to the poore foole an yerely Rent towarde his maintenance of fower markes by yeare I giue vnto Mr Marshall ffyftie three shillinges fower pence yf Iohn Harvey and Thomas ffreeman have nothing
given theme afore, or if my sonne doeth not keepe theme in his howse or other wayes provide for theme, I will that theie shall yearely haue ffortie shillinges a peece to be paide theme halfe yerely out of my Landes wheare I maie give yt:

div.p: The parish register of St Anne, Blackfriars, records the burial on 21 March 1579/80 of 'Willliam, fool to my Lady Jerningham,' who obviously had died before Lady Frances made her will (John Southerden Burn, Registrum Ecclesiae Parochialis: The History of Parish Registers in England, 2nd ed (London, 1872), 108). So, over the course of time she had at least three fools. The odd assortment of facts surrounding these entries defies simple and immediate conclusions. Whether they were merely 'innocents' (persons with cognitive disabilities) or performers is equally difficult to ascertain. However, John Southworth has shown that a fool could be both (Fools and Jesters at the English Court (Stroud, 1998), 105). Is Joane, as a female fool, a rarity? While female fools rarely appear in provincial records, a number of them do appear in court records, which show them taking part in performances at court, often in collaboration with a male fool, as happened at the court of Mary Tudor. Why did Lady Frances Jerningham in particular have so many fools? The ladies of Mary Tudor's court, like the queen herself, expressed great compassion and affection for female fools, bestowing great favours upon them (Southworth, Fools and Jesters, pp 100–6). Frances Jerningham would have experienced that court. She appears to have inherited Joane from her husband's care, and treated all three of her fools as servants of her household, who must (she was determined to ensure) be treated well after her death.

body.head: Suffolk, Kitson of Hengrave Hall 1572 SUKI09

div.head: p 191 (November)

div.p: The payment on f 64v seems to have been made not in Suffolk but in London, perhaps at the family residence in Coleman Street (Wasson, Plays and Players, p 165).
Elizabeth Jenks (Gynkes) (d. 1558) was Lady Rich, wife of Richard Rich, first Baron Rich.
Richard Rich (1496–1567) became first Baron Rich, of Felsted, Essex, lord chancellor 1547–52.

div.head: f 13 (October)
div.ab: In Reward by my master vnto Iohnson the musicion x s.

row.cell: In reward at my master his comandement to the lor L of Sussex musicions
In Reward to the Quenes players at my master his comandement

InNovember
Reward Reward to Mundes of Norwiche at my mistres comandement for amendinge the virgenalles

div.p: The reference on f 13 to Johnson, the musician who was paid 10s, likely refers to the musician and composer Edward Johnson, who 'was employed as a musician by the Kitson family at Hengrave Hall in Suffolk by 1572 and was still there in 1575 when he took part in the lavish entertainment that the Earl of Leicester mounted at Kenilworth for Queen Elizabeth' (David Brown, The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians (London, 1980), 676). John Wasson too affirms that 'Johnson was a musician with Kitson's household' (Plays and Players, p 165).

The lord of Sussex referred to on this same page was Thomas Radcliffe (1526–83), Lord Fitzwalter from 27 May 1542 and eighth earl of Sussex from 17 May 1556/7, with residences at New Hall, Essex, and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

body.head: Suffolk, Kitson of Hengrave Hall 1572 SUKI03

div.head: f 14v (December) (Rewards)
div.ab: In rewarde to Adames of Bury for playenge an interlude before my master in Christemas last xx s.

div.p: Festivities during the Christmas season at Hengrave extended through New Year's and the feast of the Epiphany. They ranged from plays like this one to activities more raucous and wide-ranging. In January, for example, Powle the glazier received 10s for replacing twenty feet of glass for windows in the inner court 'which was shaken downe by discherginge a gunne or twoo ther in the tyme of Chrystemas' (f 19). The family also paid in December for a dozen torches, for two barrels for tapers, and for three dozen wax lights; it also rewarded 2s 'to Bushe of Bury, paynter, for the paynting the bores heade with sondry colors (the December payments surviving only in Gage, History and Antiquities of Hengrave, pp 192–3).

body.head: Suffolk, Kitson of Hengrave Hall 1572/3 SUKI03

div.p: According to Gage, the person, on f 34, to whose home they are travelling was 'Sir Thomas Cornwallis (d. 13 May 1597), cousin of Lady Kitson, groom-porter to the Queen, of East Horsley, Sussex,' who was born at Broome, Suffolk (History and Antiquities of Hengrave, p 197).

div.head: f 94v (December) (Necessaries)
div.ab: PayedPayed: in display script; e smudged to Morten assmuch by him payed for a recorder vj s.vj s.: underlined

div.p: Concerning the house and master being referred to on f 61, Sir Thomas Kitson (1485–1540) had a house that included a chapel in London on Milk Street. One assumes that the master in these accounts, his son Sir Thomas Kitson, continued the Kitson ownership of that house.
All the payments from the one on f 61v through the one on f 62 to the musicians of Swan Alley were made in London.

In June (on f 45), Kitson's scribe also paid 3s to hire 'a man on mydsomer night with a corsellett to attend vppon my Lord maior,' and 2d for 'bowes' which could be anything from musical instruments to ribbons tht were part of livery.
My lord of Essex, whose players were paid on f 78v, was Walter Devereux (1539–76), eighteenth earl of Essex from 4 May 1572, with residences at Lamphey, Pembrokeshire, and Chartley, Staffordshire.

div.p: Concerning Barrowe on f 135v, Wasson identifies him as being 'the family physician, residing in Bury' (Plays and Players, p 166).
On the same f 135v, My lord of Leicester was Robert Dudley (1532 or 1533–88), fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex.
Thomas Radcliffe (c. 1526-9 June 1583) was 8th Earl of Sussex and Lord FitzWalter, with residence at New Hall, Essex. See P&P.

This reward on f 135v by Lady Kitson 'to certayne harvest fookes,' seems likely to have been given following their enacting of a customary end-of-harvest celebration of some kind. The lack of further detail in the accounts leaves the nature of the activity opaque.

div.head: f 224 (August)(Hengrave)
div.ab: In Reward to the musicians ij s. vj d./

row.cell: In Rewarde to Mr Bolderos man for bringinge Theapes
In Rewarde to Luke Sympson for settinge the virginalls
In Rewarde by Lawrence to one which broughte a paier of virginalls from Burye
Payde for the Caryage of certayne Instrumentes to walden And for A paier of Gymmers for the Cheaste wherein they were putt

div.p: Waldon (on f 238) is likely Walton, a place ten miles southeast of Ipswich, by the sea near Felixstowe. During the period of these accounts the manor of Walton was held by the Howard family, dukes and earls of Norfolk. The manor then encompassed most of Walton and Felixstowe. Walton had began its ancient life as an important Roman and medieval port and an inseparable part of Felixstowe, but because of the encroaching sea, it is now a modest village (Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 394–6). The specific nature of the instruments being conveyed, and the reason for carrying them to Walton is uncertain from the record.

body.head: Suffolk, Kitson of Hengrave Hall 1579/80 SUKI12

row.cell: geuen to the musiones at neu yeres tytet last
geuen to meg & mary at christmas lastchristmas last: ie, 1579 to Play at cardes with
geuen in reward to the quenes trompeters at mr K being last at London

div.p: Meg and Mary (f 2) were the daughters of Sir Thomas Kitson and Lady Elizabeth Kitson, of Hengrave Hall. Meg was Margaret Kitson (1560–82), nineteen years old in 1579. She married in 1580, but died at the age of twenty-two. Mary was Mary Kitson (1566–1644), who married Thomas Darcy, first lord Rivers in 1583. She was thirteen years old in 1579.
Elizabeth Tudor (f 52v; 1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

body.head: Suffolk, Kitson of Hengrave Hall 1583 SUKI03

row.cell: Geven to the musicions at the maryage of my Lord Darsye

div.p: The groom was Thomas, Lord Darcy, Viscount Colchester and Earl Rivers, grandson of Thomas, first Lord Darcy, of Chiche (St Osyth), in Essex, and knight of the Garter. The bride was Mary Kitson, daughter of Sir Thomas and Lady Elizabeth Kitson, of Hengrave Hall (Gage, History and Antiquities of Hengrave, p 213).
