body.head: Suffolk, Kitson of Hengrave Hall 1627 SUKY13

div.head: f [21] (10 May)
div.ab: Giuen to ye morish dancher at ye gate xij d.

div.head: f [1] (12 February)
div.ab: My very goode Lord: yesterday I receiued your letters by your nephew Dudley, but have not yet perused masmas: for master; abbreviation mark missing PoriesPories: John Pory (1572–1636) parlement busines, which I will impart to Sir D. DiggesDiggs: Sir Dudley Diggs (c 1583–1639), MP, yf he come to towne in any time, he went away on wensday last and left this inclosed, which I thincke geues notice that the drie-handed Indians will remember themselues and you better then they haue don: I acquainted him with so much as you wrote touching the point that you wold not have yt pressed, for God and men loue a cheerfull geuer as well as a gratefull receuer, so that how yt comes about I know not, vnles perhaps by reason of the voyce that runns of your returne, which (vpon better aduise) I do not thincke to be likely, till the treatie of renewing the truer be fully finished. we heare the King wilbe here within this fortnight and spend all the lent here about: they passe the time merrilie at Newmarket and the running maske raunges over all the countrie, where there be fit subiects to entertain yt, as lately they haue ben at Sir Iohn Crofts neere BerrieBerrie: at Little Saxham, near Bury St Edmunds, and in requitall those Ladies have inuited them to a maske of theyre owne inuention, (all those faire sisters beeing summoned for the purpose) so that on thursday next the King Prince and all the court go thether a shrouing.

div.p: In a later letter written to Sir Dudley Carleton on 22 December 1621 (TNA: SP 14/124, f [1v]), Chamberlain appears to be referring to this same performance when he says: 'before the .K. came from Newmarket he went to Sir Iohn Crofts where he had great entertainment, and a maske made by his daughters, and some few dayes after they were likewise intertained‸ and lodgest at Newmarket.' Newmarket, in Lackford Hundred, lies between Bury St Edmunds and Cambridge.

For an essential article on the likely performance itself in February 1619/20 and the certain performance in December 1621, both at the house of Sir John Crofts, see McGee, 'Masque,' pp 371–84. The article identifies the women who performed in the masque; describes the physical contexts, the structure, and the purpose of the masque; potential author(s) of the masque; biographical details of members of the Crofts circle; and a description of the manuscript containing the masque, which is now at Yale University. McGee also includes a modern edition of the masque on pp 380–4. For a discerning discussion of Ben Jonson's roles for women in masques at court, see Suzanne Gosset, '"Man-maid, begone": Women in Masques,' English Literary Renaissance 18 (1988): 96–113.

The unconstrained activities of the women in the Croft circle in their producing of masques belie the countervailing views toward women and performance then circulating in the kingdom, and indeed the complexity of the King's own responses. As Chamberlain reports in a later paragraph of this letter: 'Our pulpits ring continually of the insolence and impudence of women, and to helpe the matter forward the players haue likewise taken them to taske, and so the ballades and ballad-singers, so that they can come no where but theyre eares tingle: and yf all this will not serue the King threatens to fall vpon theyre husbands parents or frends that haue or shold haue powre ouer them and make them pay for yt.'

div.head: ff [1–1v] (22 December)
div.ab:
my very goode lord: the weather continues still so violent that I am forced to write in my gloues a thing I neuer vsed nor practised before. since my last the King wrote twise to the tower house to haue them go on with busines that this meeting might be a session, (the copie of the later I heare send you) to which they made a mannerly aunswer on tewsday within two howres after yt came, and sent yt away to Tiballs presently by the chauncellor of the DuchieDuchie: Sir Humphrey May, chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, mr . murrey of the bed chambermr . murrey of the bed chamber: John Murray, Sir Henry mildmay master of the iewell house, and another that I haue forgotten, but withall (for feare of surprising) gaue order to the Speaker and the whole house to meet at fowre of the clocke, where they conceiued, set downe, and entred this protestation inclosed; which I doubt is nothing plea=sing aboue, and for preuenting whereof there came a commission next morning to adiourne the parlement till the 8th of Februarie: I haue heard there was somwhat hatching likewise in the vpper house to the same purpose, and that they had geuen order to mr Sel=den, to reuiew the records and make perfect his papers that were mangled or missing . . ‸in his last restraint. the lower house was earnestly bent vpon this point though they wanted the assistaunce of some of their prin=cipall members, for Sir SamuellSamuell: Sir Samuel Sandys (1560–1623), elder brother of Edwin Sandys and Sir edwin SandsSands: Sir Edwin Sandys (1561–1629) stoode mute all this meeting, and our frend Sir D. Ds.D. Ds.: Sir Dudley Digges (c 1583–1639), MPeither silent, or so litle regarded when he spake that he had ben better haue sat still. in truth I am sory in his behalfe, for he is a proper (and I presume) an honest man, but he hath vtterly lost the house, that hath a strong opinion of his haleing, and the worst is he may chaunce hereafter stand straight on neither legge. on thursday abowt three or fowre a clocke in the morning a great fire brake out in the sire clarkes office in chaun=cerie lane, that burnt downe that house and fowre more, besides three others quite pulled downe, and that which was Sir mathew Caries scaped narrowly, but yet is in a manner quite defaced and torne in peices: the fire was so vehement that yt caught hold of the Rolles on the other side of the street, but by great labour and daunger yt was quenched, for which seruice Sir Iulius Caesar gaue
twentie pound among them that best deserued yt. there is great store of monie saide to be lost besides other things of value, but the losse of rolles, recordes, and writings, is irreparable. the King comes to towne this day, and on Monday christens the Lord Treasurers young sonne, whose Lady is saide to lie in very gorgeously, and (yf all be true) far beyond the qualitie they were in not longe since. before the King came from Newmarket he went to Sir Iohn CroftsCrofts: of Little Saxham, near Bury St Edmunds where he had great entertainment, and a maske made by his daughters, and some few dayes after they were likewise intertained‸ and lodgest at Newmarket. The States haue not yet had audience, but perhaps to morow they may.

div.p: John Selden (1584–1654) was a jurist and scholar of English law; see Chamberlain, Letters ;TNA: SP 14/124, ff 385, 387, 397

div.head: f [140] (16 February)
div.ab: the king is still at Newmarket but expected here within ten or twelue dayes; he is to go the next weeke ashrouing to Sir Iohn CroftsSir Iohn Crofts: Sir John Crofts (1563-1628), of Little Saxham, near Bury St Edmunds, that Lady and her daughter Cecilie haue ben much at Newmarket of late. the earle of OxfordOxford: Henry de Vere (1593-1625), eighteenth earl of Oxford came hither yesterday from sea reinfecta,reinfecta: for re infecta: 'with the matter unfinished or not done'for while he was prouiding somwhat he wanted at Portesmowth the eastfrdianeastfrdian: for Eastfordian? ships are saide to haue passed along by the coast of Fraunce into Holland. the Lord of DoncasterLord of Doncaster: James Hay (c 1590–1636), first earl of Carlisle and Viscount Doncaster is arriued this day, his Lady with phisicke hath brought herself into a poore plight, and so ouerthrowne and weakened her body that yt is doubted she will hardly . hold owt. Here be certain verses of made of Dr CorbetDr Corbet: Richard Corbett (1582–1635), bishop of Oxford, later of Norwich deane of christ church who preaching before the King at woodstocke last sommer, was so grauelled that he was faire to geue ouer, neither had he better lucke in his play then in his preaching, for thincking to mend the matter with a Comedie of the mariage of the Arts, yt proued so tedious as well for the matter as the action, that the King indured yt with great impatience, wherupon the very boyes and children flouted yt .with a rime. A mariage we had but offering there was none, saue that the King offered twise or thrise to be gone. So with the remembrance of my best seruice to my goode Lady I commend you to the protection of the Almighty
From London this 16th of February 162216th … 1622: numerals underlined

div.head: single sheet
div.ab: Thys s the Game mony receyvyd Receyvydreceyvyd Receyvyd: dittography by the handes william Dyuer parych pryst off metefyld ye sunday next fter ye ascencion off owr lord god. the secund ȝer off king henry viij

row.cell: Item for a booke for exersice on the Sunday

div.p: The heading of this account says that it was for the year 1634 'from St Stephens day,' thus the account runs from 26 December to 25 December. The entry is a reference to the King's reissued Book of Sports, which permitted traditional pastimes and diversions on Sundays. I would like to thank Mrs. Louise Kennedy, archivist, of SRO: Ipswich, for making it possible to see and photograph extremely fragile leaves from this otherwise unavailable volume.

Henry Despenser (c 1341–1406), bishop of Norwich from 1370, with residence in the Bishop's Palace, Norwich. He was known as the 'fighting bishop' for his important part in suppressing the Peasants' Revolt of 1381 and was a fierce opponent of Lollardy.

div.p: A partially surviving date at the top of f [6v] says that this is the account of ' Wilbeye,' chaplain and general receiver of the manor chantry of the Blessed Virgin Mary, 3 Henry IV until Michaelmas following, so for 1401–2, preceded by the account for 1400–1. Thus it appears that this is a two-year account, and that the accounts likely ran from 29 September to 29 September.
William de Willoughby (c 1370–1409) was fifth Baron Eresby with residence at Spilsby, Lincolnshire (John Wasson, John (ed), Collections 11, Malone Society (Oxford, 1980/81), 227.

It seems at least possible that the 'Wilbye' named in the heading of the account as being chaplain and general receiver of the chantry was a member of the Willoughby family. The minstrel(s) of the lords Willoughby performed often at Mettingham College beween 1401–2 and 1451–2, and once in 1507.

div.p: BL: Additional MS 40070, which may be a rough account, has essentially the same entries as BL: Additional MS 33990 for the years 1509–14, with some variations and generally less detail. The sums are the same in both accounts. MS 40070, f 19, says that the poor minstrel was paid once, and that the players were Shank's associates ('socijs suis,' spelled Schanke). The accounts also include payment of 12d to a servant of Lord Oxford, the servant not demonstrably a performer.

Likewise MS 40070 (f 76) uses the words 'in nat' Domini in the first entry, and 'in natali domino' in the second one. The account also includes the seemingly customary payment to Oxford's servant, not identifiably a performer.

Memorandum þat the yer off ower lorde gode Ml vC & v on Sent Thomas day the Cherchewardenes affor namyd Received off þe profites & gyftes þat warn gevyn ffor a play off Sent Thomas played þe same day & yer in the hall yard all Charges deductyed

div.p: Middleton-Stewart identifies the Hall Yard, where the play was staged, as being 'part of the manorial complex which lay beyond the church' (Records, p 44, n 16). Since the play was held on St Thomas Day and dramatized St Thomas, it would appear that the guild of St Thomas figured large in its production. That guild was one of the larger of Mildenhall's nine religious guilds. It possessed considerable lands, had a messuage opposite the church, and received numerous bequests from parishioners of note (Middleton- Stewart, Records, pp xl, xliv, lxx, 85, 85n, 99, 120–1, 125).
On ff 1, 4v, and 9v, the account names four wardens. In 1503–4 they are called church reeves but thereafter they are called churchwardens.

row.cell: Item Receyuyd for halywell May ale
Item Receyuyd for ye town May ale
Item Receyuyd for ye May ale in ye becke Weche
xl s. iiij s.xl s. iiij s: for xl s. iiij d.
Item Receyuyd ffor ye westrow May

div.p: Wasson says that these are the accounts of the wardens of the guild of St Thomas a Becket, but I see no evidence of that in the accounts (Wasson, Plays and Players, p 190). The Record Office seems to be right in calling them the churchwardens' accounts of the parish of St Mary and St Andrew, though Mildenhall did have six major religious guilds: Corpus Christi, Great Guild of Trinity and St John Baptist, St Mary, St James, Blessed Trinity, and St Thomas the Martyr (Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 272–3), plus three others. Holywell Row, Beck Row, and West Row were hamlets of Mildenhall. Each seems to have contributed to the town ale but they also mounted ales of their own, whose proceeds they also gave to the church of St Mary in Mildenhall. Three of these four parts of greater Mildenhall had its own medieval green (Birch, Ancient Sites, p 270).

row.cell: Item payd for ye pleyeres at ye Mayall
Item payd to ye tabyrar at ye May ale
Item Receyuyd for ye May ale ye summa
li. iij s. iiij d. ob.
Item Receyuyd for ye May ale in ye West Rowe
Item recepimus de Westrow ex colleccione Thome Skott domini de Mysrule in tempore Natalis domini Anno xxo Henrici viij
Item recepimus de diuersis parochianis in mense Maij vltimo preterito pro ludo vocato Maygame
Likewise we take receipt from Westrow from the collection of Thomas Skott, the lord of misrule at Christmastide in the twentieth year of our lord Henry VIII
Likewise we take receipt from various parishioners during the month of May last past for the game called 'May game'

div.p: Thomas Skott (f 20), who lived in Westrow, served as churchwarden there in 1538 and upon the death of vicar John Wylkynson served as vicar of Mildenhall from 1541 to 1555 (Middleton-Stewart, Records, pp xxxix, xlii, 78, and 92). In 1545 chantry priest William Reve designated Skott to be supervisor of his executors, and bequeathed to him his best surplice (Bury, Suffolk Record Office IC/500/1/10/81). Skott does not appear among the alumni of either Oxford or Cambridge (Middleton-Stewart, Records, p xlii). In his will, Skott designates his wife Agnes to distribute sums to the church on behalf of the poor and indigent (Middleton-Stewart, Records, p 78; for his will, see Bury, Suffolk Record Office, IC 500/2/19/).
Wasson lists the entry on f 20v as 1529, but if the account is 1528–9 and starts 22 April, it must be 1528 (Plays and Players, p 192).

div.p: The account on f 27 also lists gatherings on several other feast days.

The sum total given on f 29 appears to be referring to the amount received from all that year's ales. That total would necessarily include mimetically-informed May ales as well as those who had no clear connection to performance.

div.head: f [1v] (12 March)
div.ab: the King was ouertaken on sonday with a tertian ague, which continues yet, but without any manner of daunger yf he wold suffer himself to be ordered and gouerned by phisicall rules. I send here a rierie: likely for rime; MS deteriorated at fold made by one of kinges college in Cambrige vpon a play presented lately at Newmarket by his neighbours of Quenes college, yf you haue not seen yt alredy you will thincke yt worth the reading. so with the remembrance of my best seruice to my good Lady I commend you to the protection of the Almighty. From London this 12 of March 162412 … 1624: numerals underlined

div.p: According to Alan Nelson, the rime was most likely 'On Fucus,' a ballad written by Henry Moll of King's College, Cambridge, concerning a performance of Fucus Histriomastix before James I at Newmarket on or near 13 March 1622/3. Nelson transcribes the entire poem in Cambridge, vol 2, REED (Toronto, Buffalo, London, 1989), 878–80; also pt 1, p 598. For discussion of the authorship, manuscripts, modern edition, and performance history of the play Fucus Histriomastix, see Nelson, Cambridge, vol 2, pp 878-81, 897.

div.head: ff 367–8 (1 November; proved: 27 May 1622)
div.ab:
In the name of God Amen:In … Amen: in display script The first daye of November in the yeare of our Lord God One thowsand six Hundred Twenty and One I: William ffirmage of Rougham in the Countye of Suffolk gentleman being sickly and ill disposed as concerning my bodily health, yett of sound and perfect memorye thanckes be given to god therefore) Doe make and ordaine this my last will and Testament in manner and forme as followeth ffirst I bequeathe my soule into the handes of Allmightie God my Creator beleeving to be saved in in the only and all sufficient merittes of Iesus Christ my Redeemer, which ffaithe Godes blessed spirit encrease and strengthen in me Continually, Amen, my bodye likewise I Commend to Godes most mercifull disposition That whether in life or death I may be his And when it shall please him to call me out of this life, I will my body to be buried Item I giue vnto my brother ffrancis ffirmage all my landes Howses and Tenementes freehold to have and to hold to him and to his heyres by the vsuall Rentes and services due to the Lordes of the Mannors of whome the same are houlden And whereas I hold of the Lorde of the MannorLorde … Mannor: Jeffrey Lytell, who purchased the manor from Sir Nicholas Bacon sometime between 1561 and 1579 (when Bacon died). of greate Ashefeild in Suffolk certayne landes by Indenture of Lease for certaine yeares yett to come and vnexpired by a certaine rent in the said Indenture of Lease expressed my will and intent is that he my said brother ffrancis ffirmage shall have and hold to him his executors and assignes All those landes ffor by and during all that terme of yeares yet to come and vnexpired accordinge to the Indenture of Lease which I bequeathe vnto him his executors and assignes togeather with the said Indenture of Lease, and all other my deedes and writinges concerning my other landes Item I giue vnto my sister Shouldham Threescore poundes of good mony of England to be paid vnto hir within one yeare nexte after my decease, and also I giue vnto hir my Cupboard cloath and vallence for a bedd of Needleworke Item I giue vnto my Nephewe Thomas Shouldham, and to my Nephew William Shouldham to eache of them Twenty poundes of like mony when they shall attaine to their severall ages of one and twenty yeares Item I giue to my neece ffrances Shouldham Twenty poundes of like mony when shee shall attaine to the age of Eighteene yeares or at the daye of hir marriage which shall first happen Item I giue to my sister Gawdy fforty powndes of good mony of England to be paid vnto hir within two yeares next after my decease and also I giue vnto hir my watche Item I giue vnto my Nephewe Thomas Gawdy and to my Nephewe Edward Gawdy to eache of them twenty poundes of like mony when they shall attayne to their severall ages of one and twentye yeares Item I giue vnto my brother Mr Thomas Shouldham and to my brother Mr Edward Gawdy to eache of them five poundes in mony and likewise too each of them a ring of golde with deathes head and this posy Melioris ianua vitaeMelioris ianua vitae: in italic script; 'the door of a better life' worth fforty shillinges Item I giue vnto my vnckle Mr Henry ffirmage, and to my vnckle Mr Christofer Hirne, and to my vnckle Mr Ionas Pittes to eache of them a Ringe of golde with deathes head and the like posy as the former worth fforty shillinges Item I giue to my Aunt
Hirne and to my Aunt Pittes to eache of them a peece of plate worth three poundes Item I giue to my vnckle George Methwold three poundes in mony and to eache of his Children livingliving: second i written over e Twenty shillinges Item I giue to my vnckle Seffray three poundes in mony and to each of his children living twentye shillinges Item I giue to my Cosen Ioane Barwicke three poundes in mony Item Item I giue to my Goddaughter ffrances Shouldam, and to my Goddaughter Anne Pittes daughter of my Cosen Lionell Pittes, and to my Goddaughter Elianor Methwold daughter of my Cosen Robert Methwold, to eache of them a peece of Plate worth three powndes Item I giue to my godsonne Danyell Sutton sonne of Danyell Sutton sometymes Apothecary in Bury, and to my godson Edward Buller sonne of my Cosen Alexander Buller, and to my Goddaughter Anne Pittes daughter of my Cosen Thomas Pitts and to my Goddaughter Winifride Drury daughter of Mr Clement Drury of Rougham, and to my Goddaughter Elizabeth Goodricke daughter of Mr Samuell Goodricke of Rushbrooke to each of them twenty shillinges Item I giue to my Cosen Edmond Porter, and to my Cosen Thomas Pitts, and to my Cosen ‸Richard Herbert of Bury to eache of them fforty shillinges Item I giue to Mr Robert Drury of Rougham my Sett of English and Italian Madrigalles Manuscript to 3. 4. 5. and 6 voices, which haue my name on the Covers and are in Mr Kirby of Bury his Custody and to his wife Mrs Drury I giue my picture which is likewise in Mr Kirby his Custody, Item I giue to Mr Iohn Drury of Rougham my Sett of Latin Mottetes to 4.5. and 6. voices, and all other my Settes of singing bookes both printed and Manuscript (except those hereafter bequeathed to Mr Kirby) togither with Mr Morlyes introduction Item I giue to Mr Henry Kirchefeild of little Saxham my base vyoll with the Case and all my bookes of vyoll lessons both printed and manuscript Item I giue to Mr George Kirby of Bury my settes of bookes of ffancies and latin Mottetts to 5. and. 6. voices, and also my Lattin Mottettes to 7. and 8. voices which remaine in his handes yett vnfinished, together with all my dutch Roiall ruled paper and likewise I giue vnto him one ring of gould with deathes head and the like posy as the former worth fforty shillinges Item I giue to my man Edmond Hempston three poundes of good mony of England Item I giue to the poore of ye parisheof ye parish: written in the left margin and marked for insertion after poore of great Ashfeild in Suffolk forty shillinges to be distributed by the discretion of the Churchwardens and overseers for the poore of the said parish, and besides I giue vnto the said Poore at every Christmas yet to come for thes Tenn yeares six shillinges and eight pence to be in like manner distributed Item I giue to the Pore of the parish of (blank) (where I desire to be interred) ffive poundes to be distributed by the discretion of the Churchwardens & overseers for the poore of the said parishe. And lastly for the assured confidence and trust which I repose in my aforenamed Brother ffrancis ffirmage That he will performe all thinges accordinge to the true intent and meaning of this my last will and Testament I doe make and ordeine him my said brother ffrancis ffirmage sole Executor of this my last will and Testament and doe giue vnto him all other my goodes and Chattells not formerly given or bequeathed In wittnesse whereof I have written this my last will and Testament conteyned in one sheete of paper with myne owne hand, and haue therto subscribed my name and sette my seale in the presence of them whose names are written on the backside hereof By me William Firmage/ MemorandumMemorandum: in italic script that my further will and meaning is that my said Executor shall pay vnto my neece Anne Gawdy
the somme of Ten powndes which I bequeathe vnto hir when shee shall attayne to the age of Eighteene yeares or at the day of hir marriage which shall first happen Item I will that my said Executor shall pay vnto my vnckle William ffirmage the somme of Twenty poundes as so much required vpon a band entred vnto him by my ffather or mother Condicionally that he delivers out the said band to my said executor and discharge him thereof Lastly I remitt and forgiue vnto my vnckle Iohn ffirmage six poundes which hee oweth mee By me William Firmage./William Firmage: in italic script Sealed and subscribed and declared to be the last will and Testament of William ffirmage of Rougham the within named Testator in the presence of Peter Portman Iohn Scott, Abraham Coria etc./

div.head: single membrane (7 February) (Bill of complaint of John Cole)
div.ab: And further sheweth and informeth your most excellent Maiestie your Highnes said subiect That whereas contriveinge makeinge writeinge devisinge & publishinge of all manner of scandalous infamous and defamatory writinges are not onely straightly prohibited and forbidden by diuers your Maiesties most wholesome & ‸godly Lawes statutes and ordinances of this your Highnes realme of England but are alsoe very great and haynous offences against allmightie god and against the quiett and peaceable goverment of this your highnes realme of England by occasion and meanes whereof your Maiesties peace is often broken & disturbed and manie quarrells striffes and contencions doe arise growe and and are stirred vp amongst diuers of this your Highnes good and loveinge subiectes whereby manie times doe ensue murders manslaughters bloudshedds and other enormous and grevous crimes to the greate offence and displeasure of almightie god and in highe contempt and derogation of the Iustice of this your maiesties most happie and well governed realme and Comon weale vnder your Highnes peaceable and prosperous Raigne But nowe soe it is maye it please your most excellent Maiestie that the said Iohn Archer Clarke, ‸and other. dissolute and loose persons to your said subiect as yett vnknowne whose names he humblie praieth maie be heare incerted when they shalbe discouered beareinge causelesse mallice and displeasure against one George Battelly and Beatrice late the wife of William Breame deceased beinge persons of very honest life and conversacionconversacion: v written over an o did most wickedly faulsely and malliciously vppon or about the ffowerth daye of Maye in the eightenth yeare of your Maiesties most happie and prosperous raigne over England ffrance and Ireland contriue frame write devise and make one faulse slaunderous infamous scurrilous and defamatory lybell in writinge the tennor of which said slaunderous and infamous libell and writinge followeth in theise Wordes Viz. The West seas godesse in a crimson robe, her temple crowninge with a currall wreathe, brave Phebe haveing placed tellurs : line filler, plus hole in parchment globe, lightes from hir Caue hire fierie horsehorse: a secondr written above ther apparently to clarify to breath, All birdes take rest that vse the aire to fore, saue Philomell that nightly doth deplore, This poore musicion sitting all a lone, on a greene Hawthorne from the thunder blest, Carrolls in varied notes hir antique mone, keepeing a sharpned bryere against hir brest, the night shee spendes tuneinge hir change of shape, caused by perfidie and luxurious rape, Neere to this tree wheareas this poore bird sate, I spyed a man most carefull to behould, with dew bedawbed Cheekes condeming fate, effector of his troubles manie fould; my penne I tooke and from his mouth I wrote, the sable songe the poore soule songe god wott: Woe worth the time that ever I was borne, of man and woeman to be made a Iest, of all the worlde thus to be had in scorne, yett of my troubles theise are but the least, my hart is vexed with a burneing evill worse then to be possessed with a diuill; foule whoredomes villanie and dampned luxurie, ffor to the eies but freind to painefull Gowt, spoyler of witt & bravest memorie, Roote of all evill whence doth often sprovt, strange generacions with the bedd defylled; that manie a father scarse knowes his child, Though hell brede lust be daunced yet doth shee ware, as every prentise in the citty knowes, the richest garmentes feedinge daintiest fare, with beddes of downe herself for to repose, the Court the Citty ofte shee doth frequent, and in the Country she is resident, whore when shee visittes all she doth imploy And like a sole comaunder rule shee beres,beres: the illegible letter likely an a written over erasure our noble gentle and the roareing boye for Courte and Counterie all shee claimes as hires, All ile theire bonnettes to her fewe disdaine it, but thosethose: o written over another letter unable for to intertaine it, God makinge man both pure and iuste By nature, in his owne likenes after with all speed hee gaue him woman as the onely creature to bee his his helper at the time of neede. But shee, such was hir prones vnto euill, In steede of heaven shee help him to the Devill. Suche is my case beinge sole I tooke therefore A second help of an honest blod but shee alas is turned an errant ( )( ): parentheses enclosing a space for three or four letters; presumably a word left out either because it was indelicate or because the deponent did not know it A neighbouringe lecher turninge hir from good, Soe nowe its true as the olde proverbe goes, my children hardly theire owne father knowes, Waste not inoughe thou dringle breeched slave, to abuse my wife in suche a dampned sort, But of hir manie a child ‸forsooth must have. And I thou rascall keepe thy cursed sport. O wretched times that ore this sinfull age, should suffer such impietie to rage, With that I stept vnto him glad to knowe, his name, his country, towne, estate and place, requestinge whoe was author of his woe, constrayninge him to weare Acteons face, protestinge if hee would vnfould his minde, an alter idem of mee he should finde, my name is Dawlinge of St Nicholas Ellmeham South, the onely paradise of fertile Suffolke if you knowe the place, Theres my aboade and there my substaunce lies. The author of my Plague is Battally, renowned for whordome & sweete lechery. What Battaly quoth I baptized George of your towne, I knowe the man full well, a periured rascall in whose braines forge is framed muche vilanie without pararell Ould trustie towne bull, I hope to see thee crawle, ere it bee longe to some hospitall. An honest woman neere him scarse canne dwell, But of his bounty hee forsooth must give hir will Breame his wife canne tell you very well that hee hath bin an auncient benefactor, Since thou wearest not a Cuckolds hood alone, Dawlinge I pray the cease thy makeinge moane, Returne returne thee home againe and ceasse thy haples fortunes to deplore, A knave will bee a knave doe what you canne, A lecher, a lecher, soe will a whore a whore. The Blackmoore cannot bee washed white againe nor anie thinge that hath bin died in graine, Most humble thankes to you good Sir I give for your good counsaile, and I will indeavour with more contentment afterward to live regardinge lesse that filthy woman lecher. But neighbours all I pray you bee warned by mee look to your wives truste not George Battally. And the same beinge soe maliciouslie, wickedlie and falselie contrived framed made & written & devised by the saied Iohn Archer, : erasure with line filler and the saied other persons vnknowen, They the saied Iohn Archer : erasure with line filler & the saied other persons vnknowen ‸did in the saied moneth of Maye in the saied eighteenthe yeere of your Maiesties saied Raigne of England publishe, divulge, and spreade abroade in diverse townes & villages within the said County of Suffolke falselie & maliciouslie to slaunder discredite traduce & defame the saied George Battelley and the saied Beatrice, and alsoe to provok moove and stirre vp them and theire frendes to quarrells, contentions, strifes, and debates, whereby your Maiesties peace hath bin broken and disturbed. And the said Iohn Archer : erasure with line filler & the said & the said other persons vnknowen have at diverse other times & places in the Counties of Suffolke & Norfolke published, dispersed, spreade abroade and songe the same slaunderous and infamous libell & writinge to diverse to diverse and sundrie of your Maiesties lovinge and good subiects, aswell in the townes of Harlston, Beccles, Bungey the final Hallsworth, Yarmouth and the citie of Norwiche & in diuerse other places in Suffolke & Norfolke, to the greate slaunder and disgrace discredite, and reproche of the said George Battelley and the said Beatrice. In tender consideracion whereof and for that the saied periuries combinations confederacies faulse & slaunderous devisinge frameinge, contrivinge, wrytinge dispersinge, and publishinge of the saied slaunderous & infamous libells & writinges are offences not to bee suffered in anie well governed common wealth to escape with impunity for examples sake least others of like lewde and euill disposition mighte bee incouraged thereby to committ the like or greater offences, & the same doe tend to the great breache and disturbaunce of your Highnes peace and are against the most godlie lawes & statutes of this your Hignes Realme of England, and were all perpetrate done & committed since your Maiesties laste most gracious generall & free pardon, and are alsoe to the great wronge discredite defamacion and damage of your saide subiect ‸ & the said George Battelly & Beatrice. Maie it therefore please your most excellent Maiestie of your accustomed goodnes & clemencie to graunt vnto your Maiesties saied subiect your Maiesties most gracious writt of sub pena to bee directed to the saied Iohn Archer : erasure with line filler Samuell Tubbie & the sad other persons vnknowen commaundinge them therby at a certaine daie, & vnder a certaine paine therein to be limited personally to ‸ be & appeare before your most excellent Maiestie and your Highnes most Honorable ‸privy councill in your Maiesties most highe & honourable Court of Starre chamber then & there to Aunswere vnto the premisses, & to stand to, and abide such further order & direction therein as to your most excellent Maiestie & the saied Honorable Courte shall bee agreable to Iustice. And your saied subiect accordinge to his most bounden dutie shall daiely praie vnto god for your most excellent excellent Maiestie in all happines longe to liue & raigne over vs/.

div.head: single sheet (17 April)
div.ab: I Iohn Lymmer of Stowmarkete in the countie of Suffolk musician being : likely for sick or similar in body yet wholl of mynd & in perfecte memorye thankes be to god. do ordayne & make this my last will & Testament Item I gyve vnto marye my wyf all my goodes moveable aswell within the hows as without by what name or tytle soever they be called she paying my debtes & bringing my bodye decently to the yearthe. only excepting in my said gyfte of movable goodes my bookes & instrumentes of musicke which said bookes & instrumentes I give vnto Iohn my sonne in consideracione that the said Iohn shall paye vnto mary my wyf tenne shillinges of good & lawefull mony of ingland within one quarter of a yeare after my decease

row.cell: Layd out to my Cosen George Borrett for the playeres to goe away

div.p: The account was written on 7 January 1632/3. The only date entry on the page (six items before the one to the players) is a payment to the ringers on 5 November 1632. According to the headings, the accountants were Henry Borrett in 1632 and George Borrett in 1633, and they made their accounts on Plough Monday. In 1586–8 (pp 5v, 10) the accounts include payments for the town waytes, but these appear to be payments for weights and measures. Similar payments were made in 1595–7.

row.cell: I gave to Players for to be gone

div.p: The account was written on 13 January 1633/4. There are several dated entries closer to the top of the page, one to the schoolmaster for a quarter ending 1 November 1633, but that is followed immediately by a payment for a quarter ending on Michaelmas 1633, so it does not appear that the entries are in order, though it is probably safe to say that the payment to players happened in the fall. The only dated entry on the page (near the bottom) is a payment to the ringers on 5 November 1633. The payment to the players occurs much earlier, near the middle of the page.

row.cell: I Gave therle of Sussextherle of Sussex: Thomas Radcliffe (1526–1583), Lord Fitzwalter and eighth earl of Sussex players

div.p: A reference to a prohibition of tipplers and gamesters by the town occurs on f 89v.

The heading of this account (on f 102v) identifies its year as 16 Elizabeth without indicating month and day, although its first dated receipt is dated 10 November and its first payment 26 October (f 103).
Thomas Radcliffe (f [6]; 1526–83), Lord Fitzwalter from 27 May 1542, became eighth earl of Sussex from 17 May 1556/7. He had residences at New Hall, Essex, and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: paid ffor a new bull rope to Kynge & ffor lether to lyne the coller & ffor mendynge the coller
paid to the erle of Sussexthe erle of Sussex: Thomas Radcliffe (1526–1583), Lord Fitzwalter and eighth earl of Sussex his players

div.p: The heading of this account (f 114v) identifies its year as 17 Elizabeth without indicating month and day. However, the previous mayor had presented his final accounting to this year's accountant on 15 November, 16 Elizabeth (f 114v). A payment of 5s 8d for a Hock Monday dinner occurs on f 137.
Thomas Radcliffe (f [6]; 1526–83), Lord Fitzwalter from 27 May 1542, became eighth earl of Sussex from 17 May 1556/7. He had residences at New Hall, Essex, and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.

div.head: f 156 (17 November–17 November)
div.ab: to the lord Sheffyldeslord Sheffyldes: Edmund Sheffield (1565–1646), third Baron Sheffield of Butterwick players + plainge in the Towne iij s. iiij d.not allowed

div.p: A preceding payment on this page of 10s 1d for wine and cakes was also not allowed.
Edmund Sheffield (1565–1646) was third Baron Sheffield (of Butterwick) from 1568, with residence at Hammersmith, Middlesex. See P&P.

row.cell: Paide to the Lorde of Oxenfordes Players ye 17 of Aprill
Geven to the Erle of Leicesters Players the 2 of Iune

div.p: Edward de Vere (1550–1604) was seventeenth earl of Oxford from 3 August 1562, with residences at Hedingham Castle, Essex, and Hackney, Middlesex. See P&P.
Robert Dudley (c1533-1588) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: Item spent vpon the Bushopp of norwich Chanseler by consent of my Brethern v. s. iiij d. and to his orgayn player ij s. vj d. so all
Item by the lyke consent gave the lord stranges players
Item lykewyse to the Earle of Sussex players

div.p: The accounts refer to prohibitions concerning gaming and gaming houses in 1595-6 (f 221v), and elsewhere throughout the volume, and give a detailed description of gaming in an alehouse in 1596 (f 219v). The entries reflect a general effort to gain control of behavior in the town, of which the order in 1606-7 concerning plays seems to be part. See .

Robert Redmayne (d. 1625) was chancellor of the diocese of Norwich from 1588. He was a relative of William Redman, bishop of Norwich, who served from his election in 1594 until his death in office in 1602.

Ferdinando Stanley (c 1559–94) was thirteenth Baron Strange (of Knokyn) from 1572, and succeeded to the earldom of Derby on 25 September 1593, with residences at Lathom House, Knowsley and New Park in Lancashire. See P&P.
Henry Radcliffe (1533-93) was ninth earl of Sussex from 9 October 1583, with residence at New Hall, Essex. See P&P.

div.head: f 134 (29 September-29 September)
div.ab: Whereas the Hall comonlye called the Mootehall of this towne of Sudburye hath byn broughte in Muche ruyn and decaye by meanes of diuers disordred and vnrulie persons resortinge thither to playes of enterludes and other playes heretofore vsually suffred to be acted within the same Hall, The which ‸ And for asmuche as the saide Hall by the consent of the Maior Aldermen & Burgeses of the saide towne have byn nowe latlie repaired & bewtified by the nowe Maior aswell at the greate chardges of the Corporacion of this towne as also at the proper chardges of the saide Maior as vppon his accompte nowe shewed forth vnto vs it dooth & maye appeere, ffor the avoydinge of which inconvenience & to the ende that no more playes maye be hereafter to be acted within the same to Hall Yt is ordred consented & decreed by the full consent & agreament of the Maior Aldermen & Burgeses of this towne That if any person or persons which shall ha succeede in the place or office of the Maior of this towne or his or their Deputie or Deputies shall at any tyme hereafter give licence vnto or per willinglie permitt & suffer any playes of Enterludes or other playes to be acted or kepte within the same Hall the same person or persons therein so offendinge shall forfecte and paye to & for the vse of Corporacion of the saide towne, the somme of five powndes of good & lawfull money of England for euery tyme in that behalffe offendinge, To be levyed of the goodes and cattelles of suche offendor by waye of distresse

div.p: Anne of Denmark (f [4v]1574–1618/19) was crowned as queen on 25 July 1603. See P&P.
James Stuart (f [3v]; 1566– 1625), was crowned James I of England on 24 March 1602/3. See P&P.

row.cell: Item given to the Queens Players
Item given to the Prynces Players

div.p: Anne of Denmark (1574–1618/19) was crowned queen of England on 25 July 1603. See P&P.

row.cell: giuen to the quens ‸& princes players a Gratuite

div.p: The Sudbury records confirm that visiting troupes performed in one of Sudbury's two Moot Halls (f 134). The older of them, the so-called Old Moot Hall, on Cross Street, dates from the fifteenth century. It still survives. The records, being from a later era, provide no evidence that it served as a performance venue. The second of the two, the New Moot Hall, aka Town Hall, dates from the mid-sixteenth century. Visiting troupes certainly performed there until at least 1606–7, at which point town officials forbade its further use for that purpose. This proper Moot Hall survived until 1841 when it was torn down and replaced with a new town hall. It survives only in drawings and water colour paintings (see W.W. Hodson, 'Old Moot Hall,' p 266.)
This book also contains many references to alehouses and gaming, as, for example, on ff 16 and 169.
Anne of Denmark (1574–1618/19) was crowned queen of England on 25 July 1603. See P&P.
Charles Stuart (f 225v; 1600–48/9) was prince of Wales from 4 November 1616 until his accession to the Crown on 27 March 1625. See P&P.

div.head: p 72 (5 May–28 March) (rendered 1 May 1620) (Disbursements and Payments)

row.cell: To the Quenes players the Ladye Elizabeth her players & the children of the Revelles euerye of them x s. in all

div.p: This account was presented by the Mayor on 1 May 1620 but described itself as being for 1618 and 1619 (p 71).

The entry before the payment to the Queen's players on p 72 is a payment on Easter Monday (29 April) 1619 at the Crown for dinners and horses for Captain Sir Robert Crane and his officers, and dinners for the brethren of the town. No dated payment follows the one to players.

While each of the three troupes was paid its own 10s, the fact that the three payments and the three troupes are clustered as a single entry in several instances suggests the possibility that the three were travelling and performing together.
Anne of Denmark (1574–1618/19) was crowned queen of England on 25 July 1603.
Elizabeth Stuart (f 5; 1596–1661/2) was daughter to James and Anne; she was crowned queen of Bohemia 7 November 1619, with residences in Europe from 1613. See P&P.

row.cell: To the Princes & the Ladie Elizabeths servantes & To the Children of the Revells to every of them Sixe shillinges in all

div.p: The account on p 96 was presented by the Mayor on 16 April (Easter Day) 1620, but described itself as being for 1619 and 1620.

While each of the three troupes was paid its own 10s,the fact that the three payments and the three troupes are clustered as a single entry in several instances suggests the possibility that the three were travelling and performing together.
Charles Stuart (1600–48/9) was crowned Charles I (f [6]) of England on 27 March 1625. See P&P.
Elizabeth Stuart (f 5; 1596–1661/2) was daughter to James and Anne; she was crowned queen of Bohemia 7 November 1619, with residences in Europe from 1613. See P&P.
Anne of Denmark (1574–1618/19) was crowned queen of England on 25 July 1603.

row.cell: Given to the Queens players the Ladie Elizabeth hir players and the Children of the revells

div.p: The payment preceding the one to the Queen's players on p 174 was made on 17 January 1621/2 to the jury at the sessions. The payment following the one to the players was made on 21 February 1621/2 at the Crown to the clerk of the Market and some of the town's brethren.

While each of the three troupes was paid its own 10s,the fact that the three payments and the three troupes are clustered as a single entry in several instances suggests the possibility that the three were travelling and performing together.
Elizabeth Stuart (f 5; 1596–1661/2) was daughter to James and Anne; she was crowned queen of Bohemia 7 November 1619, with residences in Europe from 1613. See P&P.
Anne of Denmark (f [4v]1574–1618/19) was crowned as queen on 25 July 1603. See P&P.

row.cell: Item to twoo companyes of players

div.p: The account on p 240 was presented by the mayor on 4 October 1624 and was therefore for the years 1622-3 (p 239; also numbered as f 126v). The account is chronologically arranged, and the nearest preceding entry (6 away) is a payment made on 10 October 1623 for dinners at the session; none of the entries on p 240 following the payment to the players bears a date.

row.cell: Item laid out to the Drumers for awakinge the people to goe chouse the Knightes
Item given to the Droomers & others that plaied of flutes when Kinge Charles was proclaimed

div.p: According to the heading on p 279, the account on p 280 was presented by the mayor on 4 September 1626 and was therefore for the years 1625–6. The final entry of the account on p 281 further confirms the date of 4 September 1626.

The second entry on the page reimburses the mayor and a sergeant for the time when the mayor sat with the knights concerning subsidies. The next entry similarly reimbursed the mayor when King Charles was proclaimed. A subsequent entry indicates that the mayor and other officials of the town were those actually choosing the knights of the shire and that the event included their horses and a meal. The people were being summoned, one might think, to attend upon the event (to take part in or witness the spectacle). But given the many entries on the next page of the account (p 281) involving soldiers and their training by knights, one cannot rule out that the summoning involved musters. None of the entries on the page bears a date.

Suffolk, Tasburgh of Flixton Hall 1593–4 SUAR03

body.head: Suffolk, Tasburgh of Flixton Hall 17th Century SUAR06

div.head: f 33
div.ab: WherA licence for a Mynstrell./ in the parliament begonn & holden at westminster the viijth of May in the xiiijth yeare of our late soueraigne lady quene Elizabeth ther was amonges other good actes & statutes one mad for the vtter suppressing of suchThose be Iuglers pedlers Tynkers pettie chapmen fencers bearwardes Common playeres in enterludes mynstrills or such like. persones as by the seid Statute are expressed & declared to be Roges vacaboundes & sturdy beggeres amonges which number mynstriles not belonging to any baron of this Realme or other noble personage of greater degre that should wander abroad & haue not a lycense of twoe Iustices of the peace at the least wherof one must be of the Quorum wher & in what sheir they shall happen to wander shalbe taken adiudged and demed as Roges & vacaboundes & shalbe punnished according to the tenor of the said act. Be it therfor knowne vnto all vnto whom these presentes shall come that we the Iustices of peace whose names are here vnderwritten haue thought it good for diuerse good causes & Consideracions vs & euery of vs especially mouing licensed & by these presentes doe lycense w: S of C in the County of Essex mynstrel to goe abroad within the said Countye of Essex to get his liuing in the way of truth by his said art of mynstrelsy provided alwaies that if the seid w S doe not from time to time behaue himself quietly & honestly in his said wandering and goinggoing: 4 minims for in abroad But loyter or otherwise misdeameanor himself against the lawes of this Realme. that then this our licence to be vtterly void & of none effect & that from thencforth it shalbe lawfull to all & euery the kinges maieties officeres to punnish him as a vacabound or othewise, accordinge To the lawes of this Realme. This present licence or any thing therin Conteyned to the Contrary not withstanding. And this our licence to indure for the space of one hole yeare next after the dat of these presentes in witnes wherof etc.

div.p: This statute of 29 June 1572 was An Acte for the punishement of Vacabondes and for Releif of the Poore & Impotent, an act reaffirmed and amended in 1576 and 1584–5 (Statutes of the Realm, vol 4, pt 1 (London, 1819), 590).
